38498761.review:
[h1] Recenzja... studni [/h1]
[b] Downwell [/b] jest platformową grą rouge-like z proceduralnie generowanymi poziomami. 
Ma też nawet duży stopień trudności, jest szybka i krótka, jednak na swój typ idealna. Cena też jest zachęcająca (11 zł za taką grę to dość dobra okazja).
Nie ma ona jakiejść grafiki z kosmosu, wykorzystuje tylko 3 kolory i tyle. Jednak to wcale nie przeszkadza. Jest nawet plusem, bo pójdzie nawet na słabym sprzęcie. Też nie zajmuje za dużo pamięci.
[b] Teraz coś więcej o grze... [/b]
W Downwell naszym celem jest po prostu zejście na sam dół studni. Oczywiście muszą być przeciwnicy, którzy nam w tym przeszkodzą. Mamy na szczęście nasze strzelające giwerobuty, które poradzą sobie nawet z potężniejszymi przeciwnikami czy kamieniami.
[u] Rodzaje naszych butków są zróżnicowane [/u], każdy w inny sposób działa. Buty nasze oczywiście muszą mieć jakąś amunicję, jedne typy zabierają jej więcej, drugie mniej. Amunicja regeneruje się albo gdy staniemy na jakimś podłożu, albo zabijemy przeciwnika w stylu Mario, czyli naskoczymy na niego. 
[b] Ważne są tutaj gemsy [/b], za które niedość, że możemy zwiększyć limit amunicji (możemy je również zwiększyć przez właśnie zmianę butków, tak samo ze zdrowiem), uleczyć się lub podwyższyć limit zdrowia (oczywiście podczas jednej rozgrywki), to za pomocą nich odblokowujemy specjalne style poruszania się postaci, dające nam różne plusy i minusy, a nawet zmianę wyglądu całej gry.
Nie lubisz czerwieni? Zmień na niebieski!
Jednak to co w tych całych gemsach jest najważniejsze, wzmacniają one nasze buty, przez co są znacznie silniejsze i skuteczniejsze.
[u] Typów przeciwników mamy dwóch [/u]. Te na które możemy zabić w stylu Mario i te, które możemy zabić tylko bronią, a naskoczenie skończy się... stratą hp.
Za każde przejście poziomu dostajemy możliwość dania umiejętności dla naszej postaci, np. jetpack. [spojler] Jest nawet styl, który całkowicie eliminuje tą mechanikę [/spojler].
W przejściach po bokach planszy (nawet w okolicach), które prowadzą do sklepu, innych broni do butków, czy nawet złóż gemsów, mamy zatrzymany czas. Możemy to wykorzystać, zrobić sobie krótką pauzę, czy nawet uniknąć przeciwników.
Jednak, żeby sie zbytnio nie rozkręcić, zrobię krótkie podsumowanie.
[h1] Plusy [/h1]
[olist]
[*] Każdy teren ma unikalnych przeciwników (mamy 4 lokacje).
[*] Jest dostępny po ukończeniu gry Hardmode (jakby było za łatwo).
[*] Różne typy broni.
[*] Możliwość odpoczynku w niektórych miejscach.
[*] Bonusy za nie dotykanie ziemi i kombosy.
[*] Szybka i regrywalna rozgrywka.
[*] Niska cena.
[*] Różne zachowania przeciwników.
[/olist]
[h1] Minusy [/h1]
[olist]
[*] Wysoki poziom trudności, który nawet w wersji podstawowej może być zbyt trudny dla niektórych (np. 4 lokacja).
[*] Brak możliwości zapisu gry (albo zginiesz, albo przejdziesz).
[*] Grafika, która mimo, że nie przeszkadza i wpasuje się w klimat gry, mogła być jednak trochę bardziej rozbudowana.
[/olist]
[h1] Czy warto tą grę kupić? [/h1]
Tak, warto. Gra jest tania, przyjemna. Na zabicie czasu lub po prostu dla zabicia nudy idealna. Może trochę zastanawiać grafika i właśnie cena, jednak przysięgam, gra jest naprawdę dobra. Jeśli Moppin jeszcze kiedyś stworzy jakąś grę tak samo przyjemną, osobiście mogę kupić nawet w ciemno.

38481935.review:
It's a vertically scrolling platformer where you go down, stomp on and shoot dudes, collect and purchase powerups. Good for quick, arcadey play. Sort of like an opposite, retro styled equivalent to the free flash game "Goin' Up" if you've ever played that. If you're looking at this and wondering if you'll get anything out of it, I'd say check out Goin' Up. If you like the gameplay of chaining together stomping on enemies and seeing how far you can go, you'll probably like this.

The game's equal parts fun and infuriating. Major gripes I have with it are: The platforms that enemies can pass through but not the player are really, really annoying and mostly just add frustration to the game, the faster you fall the more your camera loses track of the player sprite making navigation plain difficult and left/right movement while airborne is excessively floaty from the curve in acceleration/deceleration. I feel like it would be more fun if I could change directions and stop movement easier. I get that difficulty can be a positive thing, but it's not automatically a good thing, especially if it's from the controls being floaty, that's just aggravating.
I'd definitely add contra-style dropdown to the thin platforms and tighten the movement up if I could, personally.

38291667.review:
"Okay, I'm gonna get past 1-1 this time. I know it."

"Alright, I died, I'll get it this time."

"Nice! Lets get to 2-1 now"

"Alright, I died, but lets try it again"

"Alright, let's try it again"

"Alright, let's get to 2-1 again"

-3 hours in game-

"Yes! Made it to 3-1! Let's make it to 4-1 now"

-dies-

"Fuck this game"

Really though, Downwell is an amazing indie title for its price. Being one of the indie titles that has a android mobile release (Looking at you Crypt of the NecroDancer), it'd be worth it if it were $10.

[h1] What this game does right [/h1]

It's easy to pick up and just play, no 30 minute story cutscene telling you what's going on. Just go down and shoot stuff with your gunboots, it's that simple. The movements are fluid, the shooting is spot on, and all the gun modules are balanced in my personal opinion. Once you go down to the depths of the well, it progessively gets harder with you, the player learning how things work and adapting your play style to fit that criteria.

[h1] What this game doesn't do right [/h1]

Remember how I said the gun modules are balanced? The upgrades aren't, in fact only a small portion of them are actually useful.

For example, knife and fork. It works progressively, yes, but more often than not you'll not touch the enemy at all or you'll try to go near it and get hit by another enemy.

Also, the game is a tad bit short. It'd be neat if the game had a looping mechanic like Nuclear Throne does. However, this is a $3, so it does have its limits though.

Also, jumping on enemies has really awkward hit detection sometimes. You can land a little bit to the left or right side and sometimes get hit.


Would I recommend it? If you haven't seen the thumbs up, then yeah. It's a great and simple indie game I think some roguelike fans would really enjoy.

38064408.review:
One of the best time-killers out there. Combine a simple yet effective level design, pitch-perfect smooth movement, along with excellent chiptune music and you have Downwell. 

The game stars this... white pixel person that goes down a well, and it goes wild from there. As you go down stomping all opposition, you have these gunboots, which serve both as firearms and gliding tools if you want to. What makes it work, however, is how satisfying the game feels to control. The movement combined with the sound effects grant this feedback that makes you feel like a complete badass. It encourages you to try out the different combinations.

That being said, the game offers challenge and you'll probably die quite a bit. Not that it hinders the game, since going through the areas is actually rather short if you get it right. You also get perks after beating each level, which helps you out a lot. All in all, the game offers a fun loop.

It's worth a shot, and is cheap as fuck too. I mean, what is there to lose? Quite a few hours, apparently.

WOW!  

Gorgeous little pixels...This is like Metroid, goin down down down...It truly brings me back to the to the 80's, then up to '89 when the GameBoy came about!  

I totally LOVE the pixel art and animation, when you take a moment away from the game and really look at what he created, you can really appreciate his skill and creativity.

Though it might not seem so, it is a rogue-like arcade style game that seems to take its influence directly from Metroid...using the long tubular rooms, that you can only go down into.

For only $3 you cannot go wrong with this one.

As much as I think anyone can appreciate the pixel artistry, it really is a HARDCORE platformer and may not be for everyone.  It is tough and can be frustrating, but I have enjoyed every moment of the experience thus far.

Tate mode it pretty cool, allow me to turn screen and get a full screen experience.


ACHIEVEMENTS:  It is a tough game, so don't expect to 100% without a lot of rage quitting!

37838695.review:
[i]Cayendo por un pozo mientras hay cosas que buscan c*garte en el camino. Como la vida misma...[/i]

[h1]Resumen[/h1]

Downwell es un juego bastante simple. Tanto que creo que con el chiste de arriba practicamente resumi a que va el juego: Sos un tipo que esta felizmente pasandola bomba bajo la luz de la luna pero que, por alguna extraña razon se le paso por la cabeza "che, mi vida esta demasiado tranquila, a lo mejor caer a un pozo sin fondo me traeria algo de adrenalina". 

Al principio todo tranquilo. Caes, te cruzas con murcielagos, tortugas, caracoles, gusanitos, eh.... cosos (?) y demas cosas que se disponen a acabar con uno, pero podes acabar tranquilamente. Dos reglas: blanco: se puede matar saltando, rojo: solo disparando. El mismo boton del salto es el de disparo. Eventualmente te encontras con cuevas (protegidas por algun tipo de escudo termporal (?)) donde pueden haber negocios o simplemente mejoras de armas o vida.

Pasando la primer seccion vas a poder elegir entre 3 upgrades que se van a mantener durante toda esa partida hasta que mueras, como todo buen juego con aspectos roguelike. Cada dos secciones el area cambia completamente junto a los enemigos. El juego tiene 4 areas. ¡Esta en vos llegar hasta el final y ver que hay!

[h1]Lo Bueno[/h1]

-Juego simple y adictivo. Tiene el sindrome del determinado: rejugas tanto que eventualmente avanzas mas un poquitito en cada partida.

-BARATO. Y lo vale por el contenido que trae.

-Salvo que dures bastante, son partidas relativamente cortas.

-Aun habiendolo pasado, conseguir todos los achievements puede ser un desafio bastante entretenido si son bien cabezaduras y no se frustran.

-Este punto es mas subjetivo, pero por alguna razon este juego me relaja. No se si es el ambiente retro, la musica o que...

[h1]Lo Malo[/h1]

-De nuevo, si no te gustan los roguelikes, te tengo una mala noticia...

-Honestamente estoy pensando algo mas negativo para tirar pero no se me ocurre. Quizas la duracion del juego si es que le agarraste la mano?

[i]En resumen, un juego MUY barato y vale cada centavo que gastaste en el.[/i]

37819849.review:
[b][i]It's infuriating. It makes you start over and over. But it makes you return.[/i][/b]

It's one of those games who send you rock bottom intentionally, metaphorically and literally. It sure sucks. There was one time I thought "boy I'll never even reach near the end of the game, it's pretty impossible". Happens it isn't. 37784638.review:
I never could have imagined that I would get so much raw enjoyment out of Downwell. Even after playing for just a few hours total, I would definitely go the extra mile to say that Downwell has one of the best kinds of ''Game Feel'' I have experienced thus far, where the mechanics of the game altogether work in harmony with each other.

Gameplay wise it draws inspiration from another popular rogue-lite platformer, Spelunky. Both in Downwell and Spelunky, you venture down into the perilous depths of the underground world, collecting valuables, finding power-ups and upgrades and defeating all sorts of critters and creatures along the way. But what differentiates Downwell from Spelunky, is that Downwell focuses more on the combat aspect, both enemy and player wise, where enemies left undefeated pose an actual challenge for the player later on, which encourages players to defeated as many enemies as effeciently as they can, so that later on they have more practical experience on each levels unique enemy types and have more gems to buy health and upgrades from shops located in set levels. 

When it comes to the presentation, Downwell excels on all aspects in my honest opinion. The game has a very clean and charming pixel artstyle with high contrasting colors helping everything pop from the levels. The game also sports a  chiptune soundtrack that is very pleasing to listen to whils't playing, because the tracks also help to create the proper atmosphere for each stage. The sound design makes every action, from shooting your gunboots to simply jumping on enemies and collecting gems, feel incredibly satisfying and rewarding.

TL;DR: Just buy it. Its dirt cheap, fun as heck and the quintessential ''pick up and play'' rogue-lite on Steam.

37532926.review:
*Down, Down, Down*

This game is incredibly well designed! I genuinely felt like everything I did was my fault, every little bit of damage and messing up combos. It helped train my reflexes.

To start, you'll notice the fact that there's no story. Sorta. You jump down a well, fighting frogs and turtles, bats and worms, demonic space monsters and snails. The usual. Then, suddenly, the area begins to change, and now you're fighting skulls and ghosts. Beware Child! There's bony people skeletons everywhere! Scary, right?

The upgrades are rather varied, and you will find a playstyle that suits you- for me, it was to just to go a full gem build, collect as many gems as possible and buy my way to the end. Luckily, there's an upgrade that makes it so shops appear at the start of every area, making this a valid strategy.

As you continue on, dying and dying again, you'll begin unlocking new colours and characters, and soon you'll unlock a character that will easily trump every other one. For me, it's 'boulder style', which gives you +2 max health but lowers your upgrade choice by 1. As you always got 3 upgrades to choose from, reducing it to 2 helped a lot in giving me less choice, which ironically made choice easier.

There's always a flaw, though; for me, it's the fact the final boss feels... easy. at least, on Normal Mode. On Hard Mode, You'll NEVER get to him to find out. I literally beat him 5 minutes ago, and it took me 5 minutes to beat him. I also found that getting to the final boss was easier than the area before it. Maybe that was the design choice? Who knows. To be a fly on the wall at Devolver Digital.

Now, as is life, my opinion may not sway you. I really don't mind- it's your choice! However, for it's current price, I got my fun out of it within the first hour, so if a nice time waster is something you're looking for, I heartily recommend it. The achievements are balanced and possible, the colour palettes are fun to try and unlock, and the characters are willing to do anything they can to get you to use them. Overall, it's another awesome game from an awesome company!

(Just don't get the mobile version. It kinda sucks.)

TL;DR - Simple, addictive, challenging and well-designed retro-style platformer.

Jump and shoot your gunboots with one button, fall down the well, stomp creatures and collect gems to upgrade your weapon as you fall through.
 
If you do 'git gud,' and charge through all 12 levels and boss, a successful run is about a half hour, so it's very easy to pick up and play (die) a few times, though it's just as easy to keep trying for a surprisingly long amount of time. (Those palettes don't unlock themselves.) 

Sounds and graphics are simple and effective, there's an authentically retro sense of 'what am I looking at' when the chaos runs high and you've got to trust your instincts  to get out of a jam. 

Would not dare give anything away, just that by the time you get to the end of the well, your motivations become much clearer. 

Really very good. Get the laser.

37159099.review:
This game has some surprising depth to it (no pun intended); as you play it more, you start to realize that EVERYTHING has multiple purposes. The complexity in this game is found in the mechanics; you have to strategize and find your playstyle because every option has benefits and drawbacks (I mean, you can even choose from 4 different playstyles before the start of every run, and each one is useful in their own ways). Do you want to keep your combo going to get greater prizes, or do you want to keep stopping early to maximize monetary gaines? Do you want to change your weapon just to get extra health, or is it not worth changing your gun? The game is inititally fun because of the gimmick of going down instead of left to right, but then the game becomes even greater once you understand all the all the little decisions that can fit in the span of split seconds or impact the rest of your run.
Besides the clever execution, the game is just hard; plain and simple. It's like a weird combination of a platformer and a bullethell; it requires fast decision-making skills and reflexes, and the hard mode you unlock after defeating the boss totally changes the game. I definitely recommend this game (though prepare to rage sometimes; it'll happen).

37138695.review:
Downwell is a roguelike, fast-paced plattformer with retro graphics.

You jump down a well and shoot or stomp enemies, which are dropping red crystals when they are killed. The crystals are needed for buying stuff at the shop and maintaining the weapons boost status. The weapons boost is needed to kill the enemies more quickly.

In each level you have the chance to strengthen you character with multiple weapons upgrades. After each level you have the chance to choose between some (mostly) passive upgrades. Like most roguelikes, if you die, you have to start all over again.

There are also different play styles (e.g. More life from the beginning) and color palettes to unlock permanently.

Positives:
+ Entertaining, fast-paced, satisfying and addictive gameplay
+ Different weapons/passive upgrades
+ It's difficult enough but not really frustrating
+ Funny enough to come back and give it another try

Neutral:
o Retro graphics and sound with Gameboy feeling
o Watch the trailer. That's exactly what you get.

Negatives:
nothing

37012941.review:
Downwell is a fantastically frenetic action-platformer with snappy controls, wonderful 2-bit pixel art, and a bizarrely fascinating world.

Combat is quick and satisfying, and the game bundles health and ammo boosts with weapon types to encourage you to try new weapons.

The game's characters and setting are weird as heck, and I love them for that- every new area is a joy to experience for the first time.

Getting to the bottom of the well is a mysterious challenge like nothing I've ever seen; there are no checkpoints, so to beat the game you have to go through every single level without dying once. That level of near-impossible-challenge intrigue is something a lot of roguelikes pass up in favor of "rogue-lite" mechanics, so you don't see it all too often, and it works perfectly here.

It isn't without its flaws- most of the unlockables you get through multiple runs are simple palette swaps, and there are plenty of times when not getting hit is almost impossible- but the good far outweighs the bad.

Heck, I haven't even beaten it yet, but that doesn't matter: I love this game, and, if you're an action gamer with a penchant for pixel art and tough-but-fair challenges, you will too.

36681065.review:
Recommendation: It's less that $5, what are you waiting for? Buy it.

I don't like platformers, rogue-likes/lites, schmups or procedural generation, but I love this game and seems to do it really well.

First and foremost, while the game is challenging, it is easy to jump into. This is a game I wish was on the Switch so that I can play it wherever I go. The gameplay is simple and easy to learn but hard to master. The furthest I've gotten is level 2-3 and I've died a whole lot but I still want to play more. Unlike most other games in this genre, I don't hate redoing the levels because the journey back is just so exhilarating. It embodies the term "replayability" in its purest form -- not for some arbitrary extra content or for completion's sake, but for the sheer amount of fun you can have while playing. 

There's something about the verticality of the levels and the ability to just dash through to the next level at breakneck speed without knowing what awaits you that makes the experience very satisfying. You don't have to kill any of the enemies if you don't want to, you'd only kill them for gems that you use to buy upgrades should you choose to. A very simple, cheap and highly entertaining game with a ton of replayability.

I have not experienced any of the technical issues that other people have reported. The only negative I can think of, and this is really a nitpick more than anything, is that at later levels when there are a ton of enemies swarming around you, it is difficult to tell which pixel are you or where you are. This is mostly due to the very simplistic color palettes that both your avatar and enemies use. It would have been better to use a different color scheme for the avatar to make him stand out.

EDIT: I have just played the mobile version of Android and while the game itself is still great, simulated controller schemes don't feel as good as a physical controller. But that is just my personal preference. You do you.

36636514.review:
After ~2 houes into this game (at the time of writing), but only getting to level [b]2-1[/b] maximum, I can say the difficulty is refreshing. I have had my fair share of hard games, but this game is decently difficult. Starting out with 4 health, dying and losing all of your progress is easy. Later in the game you can receive upgrades and "Styles" that can increase your health and affect specific variables in the game, as to increase your ability to survive and get to later stages in the game. The upgrades and styles are very neat ways of adding challenges and ways to make the game easier. There is also a "Platette" that allows you to change the base color and theme of the game, allowing for multiple visual styles in exchange for the original one. The randomized levels offer a neat variety of experiences, and up the replay value a lot. The game is fantastic at allowing you to just "Jump In" and play, as you can spend a few days without playing and then jump back in without the dangers of starting off in a tough position.  I haven't encountered any bugs/glitches and the game looks and feels very polished. I got the game on a sale, so I only spent 1.01$, but with what the content is and the inital price of 2.99$, I feel like I took something from the devs. The difficuly can occasionally be frustrating because it can feel like you arn't getting anywere, but it isn't that big of a deal. 

tl;dr in list form

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
  [*] Difficulty
  [*] Randomized Upgrades 
  [*] Platette options
  [*] Randomized Levels
  [*] Visuals
  [*] Ability to jump back into playing
  [*] The Price 
[/list]

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[list]
  [*]The Difficulty can get annoying at times.
  [*]The bats.

36476542.review:
Au début j'étais assez réticent à acheter Downwell, ses graphismes m'inspiraient plus un jeu fait à la rache pour récolter quelques euros rapidement. Mais après avoir vu l'épisode de Game Next Door qui lui est dédié et vu son prix j'ai décidé de l'acheter.

Ce jeu est une de mes meilleures découvertes de cette année et de loin.

Downwell est un rogue-like (ou rogue-lite pour les puristes) ultra adictif, où vous descendez dans un puit rempli d'ennemis qui changent en fonction des différents niveaux. Son gameplay est génial et super bien pensé, ses graphismes (certes minimalistes) et sa bande son créent une ambiance sombre et creepy, les items ont une réelle utilité, il y a plusieurs persos (bon en fait c'est juste le même perso mais qui va agir différemment, exemple : le style pierre vous donne plus d'hp mais vous aurez moins de choix pour l'upgrade en fin de niveau) et il y a même des thèmes visuels qui s'unlock au fur et à mesure que vous avancez dans le jeu. Et c'est personnellement la première fois qu'un rogue-like/rogue-lite me fait jouer autant de temps d'affilé. Mais parce qu'il faut toujours un point négatif, sur certains PC sous windows 10 il y a un bug qui rend le jeu injouable en full screen, pour régler le problème il suffit de mettre le .exe du jeu en mode de compatibilité windows 8 et c'est bon.

Enfin bref, pour le prix d'un café trop cher ou d'un skin cs par dégueu vous pouvez obtenir une petite pépite du jeu vidéo, à noter que le jeu est aussi disponible sous android.

36352188.review:
Mein Fazit des Spiels gibt's unten, falls einem der ausführliche Text hier zu lang sein sollte, und man grob die Stärken und Schwächen des Spiels aufgelistet haben möchte.

[h1]Handlung[/h1]
Zum Inhalt der Handlung kann ich nichts sagen, was nicht auch schon auf der Steamshopseite steht. Man spielt eine junge Person, die aus Neugier in einen Brunnen im Park hinabsteigt. Und im Gegensatz zum Brunnen ist die Handlung auch nicht viel tiefer. Aber das macht nichts. [i]Downwell[/i] ist eindeutig angelehnt an eine Ära, in der Videospiele noch keine hochwertigen Geschichten erzählt haben, sondern man ohne Umschweife mit dem Spielen losgelegt hat.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Mit schweren Kanonen an den Stiefeln ballert man sich seinen weg hinab durch den Brunnen, der eigentlich viel zu tief und breit für einen normalen Brunnen ist. Hin und wieder gibt es einen Nebenraum hinter einer Zeitanomalie. Betritt man diese Anomalien, bleibt die Zeit außerhalb stehen, sodass man diese als sichere Zonen nutzen kann. In diesen Nebenräumen findet man entweder Edelsteine oder neue Waffen, die auch gleichzeitig die Gesundheit oder Energie verbessern.
Manchmal trifft man auch auf einen Händler, dem das Wort "Standortfaktor" anscheinend völlig unbekannt ist, und der absolute Wucherpreise für seine Reisbällchen verlangt.

Am Ende eines jeden Levels kann man sich noch aus einer zufälligen Auswahl ein permanentes Upgrade für diesen Durchlauf aussuchen.

Hat man das Spiel ein paar Male gespielt, schaltet man zusätzliche Spielstile frei, die die Sprites der Spielfigur beeinflussen, sowie andere Parameter des Spiels, wie zum Beisiel die Preise beim Händler oder die Anzahl der Upgrademöglichkeiten.

Der Schwierigkeitsgrad ist angenehm schwer. Man wird so einige Versuche brauchen, bis man am Grund des Brunnen angekommen ist. Allerdings wird man hier nie frustriert, denn dazu macht es einfach zu viel Spaß. Es gibt auch keine unfairen Stellen im Spiel, an denen man einfach nicht vorbeikommt und jedes Mal von vorne anfangen muss, bis man den Dreh 'raus hat. Bei [i]Downwell[/i] denkt man sich nur: "Nächstes Mal schaffe ich es noch ein Stück weiter!"

[h1]Atmosphäre[/h1]
Das Ganze präsentiert sich in einer höchst charmanten 2bit-Grafik, die nicht nur an vergangene Zeiten erinnert, sondern auch noch funktional ist: Jede der vier Farben hat im Spiel eine Funktion, und anhand der Farben kann man erkennen, ob man auf einen Gegner draufspringen kann oder dabei Schaden erleidet, ob man auf einem Terrain sicher landen kann oder es gefährlich ist. Der grafische Stil hat mich auch stark an das (sehr empfehlenswerte) Flashgame [url=https://www.newgrounds.com/portal/view/493990][i]Down the Well[/i][/url] auf Newgrounds erinnert - was irgendwie auch sehr naheliegend klingt...
Während des Spiels schaltet man für gesammelte Edelsteine neue Farbpaletten frei, die die vier Farben verändern. Nur eine eigene Farbpalette kann man leider nicht zusammenstellen.

Passend zum Stil des Spiels gibt's was auf die Ohren von einem herrlichen Chiptunesoundtrack, der das Retrogefühl des Spiels nochmal doppelt unterstreicht. Jedes Musikstück ist einzigartig und lässt sich eindeutig einem Spielabschnitt zuordnen.

[h1][u]Fazit / TL;DR[/u][/h1]
[i]Downwell[/i] überzeugt mit seiner simplen aber spaßigen Spielmechanik und seiner charmanten Präsentation. Der relativ hohe, aber niemals unfaire Schwierigkeitsgrad machen Lust auf mehr und spornen den Spieler dazu an, es immer wieder zu versuchen. Das alles in Kombination mit dem sehr niedrigen Preis machen [i]Downwell[/i] zu einem kleinen Goldstück.

Pros: The gameplay is very addicting, and purely based on skill, yet very simplistic. The variety of weapons to choose (and shoot) from are both fun and challenging to master. For me, this definitely helps the game from not getting repetitive too quickly. The free upgrades you can choose at the end of every level also helps with this.

Cons: However, the game does suffer from poor optimization, causing black screens upon launch. And still occurs even after re-installing twice. There's also frame-lag which makes the game look a little more floaty than usual, even when running on a decent gaming laptop with 8gb of RAM. I do hope the developers release an update and fix these issues.

All-in-all I'd say it's a very fun and very challenging game with a nice, crisp 8-bit look. If you like arcade-styled, rouge-like games, you better buy this. Just hope that your PC is optimized to handle this game fully.
And it's only $3, I mean, who can argue with that?

[h1] Downwell Review [/h1]

[h1] Art Style [/h1]
The art style is what I love the most about this game!
It's has a simple 8-bit art style with heavy color contrast to allow you to easily spot what you are supposed to shoot. This means that snap decisions have to be made and you will have stay on your toes!

[h1] Weapons [/h1]
From lasers to 3 round bursts, it has a wide variety of weapons to choose from. Each weapon feel refreshingly different from one another, but still similar enough where you still feel comfortable using them.

[h1] Controls [/h1]
I feel that the controls are very responsive and well refined. 

[h1] Replayability [/h1]
Can be played from morning to night, you will not feel any repetition due to it's randomly generated levels. When you reach the end, you will receive a random upgrade. This means that

[h1] Overall Impression [/h1]
Extremely satisfying to play! I'd give it a solid 9/10
Thank you Moppin and Devolver Digital for this wonderful game, and for making a mobile port as well!

Edit: If you were wondering why I only have 2.7 of playtime, I have moved on from playing Downwell on my PC to playing it on my mobile phone :)

35656884.review:
Piccolo gioiello poco considerato anche se di una casa di sviluppo enorme!

Downwell non è altro che un giochino a scorrimento verticale con piccole caratteristiche roguelike, possiamo quindi considerarlo un roguelite a parer mio.

Il gioco ha un concept semplice, arrivare in fondo al "pozzo". Per farlo dovremo cadere giù, lungo questo buco quasi infinito armati di stivali-sparaproiettili per farci strada tra le creature che lo popolano. Troveremo nemici di vario genere, sconfiggibili in vari modi, che alla loro morte lasceranno "gemme", il credito delle partite per comprare vita/vita massima/cariche nei negozi sparsi per la mappa. Troveremo anche piccole caverne che contengono delle armi o delle gemme. Ci sono moltissime armi, dal fucile laser alla mitraglietta.
Alla fine di ogni stage potremo scegliere un power-up, anche questi numerosi e molto utili.
Alla nostra morte/completamento della partita il nostro punteggio del gioco aumenterà e ogni livello ci darà una palette di colori per il gioco/uno "stile" del personaggio. CI sono pochi stili che fanno cambiare alcune statistiche base del personaggio.

Questa era una breve descrizione oggettiva del gioco. Parlando per me trovo questo gioco molto impegnativo, vedi gli achievement, molto divertente e un buon modo per perdere quei 10 minuti ma non fraintendetemi non è un giochino casual da giocare appunto quando capita, ma è un validissimo titolo!

Qualche votazione nei vari comparti del gioco:

Grafico: 8-bit molto colorato e carino. 8
Musicale: Molto carino anche se preferisco tenerlo spento per ascoltare la mia musica. 6
Giocabilità: Virtualmente infinita, anche se dopo qualche partita puoi stancarti di rifare tutto da capo. 8
Gameplay: Molto bello, ben pensato e strutturato. 9

35560485.review: A really clever game, fusing concepts from platformers, shmups, and roguelikes in a way that feels natural and sui generis. It's hard to believe Downwell isn't the latest entry in some long-established genre. Recommended only for people who love fast-paced action games, as this one demands intense focus and excellent physical execution. That's the core of the game, actually - gravity is always pulling you just a little too hard as you fall down a procedurally generated shaft, zooming through deadly hazards faster than the speed of thought. To control your descent, you have gun boots with limited ammo that stall your momentum, and whose bullets have complex and varied effects on the various structures and monsters populating the shaft. There's a combo/chain system, and randomized items, but the core action is reading the level design as fast as possible, and knowing exactly when it's too much and you need to back off for a millisecond. Totally compelling.

不愧是白金难度为噩梦的游戏，但是整体游戏节奏不错，玩起来还是很爽快的

普通难度通关建议（其实没什么实际意义，多打几次熟悉一下就没问题了）
下落时不踩踏地面并连续击破敌人会出现combo，combo在落到地面后会终止，被敌人攻击到不会中断
combo连击到达一定数目后会有额外奖励
9连击（忘记多少了，反正比较容易）combo额外获得100宝石
15连击（这个也记不太清了，大概是这个数）追加一枚弹夹
25连击追加1HP回复，到boss前可以在第四大关刷一下，提升一下hp上限比较容易打boss
武器当然是用激光最简单
style个人习惯用第二个只有武器升级的
升级如果有的话优先Stomping（踩踏敌人会向下放出冲击波）
还有Gem power（获得宝石后会向上方发射子弹）
以及Knife&Fork（吃掉一定数量的敌人尸体可以回血），具体可以吃的有第1大关的蝙蝠、青蛙、乌龟、小虫子、大蜗牛；第二大关的幽灵、骷髅投手、大骷髅、蝙蝠、第三大关的乌龟、章鱼
第4大关的敌人不会有尸体掉落，前几关一定多吃点，尽量把hp上限升上去然后到第4大关攒combo加血
剩下的升级看着顺眼就点吧，记得看自己的状态来选，相性不好的就不要升了（比如点了吃尸体回血又点了击中敌人尸体诱发爆炸、武器是散弹或激光之类的基本没有弹壳的却选了弹壳也能对敌人造成伤害）
每关开头会出现商店并获得10%折扣的看到了也可以升一下，补给还是挺重要的

34644130.review:
Downwell is proof that a solid concept is the most essential element in game design. The one-line concept for both Downwell is exceedingly simple:

You're falling down a well and your only weapon is guns attached to your feet.

Downwell nails what a lot of retro games miss: that the concept should be interesting enough to carry the whole game by itself. Convoluted systems and mechanics aren't necessary. The game is so fabulously simple I can explain all the mechanics you really need to know to somebody who knows nothing about video games at all right here in the review. Use the arrow keys to move left and right. Jump with spacebar. Spacebar in midair shoots your foot-guns. Colored stuff is interactable. There you go, the game is well designed enough that everything else can be trial-and-errored or even intuited the first time you encounter it in-game, and to me, that intuitivity is one of the lost arts of game design.

Apart from that, Downwell is very challenging. It's demands some unreal reflexes out of the player and if your reflexes are pretty blunt that might be a turn-off. Art and music are both good. If I had to pick some cons out of this game, it'd be technical stuff, such as BGM and SFX volume not having separate sliders, windowed mode not being resizable, and fullscreen alt-tabbing being pretty awful considering how light the game is. Overall, highly recommend, especially for the price.

34543495.review:
TL;DR

Downwell is a vertical, bullet-hell rougelike with quite a bit of difficulty to it. You play as a kid with gunboots, falling and shooting down a massive well past lots of different monsters. Ghosts, floating eyeballs, turtles, things like that. The game's controls are very solid, and movement is a lot more fluid than it looks. You can bounce off of walls, smash ontop of enemies to chain combos, or just land on a ledge before moving on. And certain 'styles' allow for different runs, such as the Spinning Arm, which allows you to only find gun types (a good thing), but shops are much more rare.

And the soundtrack is pretty great, too. Downwell's soundtrack reminded me of Hotline Miami's, (Another Devolver Digital title, may I add.) in how fresh it felt. The songs were perfect for each respective stage, and they really help make the game special.

Downwell is just a really great game overall, and took me about 15 hours to 100%. I'd recommend it for sure; and I mean, the price really makes this game a steal for what you're getting.

33951364.review:
Downwell is inspiring to say the least. If this game was released on the NES, the creator Ojiro Fumoto would have been a millionaire and it would have been a killer app. Rumor has it, that this is his first game... wow! 

As for the game itself, it is fun to play for a few minutes here and there. Its a great 15 minute work break game. Its very simple yet very challenging.  The game is very short but very intense. Imagine a tiny roller coaster that still gets you dizzy. The game is pure acton so if you are looking for a calm relaxed RPG, look elsewhere. 

This game is for oldschool game purists. For those who love having no save points and brutal perma death. It has random elements so I consider it a rogue-like game. Imagine blending the original NES Metroid, Contra and Mario into one game. You will be going down a well, bouncing on he heads of enemies and shooting bullets like a madman whilst looking for upgrades to your gun.

This game is an homage to the age of video games when graphics meant little and gameplay meant everything. Well done! I look forward to a sequel...

33471738.review:
Downwell is a tricky game.  It will trick you in to thinking it's easier than it is up front by throwing you in to the game with little explanation, but utilizing simple controls and mechanics so you quickly get the hang of what's going on.  Yet as you descend, you'll find quickly that there's a very difficult game not too far down that well.  

Downwell is, at its core, a shoot 'em up.  Sure it has plenty of platforming action and doesn't constantly have you moving, but the driving force is blasting away at screens of enemies with a variety of weapon pickups as you drop ever downward.  It also has some roguelite elements, such as dying forcing you to restart, and each run potentially unlocking either cosmetic “palettes” that change the colors of the game, or new game modes called “styles” that affect the character and levels.  You won't necessarily be taking anything from run to run except your understanding of the game and practice, but changing to the different styles may fit the way you play better and make a run more successful for you. For instance, the first style unlocked, Arm Spin Style, will make it so the player always finds new weapons in the side rooms that spawn, but shops won't spawn as often.  Most styles work  in this way by having both a positive and negative element.

The game does get much more difficult as you proceed.  You will end up doing quite a few runs before you even encounter the boss, and even then there's a good chance you'll get your ass kicked like I did when you finally see it.  The nature of Downwell and it's short sessions means that it is a game that's very friendly for popping in and out of without much commitment or overall time investment.  It's not necessarily that long of a game, but the challenge coerces you into investing more time than you'd imagine given the fairly minimal number of levels.  It also has a hard mode so if you are someone unlike myself and actually good at these sorts of games, you can find a new challenge after completing it.  

The only thing that would be more difficult than Downwell, is not recommending it.  That's why I'm going to take the easy route and say, for the already ridiculously low base price, it's well worth having and trying out.  You get a well crafted and enjoyable game that has great value and as fair amount of replayability.  That's pretty much all I look for in an indie title to convince me to pick it up.

If you'd like to see more of my reviews, check out my curator page here: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/EndyoGaming#curation

33430170.review:
Finito poco fa.
Vediamo insieme perchè acquistarlo e perchè no.

COMPRALO PERCHE:
-Graficamente è un titolo Retro ideale per girare su qualsivoglia dispositivo senza problemi tecnici di sorta, se riscontrate problematiche nel FullScreen in Windows 10 vi consiglio di abilitare l'opzione Beta del gioco e tutto.
Il gioco ha uno stile, che seppur risulta avere un palese effetto dejavu in titoli del passato fa il suo sporco lavoro aiutato da effetti di luce sulle armi davvero graziosi. Un comparto non per tutti ma che sicuramente risulta esser sufficiente
-Main OST e Tracklist ad 8-BIT molto orecchiabili e mai troppo invasive ad invogliare la frustrazione nel giocatore ed anzi, invogliandolo in qualche modo, a continuare la giocata per sentire le varie variazioni di ritmo che si presenteranno nel corso dei vari livelli
-Ludicamente parlando il titolo si presenta come una sorta di platform atipico, condito da shooting e quella vena Roguelike che può piacere o meno (infatti ad ogni morte il gioco vi riporta all'inizio). Il gioco è tutto in discesa (come già il titolo può far intuire) e la nostra avventura è condita di potenziamenti per facilitare la nostra discesa. Il livello di difficoltà è sicuramente alto e la discesa sarà letteralmente piena di Santi da sparare. Un gameplay semplice, fatto di frecce direzionali e di un solo tasto per il salto/fuoco quindi ideale per grandi e piccini.
-La longevità varia da persona a persona a seconda delle vostre abilità, gli sbloccabili o l'Hard Mode (ve ne era la necessità?) non sono incentivi tali per un eventuale rigiocata una volta finito (come lo può essere l'attacco al punteggio invece). In definitiva un paramentro molto variabile ma che sicuramente saprà dare delle soddisfazioni


LASCIALO A STEAM PERCHE:
-Se state cercando un titolo pieno di significato o di Storia state totalmente sbagliando genere perchè non ne ha assolutamente...Spoiler sul Finale, non salvate neanche una principessa ma un semplice gattino quindi, no sangue amaro.
-Se non preso alla leggera il gioco risulta sicuramente frustrante

Avendolo snocciolato in toto posso dire che è un gioco che vale davvero la pena almeno provare (e nel caso chiedere refund, visto anche l'esigua cifra richiesta per acquistarlo). Adatto letteralmente a chiunque ed ideale per farsi quella partita di 15min tra un pausa all'altra di giochi ben più difficili o semplicemente quando si è al PC per fare altro e non giocare.

VOTO
70/100
Oggettivamente per quanto bello e riuscito non può prendere più di questo score.

33425605.review:
Clean, simple fun.

Downwell is a novel take on verticle shooters. You control a man plummeting down a well, armed with nothing but his gunboots. Bounce on enemy heads on your way down, and keep yourself aloft with the kickback from your kicks to rack up a huge multiplier. You'll find multiple gun types, health and ammo upgrades, and even shops to help outfit you as you move through several unique levels. As you play, you'll unlock new tri-chromatic color-schemes and new "fall styles" that tweak the mechanics a bit when you need a change of pace.

I'm honestly impressed by the character and personality that Moppin has squeezed out of three colors, a tight playing area, and simple controls. The soundtrack (and soud effects) are top-notch. I keep finding myself coming back for more of this one.

33414164.review:
Tengo una relación de amor-odio para con este género. Me encantan, los adoro y me lo paso genial jugándolos. Por otro lado, soy incapaz de pasarme cualquiera de ellos. De hecho, creo que no me he pasado ningún roguelike de cuantos he jugado. Y sí, incluyo a Downwell. ¿Que qué hago analizando un juego que no me he pasado? Bueno, bueno. Le he tirado unas cuantas horas. Creo que las suficientes para sacar mis conclusiones.

Algo muy positivo que saco de estos juegos es el jugar por simple y pura diversión. Me recuerda a mi infancia, cuando me iba a la recreativa a dejarme las monedas de 5 duros. Juegos como este Downwell, The Binding of Isaac o Enter the Gungeon proporcionan horas de diversión sin preocuparte en el por qué, ni pararte a pensar en el quién ni en el cuándo. Aquí no hay más pretensión que el jugar. Son el equivalente actual a los juegos arcade de los que podíamos disfrutar hace ya unos cuantos (bastantes) años. Es más, al igual que por aquel entonces, si mueres pagas. En su momento con otra moneda más; ahora con tiempo, teniendo que empezar de cero cada vez. Si sumamos cosas como rankings y el compartir (vía stream, youtube y demás) tus partidas, tenemos un ambiente similar al de estos salones recreativos.

Personalmente, y al igual que me pasaba con las recreativas, mis partidas suelen ser cortas. Ni disponía de mucho capital para tirar a la máquina, ni ahora quiero sobrepasar la línea entre diversión y estrés porque se me resista algún nivel o enemigo. Como he dicho, aquí prima el placer de jugar sin más.

33089815.review:
■ここが良い！
・敵を踏むマリオ的な要素と、ガンブーツ射撃のシューティング的な感覚が組み合わさり、唯一無二のプレイ感覚を作れている。
・「覚える」という要素を強く意識していること。最初は難しすぎると感じるステージでも、ある程度癖を掴んで何が有効かわかれば、サクサク進むことができて成長を感じられる。それはアクションゲームとして良く出来ているということだ。
・主人公がなぜ井戸に潜っているかもちゃんとわかり、かつ微笑ませてくれる気の利いたエンディング。

■ここが駄目！
・ランダム性が活きていない。
　ダメージを受けるほど不利になり、リカバリーも難しいため、ミスが続くとゲームオーバーになる前にギブアップして良展開になるまでやり直しがち。
「あるものでいかにやりくりするか」というローグライク的な感覚は薄く、単にランダム性が運ゲー感を加速させるだけになっている。これなら、配置が固定のルートを複数用意してくれるほうが良かった。
・BURSTだけは最後まで有効な使い方がわからず邪魔としか思えなかった。弾数上限上げるためにウェポンを毎回取りたいのに、その中にこういうハズレウェポンがあるのは勘弁願いたい。

■総評
アクションゲームとしては一流、ローグライク要素のあるゲームとしては三流。癖のある良作と言ったところか。
しかし、この唯一無二なプレイ感覚を作ったことだけで誉めれる。次は同じシステムでランダム性のない真っ当なアクションゲームを作ってもらいたい。

32603092.review:
One of the most quality action shooters I've ever played, Downwell has you somersaulting and gunning downward against a variety of ghouls, blobs, bats, and gremlins. Chaining together combos is insanely satisfying, as are the different gun powerups and end-of-level upgrades, and the general gameplay is rock-solid. Lots of games try to be "arcadey", but Downwell hits it dead on.

Each of the four randomly-generated areas bring a different twist to the formula, such as the aquifer levels, where you're required to keep your air up, or the purgatory levels, where there's rarely a place to land. This one's not very long, with a full game potentially lasting less than 20 minutes, but the difficulty more than makes up for it. Very much a game you pick up, play, put down, and come back to often.

I do think the game could've used some polish; the one button controls mean you occasionally have to bump into an enemy above you to go down, and many a cheap death occurred because the bats and squids are unfairly difficult to land on. The wall jump mechanic also plays against the player most of the time. These are relatively minor gripes compared to the price and the amount of enjoyment I got from it, though; otherwise, absolutely spot on. Required playing. (As an aside, excellent controller game. Supports XInput joypads, such as the 360 one, and you'll want it for this.)

32584531.review:
The bats in the first area will have you staring daggers at the screen. The bone-throwing skeletons in the second area will cause you to grit your teeth so much your dentist will be rollin' in a new set of wheels by the end of the week. Having to resupply yourself with oxygen using bubbles in the third area will trigger PTSD in Sonic veterans. As for the fourth area? Well, that's quite a blast, actually, as is the rest of the game. Extremely simple (and solid) mechanically, but oh-so deep as your keep playing, Downwell is a true joy to play.

If you're a newcomer in need of some tips: learn to combo and ALWAYS focus on upgrading your health (whether through post-level upgrades, cave finds, or purchasing HP/upgrades from the shop).

Oh, and the Puncher is a piece of crap. Don't even give it the time of day.

Das Spiel ist an sich eigentlich super, doch nach fünf Stunden Spielzeit meinte es einfach im Vollbild überhaupt nichts anzuzeigen.
Dies verärgerte mich doch sehr, da es an sich, wie schon vorher gesagt, mir viel Spaß bereitete. 
Man kann das Spiel zwar auch in einem stark komprimierten Modus anzeigen lassen, doch siehtmann dann nicht, wie viele Leben und Gems (die Währung) man hat.
Außerdem ist das Bild dann so groß, wie der Bildschirm eines kleinen Smartphones. Da ich hierzu schon in mehreren Foren gehört habe und dies dort schon seit einiger Zeit bekannt ist (eigentlich seit Release), bin ich nicht sehr zuversichtlich, dass die Entwickler dies jemals beheben werden. Schade.

Edit: Durch das Starten des Spiels im "Beta-Modus", funktinierte wieder alles und es sind keine weiteren Probleme aufgetreten. Das Spiel macgt zwar Spaß, ist fordernd und gibt einem dieses "verdammt nur noch eine Runde" Gefühle, aber das mit dem Bildschirm hinterlässt einem einen schlechten Beigeschmack.
Für Fans von Rogue-likes und Spielen die man nicht so einfach los lassen kann, kann ich das Spiel allerdings noch empfehlen, auch wenn die ganze Sache mir die Lust am Spiel verdorben hat.

- interesting dungeon progression  
- great gameplay and gameplay feel  
- original shooter combat mechanics with 8 unique weapons 
- upgrades are interesting, easy to understand, they combine well, and allow interesting and different playstyles
- low price
 
- overall progression: the player can unlock different color pallets and some new game modes, but all of this gets pretty boring pretty quickly being that the same levels are repeated. I would find it a lot more engaging if the content being unlocked was more meaningful 
- the initial difficulty is too high, the game demands at least an hour of play to get the players interested, but being that the same levels are repeated over and over, new players who are not accustomed to shooters of this type might be turned off
 
With some additional content, it would be perfect, but it still hits really close to this mark.

If you are looking for other interesting shooter games, I would like to invite you to our community group on Steam:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/593680

32136309.review:
-A mixed review of Downwell-

Reflecting on downwell after beating normal mode, I understand why it's really good.  Just watch the YouTube videos that analyze downwell's game design, and you'll find it hard not to appreciate the game. 

However, despite its very high reception and lack of criticism, some things leave me a bit sour. 

Like, there's only 4 levels basically, because (to me at least) the sections for each layer felt exactly the same. For instance level 2-1 looked and felt exactly like level 2-2 and 2-3.  I also just felt the game actually got easier as you progress downward, which is really weird.  Once you can play it fairly well, it's easy to amass lots of ammo and then it becomes so easy to chain and get more life and also avoid taking damage by controlling your descent. The last layer is supposed to be hell-like but it's the easiest level to me by far, because of the lack of enemy variety, the fact that there's no floor (making chaining effortless), and the surplus of upgrades amassed once one has reached this layer.  I don't even get hit once hardly ever in this layer.  Then the final boss just cycles through a very short move rotation, so the pattern is very easy to beat.  

Some weapons also seem kinda pointless to pick up even for a potential upgrade.  The laser is only really useful for the boss.  The other guns were all pretty useful, but they didn't feel too distinguished in my opinion.  The gameplay changes are quite subtle and don't really allow for much variation in play style, which is ok, but more distinct weapons would have I think added more depth.  

I have a similar issue with the shuffling power ups between levels. Some seem like you'd never NOT want to pick them, while others seem mostly useless. They also seem to add to much luck into how much momentum you can generate which makes the game easier or harder.  

My biggest criticism besides the decreasing difficulty though is the lack of modes.  The additional modes here simply add slight spins on the "get through the 4 layers" thing.  For instance, in one mode you'll be more floaty. In another, you'll have slightly more life but less weapon upgrades.  This game really needed certain modes to knock this game out of the park.  An endless mode feels almost odd not to be there, considering the game being somewhat procedurally generated. There also could have been maybe a mode where you climb UP the well instead, and rather than only having 1 wall jump per chain, you can wall jump infinitely and you shoot from a hat instead of your shoes.  Or maybe a mode where you're rushing against some kind of insta-death thing from above, forcing you to worry less of chaining, and worrying more about moving as fast downwards as possible. For a game that does so much with so little, it could have also gotten exponentially more mileage out of additional game modes that shake up how the mechanics are used. 

The game is really well designed, fun, and feels great, but I found the execution a bit disappointing so I'm a little surprised how little criticism there is.  I'm excited to get through hard mode now, but not sure how much more I can get out of this game. Overall, I would give this game a mixed review if I could, but at 3$, I do think it is worth buying and playing, especially considering how many people love it.

32079474.review:
ガンブーツと呼ばれる靴型の武器を装備して
果てしなく深い井戸の中を降りていく
国産インディーによるレトロ風アクションゲーム。
とにかく下に降りるのが目的です。


[h1]・主なアクション性[/h1]
・真下に弾丸を放つ(浮遊効果有り)
・武器のアップグレード
・戦闘スタイルの変更
・踏みつけ
・ジャンプ
・壁キック

[h1]・ジェム[/h1]
Downwellの通貨の様なもので
集めて買い物が出来ます。

他にもジェムを100個取ると
攻撃力と武器の射程が一時的に伸びるなどの
ボーナスもあります。

[h1]・アップグレード[/h1]
ステージをクリアするごとに
パッシブスキルを習得する事が出来ます。
覚えられる能力はプレイをするたび変わります。

[h1]・コンボ[/h1]
地面に着地せずに敵を続けて倒すと
コンボが発生して数々のボーナスが手に入ります。

[h1]・難易度[/h1]
残機などはなく、ライフが0になったらGameOverです。
途中で回復できる要素もありますが、
難易度は高めの作品です。
基本攻撃が真下にしか出来ないという事もあって
上や横の攻撃に対応する立ち回りが求められます。


[h1]・プレイ中に個人的に抱いた不満点[/h1]
私の環境が原因なのかもしれませんが、
スタイル変更やリトライをするたび
強制フルスクリーンが起きて画面がバグります。
オプションでOFFにしても保存されず、
Alt+Enterを毎回押す事になるので
いまいち快適に遊べません。


[h1]・総評[/h1]
個人的に「質実剛健」という
言葉が似合う作品に感じました。
グラフィックや声やムービーなどに
お金をかけなくてもゲーム性は造られる。
クリエイターらしい作品だと思います。

値段はお手頃ですし、レトロゲーム好きや
アクションゲームに自信のある方は
試してみても良いと思います。

32035259.review:
Decades ago video games were, much like Downwell, simple low colour pixelated affairs that were sometimes played on cabinets about the size of an average fridge freezer. In the early days of games your options about what you could do in a game were vastly more limited by the hardware of the age so developers had to get smart about how to make a game look, sound, and feel good enough to attract the attention of you and your precious currency.

Downwell would have had no difficulty in this regard as it manages to create a fast paced action platform experience both simple and complete. The player descends into a well equipped with their trusty downward firing gunboots which can be used to destroy some enemies and platforms, and to slow your descent as you fall. You acquire gems for destroying your enemies as well as bonuses for stringing together kills without landing on a platform. Some enemies can be stomped on which will refill the gunboots limited charge, allowing you to keep the ability to control your descent while remaining airborne. Strewn to the left and right of the well as you tumble downward are treasure rooms and shops which contain power ups, and will thoughtfully freeze time when approached so that you can keep your current combo without having to skip them. When a level is completed you will be offered a choice of upgrades allowing you to further increase your abilities. Playing through multiple times will unlock different styles that mutate the game in various ways, as well as several colour palettes which can be chosen to suit your tastes.

This game has an excelent arcade feeling, fast paced action with frequent rewards and reinforcement which keeps you engaged constantly as well as an easy to learn, hard to master difficulty curve. The retro styled graphics demonstrate the effectiveness of an extreme limitation of colour if adapted well, both keeping enemies distinct from scenery and indicating enemies weaknesses, a critical game design choice in a fast paced platformer. In truth the inginuity in game design on display in Downwell makes me feel guilty that I got it at a sale price, but even at regular price it'd probably feel like a steal because it keeps you coming back again and again.

曾经我不相信魔法，认为那些都是苟屁，只有我手里的长剑与盾才能打倒我面前的敌人。然而，后来我被一个绿BUFF吸引误打误撞走进了这个世界，我惊呆了，原来这个世界上触摸一下青蛙真的会-1，啊我的上帝，这真不可思议！
后来我发现了问题的严重性，随着接触的青蛙与怪东西越来越多，我的生命变得所剩无几，然而人类的本性驱使着我活下去，不要死！在一次偶然的机会下，我遇到了一个商人，他向我索要了我身上全部的积蓄，没错，就是杀怪掉落的那些宝石。
随后发生的事，我可能永远不会忘记，我那被青蛙消磨殆尽的生命随着+1、+1渐渐变得充盈，我惊讶的看向那个商人，他说续命的宝贝就这么多了，再想获得生命就要靠你自己努力了。
重新获得的生命是我变得兴奋。我迫不及待的走向了寻找+1的道路，用以弥补我那受损的生命，后来我路过了一个山洞，那里有一块血红色的宝石，那浓郁的红色仿佛是鲜血凝固而成，妖艳的不成样子，我好奇的拿起了它，我再次惊呆了，虽然这个世界带给我的惊喜带给我的惊喜已经够多了，但是我想我这回我一定是是找到了+1的法门。
在以后的岁月里，我便走向了寻找+1的道路。如果以后你看到了这些文字，也许你走向了和我相似的道路，相信在以后的岁月里，命运会趋使你与我相遇，我在远处等你，来自远处的旅行者！

31887596.review: DESCRIPTION: An incredibly clever, tight, and addictive arcade roguelike that's worth every penny; Downwell nails the idea that games should be simple to approach, with plenty of depth under the surface. Every single mechanic the game uses has multiple purposes and some sort of risk/reward mechanic, giving it an unexpectedly high skill ceiling for how simple the controls and mechanics are: move left, right, jump, and shoot. Semi-random level generation ensures the game doesn't get stale but also  rarely feels like the levels are generated unfairly. Downwell also features alternate color schemes and playstyles as rewards for playing, as well as a hard mode for anybody who beats the game. $3 USD is a complete steal for this game, not even mentioning how often it goes on sale for 50% off or more. And it's even available for the same price on the iOS App Store and the Google Play Store, where it controls better than any other mobile platformer I've ever seen, in addition to having no ads or microtransations.  Whether you're a fan of roguelikes like Spelunky, you just want an engaging little game to play for five minutes in your free time, or you would love to master a tight combo system to bounce your way through fifteen hectic minutes of lazer blasts and jetpacks, you owe it to yourself to pick up Downwell.

31885588.review:
[h1]Cheap, Fun and Mayhem.[/h1]

This game will make you sit and play for hours as if you were that child that once used to stay up at night covering yourself under your blankies with a gameboy having the time of your life.

 The suspense that this game gives you when falling into a dark abyss where the experience changes everytime you die, you have no idea what to expect. Little bit of humour here and there in the context of upgrades and lots of pixel destruction with all the massacare of the explosions and whatnot coming out from your [b]super cool rocket boots.[/b] [i](who doesn't like that?)[/i]

[i]If you feel voided by not being able to enjoy a game once in a while or just tired of playing multiplayer games and just want to have some fun during the day or night[/i], just open up downwell and fall into utter bliss. The game offers different upgrades completing a stage making the gameplay very different each time you play, added with blaster upgrades for your super cool rocket boots which make the game even more interesting depending on which you pick. Kinda like those plane fighter games but reversed and more fun.

[b]AND DID I MENTION THE ANIMATIONS[/b], the details on the characters like the white highlights that indicate where the monster need to hit and all the crazy shit the monsters do and learning their moves each time you enter a new stage is just fun on it's own. You unlock different playstyles which help you depending on how you play, with more hearts or more blaster upgrades and even being able to unlock different colour schemes which make the game prettier depending on which you like from old school gameboy look to just generic colours like blue and green.

overall for a game that costs this cheap, and not to mention is also [b]ON SALE[/b] which makes it even more cheap thanks to the developer games discount. I must say this game is worth every dollar you throw at it because when there are no more games to play for the day, might as well sit down, relax, and play some [b]motherfucking Downwell[/b] [i]amirite?[/i]

[b]TL;DR: this game is amazing, don't linger on it and just buy the damn thing.[/b]

31707823.review:
Downwell is very simply and well designed. It's really pretty amazing how much the game shows with color, and the way it introduces its enemies and level elements is nearly seamless. You fall, you shoot things, jump off of things. Expand your health and battery, at the end of each level you get a new passive ability, most of which are fairly interesting, a few of which are practically essential for a run. There are also I think seven different weapons that are reasonably well balanced, although Puncher is awful. 

A full run of the game is pretty quick, but unless you're a lot better than me at platformers it'll take you many hours to actually beat the game. About 95% of owners don't get that far anyway. I'm writing this after I just beat the game on normal for the first time, which took about 17 minutes for the run and over 20 hours of failure to get there. I got a lot of joy and frustation out of learning this game, annnnd I'm probably not going to go on to hardmode.

As a final note it'd be good to see a borderless window mode in the options, and seeded maps would probably be nice for people who speedrun. That's all I got.

31702624.review:
Superficially one can look at Downwell and jusst see a cheap game, but while it's cheap Downwell does what it's proposes to do in a primorous way. At the first sight the gameplay is basic and simple, you have a button to jump/shoot from your boots and can move left and right, and while the controls are indeed simple there are more nuances to it, like a wall jump you can do, maintaining a combo to gain it's bonuses once you finish it or choosing the best upgrades to fit the style you choose to play.

In my modest opinion Downwell shines in the small details, like after reaching a new "world" the music only starts after you land on a platform or in an enemy. Using a limited color palette but still makes it easy to distinguish between the enemies you can land on from the ones you need to avoid to not take damage, and the same applies to environment and as you progress through the game you unlock more colors. Other small thing I appreciate in the game is since the time pauses when you enter one of the side rooms the music stops, and you not loses your combo, even though you recharge your boots by landing on them.

I short i highly recommend this game.

Yo le echo un vistazo a sus botas-pistola, pero, ¿se ha planteado usted si tal vez su necesidad sea darse un capricho en cualquiera de los centros comerciales más populares del momento, Unreal Engine o Unity, a ver si encuentra por ahí algo mejor?

31457305.review:
Downwell has simple and tight controls, endless replayability - as you can see from the amount of hours I have played from this game - and self-explanatory gameplay mechanics. 

Basically, Downwell is a game of falling down. Gravity accelerates your fall, so to decelerate your fall, goomba stomp or shoot those pesky flying slimes and squids and other enemies to collect and accumulate gems to buy items from the shop, whether it be charges (to increase ammo count) and health (which is more expensive than charges). That's basically the gist of it, [spoiler] though there are other mechanics like powerups and gun modules, but that would be spoiling the game too much. [/spoiler]

However, the difficulty curve definitely spikes up, which is an unexpected and unprecedented change. Given the simple controls and easily comprehensible mechanics, the difficulty is sensible and never feels like it is purposefully making the player want to point his or her metaphorical gunboots at the head and shoot. 

Once you've beaten the blob of gelatinous and repugnant sewer beast that lives near the pit of the seemingly endless  well, you're welcomed with - guess what? - hardcore mode.

In my experience, a spirited and rigorous affair is always a conduit for self-improvement. When I first played this game, I couldn't get past the first level. Now, I could probably pick up this game again and beat the boss on hard mode again. The reward, the green light at the end of the harbor, or I should say - the light at the end of the well - is always gratifying to the senses, and it might be for you too.

tl;dr I love this game and you should buy it.

31337746.review:
A game I would recommend to literally anyone. The gameplay is solid, level generation is outstanding. There aren't many levels and you don't unlock more during repeat playthroughs, however the ones that are there are unique and offer different playstyles, each level goes on for just long enough not to get bored of it. As for the playstyles, they range from your average platformer to race against time to having to use enemies as your only ground.

This game does require skill. The controls are just 3 buttons - run left, run right, jump and shoot are same button, you can only shoot downwards and only in midair, doing so will propel you upwards a little for extra air control. Using these few options for their full extent requires some practice, don't expect to beat this game quickly.

The roguelike aspect of the game is not affecting the gameplay as much some other games of the genre. There are 20 upgrades for 10 levels while some games have hundreds of items for 5 levels, and the levels while randomly generated are always linear.

On topic of upgrades, there are also multiple weapon types (modules) that while working differently have about the same firepower, therefore which weapon is better is to the player's choice. It's still beneficial to pick up weapons when you  find them because they can grant extra health and extend gunboot battery depending on module appearance.

Now for an important topic - replay value. This is not a game to play the hell out of non-stop. Instead, it's better to return to the game every once a while to truly appreciate it. As I previously stated, there are no extra levels on repeat playthroughs (which is kind of saddening), but there is a hard mode.

In conclusion, I'd rate this game 9/10. It would be fantastic if this game ever recieved extra content such as new levels, or heck I'd love to see a more traditional left to right platformer or even a metroidvania based on this.

31049293.review:
Downwell is a minimalist retro arcade style platformer with an unexpected difficulty curve.

The controls are ridiculously simple, the game mechanics are mostly self explanatory and the gamefeel is on-point. Although the pixel graphics might be tiring as a staple of indie games, the minimal 3-4 color palette is surprisingly functional, and along with well animated sprites, creates an unique atmosphere.

After several replays, it's hard to tell whether the game truly embraces its rougelike aspect. The levels are procedurally generated, you do get randomized upgrades and weapons throughout your playsession, however, near the final stages of the levels, you'll end up with most of the upgrades and similar levels of stats. Perhaps it's better the RNG luck is only a determining factor in the early stages when picking upgrades, but at the same time it makes it seem as if permadeath is a redundant feature here due to the consistency of the outcome.

The only negatives to be pointed out stem from minor technical issues, such as lack of cloud saving, no Linux port (runs fine in Wine) and enemy pop-in on harder difficulty.

Even for its base price, this really is a hidden gem.

Yes I do recommend it. Definitely. What is it like 3 bucks? For the price the experience is worth it. It's pretty simple to understand, has some rogue-lite elements and is just generally fun to play. I have a handful of issues with it, but beyond that I really think that anyone who likes the way it looks should definitely give it a go.

So yeah the game aesthetic is mostly very good. Simple colors and the likes. It all melds well aesthetically, though my biggest gripe is clarity. Enemies who are 'colored' and have 'no white' appear to deal damage to you no matter what. Most of the enemies that you 'don't want to touch' are pretty clear, but I don't fully understand what the 'white and colored' means because for example the toad enemy is white and colored, but if I touch him without falling I get hurt. Meanwhile there is some grub you can just run over? Whether or not it's fully clear at first, you learn though and in the end it's fine. Only a small complaint I feel. Otherwise the aesthetic is great and very well thought up for enemy identification.

Controls work great. Simple and yet so nice. They're very responsive and I haven't a single problem with em. Jump jumps and also shoots when you are jumping and it buys items and stuff when at the vendor. Left and right move...that's it! That's all ya need to know really. The game functions a little differently with 'different styles', but not much.

The meat of the game is what ya see in the vid. You fall and shoot. Fall and shoot. Bounce off enemies who are 'white and colored' (as I said in graphics) when you are falling and you can chain up your bounces. I think the bounce chain thing is quite rewarding and the kickback on weapons feels good creating a pretty nice dynamic to thinking about whether to shoot something outright, shoot to maintain your height or just fall. You also regen ammo by bouncing so yah. I think it's great!

Sound is good. It's not the most amazing stuff I have ever heard, but everything fits well. Shotgun has that 'thump' you'd expect, machine gun sounds good, etc. It's all good and such.

It's worth saying that in terms of the actual LENGTH of the game, it's pretty short. The rogue-lite elements, alternate styles and unlockables extend it a bit, but not by much. I feel it's worth it though. I think that's all there is to really say about the game. Just simple fun. There isn't really a story, but the aesthetic and ambience is really nice. Not sure what else to say to be honest.

3 bucks or less. Worth it definitely. I mean so long as you're into this sort of thing.

Downwell is about as close to a perfect game as you can get. It has an amazing sense of flow; it's simple to grasp, but has endless depth and it has tons of replayability because despite being intuitively simple it's just incredibly polished. 

But what makes this special, I think, is that it's a game that melds traditional "ultra-hard" mechanical inspirations a-la super hexagon or VVVVVV with a gameplay system that really adjusts to the skill of the player and allows for a large variety in gameplay styles. This is not a game that punishes you for not doing exactly what the game tells you to. It does not kill you instantly and respawn you instantly with a souless "try again" until you conform to what it wants you to do. It lets you have adventures. It lets you teach yourself how to play in the most wonderful way. This game is the only game I have ever played where I felt not only the rush of beating something immense, but haven't been frustrated at it. 

THIS GAME IS AMAZING. THIS GAME IS 3 DOLLARS. It's a wonderful experiance. What else could you want?

Recommended.

30092003.review:
[h1] Downwell [/h1]
[i] No snazzy quote for this one, cause there's no dialogue! [/i]

Judgement : [u] Worth Full Price [/u]

Downwell is a simple concept executed flawlessly. It's incredibly rudimentary in its design, but this simplicity and forwardness is what allows it to work so well. It's lean, and everything in it is running multiple functions for the sake of streamlining how the entire game controls. This may sound like a negative, but Downwell was designed with mobile devices in mind, which is one of the reasons that it is presented in a portrait style, and its mobile home is why it has only three buttons. However, this does nothing to detract from how it plays, and as someone who played it on both mobile and PC, I can say for certain that here is where it shines. 

A lot of what I want to say on this game is covered by Mark Brown in a series he makes called Game Maker's Toolkit. His video on Downwell succinctly covers what about the base design allows Downwell to function so well, and I highly recommend watching the video, even if you're not too interested in the game right now.
Link: https://youtu.be/i5C1Uj7jJCg

Now, since he covers a lot of what I would cover at this point, I want to talk from the perspective of someone who got [i] really, really good [/i] at this game. I told myself that I would beat the game completely before I wrote this review, and that meant completing Hard, which I just managed to do.
And by God if Ojiro Fumoto (the developer) didn't make me fucking work for it.
As Mark said, this game demands that you play by its rules. It forces you to play fast and loose, and by the time you've cleared the game on Normal, you've started picking up on the bonuses speed and style confer, with combos providing health and ammo increases.
When you start attempting Hard, you'll realize that those bonuses are not just nice, they're mandatory. This game demands that you think while it's going by at 100m/s. You have to plan how you want to approach each part, and which powerups are likely to result in success. For something that looks and feels so simple, it has real depth to it (pun intended). Getting good at this game becomes a test in pure reaction speed and muscule memory. You start subconciously remembering how everything is supposed to go on a good run, and you'll begin realizing how well the visual feedback keeps the player informed. As speed increases you spend less time trying to recognize enemies, and just begin reacting without thought. When you get going fast, this game almost becomes zen in its playstyle, with you effortlessly bouncing off enemies and blasting others while you descend.

Downwell is a testament to the idea that a simple concept can be wholly engrossing. It didn't need flashy visuals, a budget the size of Montana, or even dialogue. Its arcade like gameplay managed to pull me in with what it has, and it did it for very, very little cash.

At the end of the day, the question is whether Downwell is worth your money or not. 
And it absolutely is.
The fact that it's only $3 just makes this an even easier recommendation, even though I would've recommended it at $10. It's great, it really is, and if you can appreciate a challenge, you'll find plenty available for you here.


[i] Plus, how awesome is it that you have Gunboots? Boots that are Guns? Who wouldn't want that? [/i]

Really, for less than the price of a half-decent sandwich, you'll get one of the best little gems out there. A mechanical masterpiece, and a game I'm likely to still dive into now and then for years to come. It takes little time and little money to give Downwell a shot, and it's worth every penny and second you give it.

30052216.review:
Don't let the small play time on Steam fool you. I've been spending hours on this game through the Android and Vita versions, and those are exactly the same game you get here.

Downwell is a very addicting Roguelike experience. The goal of the game is to go down a well as far as you can without dying. Sounds simple, right? Well, the game is not afraid to show you that it's not messing around, as it can overwhelm you with enemies as early as level 1, and the game only gets harder from there. I myself have never managed to get past world 3 (out of 4 worlds in total, not counting the ending boss fight), even after I managed to accumulate over 150,000 gems over the course of playing the Vita version, and unlocking all of the play styles on both Android and Vita. The game does have a pretty high learning curve, but once you know how everything works, you'll start managing some pretty good runs.

Unlockables are pretty nice. Collecting gems counts to an overall total, and when you die or complete your run, the gems you collected will count towards a progression bar that levels up when you reach a certain milestone. Every time you reach that milestone, you'll unlock either one of 4 additional playstyles that each add a different set of rules for your run, which can increase replayability and experimentation, or one of dozens of pallete swaps that change the color scheme of the game. Rather than all of them be "red turns green" however, the palletes can also consist of screen alterations inspired by game consoles and 8-bit visual styles, or even just be very random screen changes. Just be mindful that some of them may cause the game to be a lot harder because of them being incredibly bright or consisting of a single solid color, making damageable enemies hard to distinguish.

My only real complaint is that the combo system doesn't feel very rewarding, to an extent. How the combos work is that for every kill you get while airborne, it gets added to a combo, with the count showing after you reach 5. When you reach 8 kills, you get 100 gems once the combo ends on landing. Hitting 15 gives you an additional gun charge along with the 100 gems. Hitting 25 gives you a free point of HP along with the previous benefits. The problem I have with this is that this is really it. You don't get any additional rewards by getting bigger and bigger combos, even if you were to hit numbers as high as 600+ (which is possible. Look up videos on Youtube). This does suck up any incentive of getting combos higher than 25 unless you're just going for the acheivements or bragging rights. What would've been nice is that for every 50 kills you get in a combo, or even 100, the rewards you get are added by 1. For example, if you hit 50, you get 200 gems, 2 charges, and 2 hearts, and hitting you 100 gives you 300 gems, 3 charges, 3 hearts, and so on. That would be a nice incentive for racking up higher combos, especially in a game that encourages players to stomp on enemies to stay airborne.

That's really my only negative, and it's more of a nitpick than anything else. The game is still very addicting and fun to play.

29885496.review:
Downwell is  a deceptively simple game. All you do is fall, well... down a well. At its heart, this game is a platformer. You can jump and shoot a limited amount of bullets out of your boots. You can kill enemies with these or by landing on top of them. If you can manage to land from one enemy to the next, you chain combos that award you gems; the more enemies you chain, the larger the bounty. Also sctatered through the levels are shops where you can spend your gems in items that give you a largar life pool or more charge from your boots. 

And that's about it. You go from level to level trying to chain as many enemies as you can and trying to stay alive. Every 3 levels or so you enter a new area with different twists; some have spiky floors, others are underwater, etc... Things get pretty insane past area number 3, I'd say. 

Maintining a rythm and chaining enemies together is satisfying as all hell, but hard to pull off. 

If you want a challenging platformer you can play casually, give this a go, you won't regret it.
