24121317.review:
This is a fast-paced platformer with randomly generated levels and permanent deaths, so that makes it a rogue-like. I'm not very keen of this genre for its high difficulty and frustration but Downwell lets you jump right back into it even when you die, so you keep your flow. And that makes it very addictive. 

It is fast and has a lot of action but manged to generate good pacing. At the end of every stage you can breath through but also in the many upgrade caves where you get some peace and quiet. That way it doesn't become mind-numbing. And the palette-swaps that you can choose from provide some visual variety. The game feel is also very rich and the concept of verticallity feels fresh.

The skill ceiling is very high so it could be impressive to watch a master.

I know a well designed game when I see one and this is absolutely one of them.

Downwell...desarrollado por Devolver Digital,ultraconocida en Steam por diseñar juegos
independientes de calidad,este no es un excepción a pesar de su simpleza al principio.

El juego comieza cerca de un precipicio por el que debemos tirarnos,desde ese momento
iremos descendiendo poco a poco tendremos la ayuda de un arma con ciertos usos y a
medida de que bajemos iremos desbloqueando mas tipos de arma,en cuanto a las cargas
podremos ir aumentandola en las tiendas.

Utiliza una paleta de colores bicronoma,segun subamos de nivel se nos iran añadiendo
nuevas paletas,si la de rojo y negro nos resulta aburrida...a su vez segun desbloquemos
logros se iran desbloqueando nuevos tipos de personaje con sus propios atributos.

Desconozco los niveles que tiene,eso si estan divido por tres secciones y cuando
completemos una sección podremos elegir una mejora para nuestro personaje,
las hay de todo tipos,desde útiles como un dron,hasta un globo bonito que te
preguntaras para que sirve,para nada.

Muchos lo comparan con Doodle Jump pero al contrario,sin embargo,este es un juego
mas primitivo en cuanto a diseño,pero no quiere decir que sea malo...

En fin recomiendo este juego por varios motivos,en primer lugar por su precio asequible,
seguidamente por que entreteniene y por último a mí se me hace divertido...

Saludos b_H89

24069790.review:
[h1] Game [/h1]
Downwell is the famous retro platformer game with perma-death features and some rogue-lite factors that everyone been talking about ever since it was released.

You probably saw so many youtubers playing/talking about this game, as well as they should because it really is such a unique style of a game with a perfect retro feeling.

I don't want to get into too much detail, almost everyone knows about this game its popular enough

[h1]But FPS issues[/h1]
here is what they don't tell you.
You are 80% most likely to have a serious FPS drop issue with the game no matter how good your specs are.
[url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/360740/discussions/search/?q=FPS&gidforum=481115363874629127&include_deleted=1&p=1] SteamDiscussion	[/url]
Click there to reveal the discussion area with a "Fps" filter on it and see how many people are having fps issues.

The game gives fps drops when there are too many enemies and explosion animations on screen, but it goes from 60 to maybe 55 minimum which is all good with me, but if you get hit it goes down to 47 and sometimes lower.
[b]HOWEVER[/b]
Apparently according to the developer the FPS dropping when you're hit is an intended effect to give the old retro "slowdown" effect when you get damaged "I am not still 100% convinced by that response", that still does not excuse the FPS drop when there are too many explosion and enemies on screen.

[b] Note [/b] 
The fps issue happened to me in the following systems.
corei5 4gb ram gt635m laptop 
corei5overclocked, 8gbram r9 290x desktop 
and with my friend's pc having a gtx980

[h1] Dev response [/h1] 
The developer has responded that he/she wont be able to provide any fix whatsoever because he/she is working alone on the mobile port, so it might take a long time to see a fix for this.

As for me luckily I got to play the game for about 2 hours when I didn't have internet connection and now steam has recorded less than 1 hour for me, I will not cross the 2 hour timer because I really would like to refund the game if they never try to fix this, I know the game is cheap and all but I really don't like buying something that is broken and wont be fixed.


[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Great game if it weren't for the FPS issues, know that you might not get the same issue so you can always buy it play and refund it if you did, the download size is only 34mb so it should be fairly simple to do that.

24056163.review:
Pasan los años y sigo asombrándome de que juegos tan simples puedan ser tan divertidos. Tres botones: derecha, izquierda y disparo es todo lo que necesitas para descargar adrenalina y pasar un buen rato poniendo a prueba tus reflejos. 

El juego consiste en descender por un pozo disparando o esquivando a todos tus enemigos. Como los disparos los haces cn las botas sólo puedes disparar hacia abajo y cuando lo haces relentizas momentaneamente la caída. Hay bloques que puedes destruir con tus disparos. Hay enemigos que solo puedes matar cayendo sobre ellos y otros que te hacen daño si caes así (los distingues porque los segundos son rojos). En medio del pozo hay 'habitaciones' donde encontrar energía, recargas e incluso una tienda con accesorios. Al pasar cada nivel puedes escoger entre tres mejoras que se generan de forma aleatoria. Por cierto: los pozos siempre son procedurales, no se repiten nunca.

Y te juro que es divertido. Por menos de 3 euros no tienes problema para probarlo. Además dado su diseño supongo que cualquier ordenador, por antiguo que sea, podrá moverlo.

Tardé bastante en pillarlo porque aunque las críticas hablan maravillas de él (con razón) el vídeo del gameplay, sinceramente, no me llamaba nada. Pero una cosa es verlo y otra, muy distinta, jugarlo. 

Aparte de eso dada su condición de 'permadeath' (no se puede grabar, cada vez que mueres empiezas desde cero) lo convierten en el juego ideal para echar una partida entre sesiones de trabajo o cuando tienes un rato libre.

24035508.review:
Simple, but fun and challenging. There are only three buttons: left, right and jump/shoot. When in the air the jump button causes you to shoot downwards with your gunboots. You free-fall down a well until you land on a platform or an enemy, and along the way you pick up items that upgrade your character.

There's a metagame with some different color pallets and characters to unlock via the gem currency, but it's permadeath and has no saving otherwise. I've found it very difficult so far and only made it to level 2-3 once. For the price it's well worth buying as it provides a different experience that's good for short bursts of play.

24034423.review:
Downwell, is a game I saw in my queue and instantly knew I had to buy.  Despite this being also released on mobile, you would not believe how much it outclassed standard smartphone crap.  Rather, Downwell is pure of form and purpose with a simple 3-input control method (left, right, and a jump/shoot button) so it wouldn't be too hard to translate those few inputs to a touchscreen.  But that's neither here nor there, get a controller for this game and buckle up.

Downwell is a fast game where you'll have to be able to react to random situations quickly to have a chance of finishing it at all... and that's before you unlock Hard Mode.  You can only shoot while in the air, and only down.  You can also kill enemies by stomping on them, which refills your ammo just like landing on ground.  Some enemies must be shot, while others must be stomped, and most are either/or.  You can slow your descent a bit with the recoil of your shots like in Vectorman, but that drains valuable ammo just to give you a bit more control.  There are some extra nuances like a combo system than penalizes you for landing and a not-so-hidden wall jump but that's the gist of it.  The game is randomly generated of course, forcing you to make these decisions on the fly and sometimes dealing you a pretty hard hand.

All the fluff and "features" that could dampen or otherwise ruin the experience have been cut out.  This game is as pure and focused as anything to come out of an 80's arcade cabinet like Joust or Centipede, and it even has the same overall aspect ratio.  Downwell is maddeningly addictive, and I have no doubt it would've gobbled up many quarters if it came out back in that day.  Games like these often seem like something you fully understand in 5 minutes, except it takes you a few more hours to even realize the subtle nuances and strategies you can, and in some cases must, develop in order to see the end of the game.  That's a beautiful thing.

Good:
-A simple concept that you can pick up and play immediately
-Very clear art that leaves no ambiguity
-Options to change palletes for funsies
-Different gameplay altering styles to suit playstyle preference
-Just difficult enough, punishingly fast but nothing you can't handle with practice
-Randomized for replay value
-Solid in-game timer for speedruns

Bad:
-Some alternate palletes are much harder to see, making them useless features that add fake difficulty
-The soundtrack is pretty abyssmal, but you have the option to disable music entirely and play your own
-Full Screen doesn't work properly in Windows 10, forcing you to jump through some hoops getting it running in windowed mode.

23851162.review:
Downwell is simple, fast-paced, challenging, and very fun. 
The graphics are also simple, but you unlock many different colour palettes as you progress. There is also a handful of different gameplay styles you can unlock. They change things like how much HP you have, or how the level is created.
Speaking of which, the levels' layout and items you get are different every time you start a new run. This improves it's replay value immensely. 
The music is very catchy. You won't get sick of hearing the first level's theme, even if you have to hear it over and over again (and you probably will). 
Overall, I greatly reccommend Downwell, and I think it's worth it's $3 price, if not more.

23843884.review:
"I have a horrible feeling that this Downwell might be the best game I've ever played. But it may have cost me my sanity. 

Amorphous shadows seemed to lurk in the darker recesses of the weed-choked hollow and to flit as in some blasphemous ceremonial procession past the portals of the mouldering tombs in the hillside; shadows which could not have been cast by that pallid, peering crescent moon. I constantly consulted my watch by the light of my electric lantern, and listened with feverish anxiety at the receiver of the telephone; but for more than a quarter of an hour heard nothing. Then a faint clicking came from the instrument, and I called down to my friend in a tense voice. Apprehensive as I was, I was nevertheless unprepared for the words which came up from that uncanny vault in accents more alarmed and quivering than any I had heard before from Harley Warren. He who had so calmly left me a little while previously, now called from below in a shaky whisper more portentous than the loudest shriek:
     “God! If you could see what I am seeing!”
     I could not answer. Speechless, I could only wait. Then came the frenzied tones again:
     “Carter, it’s terrible—monstrous—unbelievable!”
     This time my voice did not fail me, and I poured into the transmitter a flood of excited questions. Terrified, I continued to repeat, “Warren, what is it? What is it?”
     Once more came the voice of my friend, still hoarse with fear, and now apparently tinged with despair:
     “I can’t tell you, Carter! It’s too utterly beyond thought—I dare not tell you—no man could know it and live—Great God! I never dreamed of THIS!” Stillness again, save for my now incoherent torrent of shuddering inquiry. Then the voice of Warren in a pitch of wilder consternation:
     “Carter! for the love of God, put back the slab and get out of this if you can! Quick!—leave everything else and make for the outside—it’s your only chance! Do as I say, and don’t ask me to explain!”
     I heard, yet was able only to repeat my frantic questions. Around me were the tombs and the darkness and the shadows; below me, some peril beyond the radius of the human imagination. But my friend was in greater danger than I, and through my fear I felt a vague resentment that he should deem me capable of deserting him under such circumstances. More clicking, and after a pause a piteous cry from Warren:
     “Beat it! For God’s sake, put back the slab and beat it, Carter!”
     Something in the boyish slang of my evidently stricken companion unleashed my faculties. I formed and shouted a resolution, “Warren, brace up! I’m coming down!” But at this offer the tone of my auditor changed to a scream of utter despair:
     “Don’t! You can’t understand! It’s too late—and my own fault. Put back the slab and run—there’s nothing else you or anyone can do now!” The tone changed again, this time acquiring a softer quality, as of hopeless resignation. Yet it remained tense through anxiety for me.
     “Quick—before it’s too late!” I tried not to heed him; tried to break through the paralysis which held me, and to fulfil my vow to rush down to his aid. But his next whisper found me still held inert in the chains of stark horror.
     “Carter—hurry! It’s no use—you must go—better one than two—the slab—” A pause, more clicking, then the faint voice of Warren:
     “Nearly over now—don’t make it harder—cover up those damned steps and run for your life—you’re losing time— So long, Carter—won’t see you again.” Here Warren’s whisper swelled into a cry; a cry that gradually rose to a shriek fraught with all the horror of the ages—
     “Curse these hellish things—legions— My God! Beat it! Beat it! Beat it!”
     After that was silence. I know not how many interminable aeons I sat stupefied; whispering, muttering, calling, screaming into that telephone. Over and over again through those aeons I whispered and muttered, called, shouted, and screamed, “Warren! Warren! Answer me—are you there?”
     And then there came to me the crowning horror of all—the unbelievable, unthinkable, almost unmentionable thing. I have said that aeons seemed to elapse after Warren shrieked forth his last despairing warning, and that only my own cries now broke the hideous silence. But after a while there was a further clicking in the receiver, and I strained my ears to listen. Again I called down, “Warren, are you there?”, and in answer heard the thing which has brought this cloud over my mind. I do not try, gentlemen, to account for that thing—that voice—nor can I venture to describe it in detail, since the first words took away my consciousness and created a mental blank which reaches to the time of my awakening in the hospital. Shall I say that the voice was deep; hollow; gelatinous; remote; unearthly; inhuman; disembodied? What shall I say? It was the end of my experience, and is the end of my story. I heard it, and knew no more. Heard it as I sat petrified in that unknown cemetery in the hollow, amidst the crumbling stones and the falling tombs, the rank vegetation and the miasmal vapours. Heard it well up from the innermost depths of that damnable open sepulchre as I watched amorphous, necrophagous shadows dance beneath an accursed waning moon. And this is what it said:
     “YOU FOOL, WARREN IS DEAD!” - 10/10 - H.P Lovecraft.

So goddamn satisfying to watch your skill in this game increase, and since the levels, enemies, obstacles, and items you find are randomly generated, theres always a new challenge for you. An amazing game with a great soundtrack, also very good to play while listening to podcasts.

Very intuitive game mechanics, the gunboots are quite challenging to use well, as you need to balance ammo between breaking down your fall and hurting enemies you can't stomp on. You can also walljump in the game, it's a great homage to Super Metroid and a very handy mechanic to get you out of (or into, if you do it by mistake) tight situations.

The area design is quite varied, with each one having it's own set of challenges, hard mode add twists to all areas, along with a ton of extra enemies.

Couldn't take it out of my mind until I managed to beat the game on hard mode.

23659480.review: This game is excellent and incredibly addictive. If you want a game with very simple, tightly designed mechanics that rewards practice and mastery, this is for you. The only complaint that I have, and it's a relatively small complaint, is that the rewards you gain for racking up combos don't scale far enough in my personal opinion. As you descend dow nthis hellish well, armed only with a pair of gun-boots, you get rewards if you can kill enough enemies in a row without landing. If you get a combo of 8 or more, you get 100 gems, at 14 or more, you get an extra charge, and at 25 or more, you get an extra life, but it stops there. I once racked up a combo of 152 and was mildly let down to realize that it gave me the exact same rewards as a combo of 25. I wish that the game could encourage mastery even further by giving in-game rewards for pulling off insanely high combos, even if they scaled very slowly. Shame, but at the same time, it's a small complaint, especially considering how much fun I have with this game. The fact that there's a hard mode and various modes and pallettes to unlock appeals to my inner completionist and if you're the sort of person who enjoys unlocking all the little extras in a game, you'll enjoy it too. I highly recommend giving it a try.

23435170.review:
An amazing game!  I bought it on sale for $1.50 and it was worth every penny!  Even if it was for $15.00, it would still have been quite worth it!  

Only three buttons are required to play. Two to move, and one to jump and use gunboots.  It says that it is controller-capable, but it seems not to work for me, but just using a normal keyboard is just fine.  

The goal of the game is to go as far down into the well as possible, jumping, and shooting bad guys as you descend down.  As you get gems from killing enemies and breaking blocks, you will progress to get new palattes (new colors for the game), and new styles (how you walk, and how much health or upgrades you get.)

One thing that I noticed when I bought the game,  was that I first found it to be boring.  I didn't know how fun the game could be once you begin playing.

My favorite part of the game, would be when you get to a "resting spot" in the game.  There are time circles by which, when you enter, time stops, and you can take a break, rest your fingers, get a powerup, and continue your journey.  It all seems like an old 16-bit game until you reach a place like that!

There are multiple areas, containing three levels each, progressing in difficulty.  Between each level, you will be given an option to upgrade your character.  In the resting spots, you will either find a shop, gun module, or gem stack.  You can spend your gems that you have collected to buy health or charge.  And, even if you spend gems, they will still we added to your total amount. 

Thank you for reading this review, and I hope you will be playing Downwell soon!

Don your trusty gun boots and get ready to go spelunking in your backyard well. The premise of the game, make it down to the bottom of the well while collecting treasure.

Mechanics: This is a hybrid platformer/shooter. As you jump down the well aim carfully to shoot enemies with your trusty gun-boots. 23284235.review:
There comes a time in the life of every man where he must strap guns to his boots, and jump down a well.  Other men may call him mad, suicidal even, but that which is at the bottom of the well calls to him, and he shall answer that call.  For glory.  For peace.  And for love.

He knows the fall will be wrought with danger of a sort not meant for the common man.  He knows that with every new plunge into the abyss the well shall change anew, giving him no familiar rock on which to rest his weary head.  And without his hands to guide his firearms, he knows his bullets will fly never to the left, nor to the right, only down, down, down.  But just as the recoil of a bullet jostles the arm, so too will the recoil of a gunned boot push against gravity itself, slowing the descent into madness so that the mind may comprehend the blur of images hurdling by at terminal velocity.  And should this man tarry long enough, he knows he will find finer guns, and finer boots on which to strap those guns, to expedite the culling of the beasts which crawl and flutter in the darkness.

So fall.  Fall down.  Fall deep.  And know that a man is not a man until he stares long into the abyss, and shoots it in the face with a gunboot.

23245626.review:
Pros:
- Short sessions
- Price
- Skill reliant
- Diverse environments accessible with practice
- Meaningful upgrade and style choices let you configure playstyle creatively
- Different guns during the game means each session has a little more variety
- Combos feel great

Cons:
- Dull visuals (Highly subjective)
- Shallow and simplistic depth of abilities/strategy
- Progression consists mostly of different color choices, not too useful or interesting
- Requires skill at clunky mechanic to enjoy, but doesn't give a reason to stick around
- Combos are not that rewarding, and many experienced players stop their combos early.

Honestly, you'll just have to try it to see if you like it. Fanboys of the developer will defend this game to the death, but your enjoyment of this game hinges completely on whether or not you enjoy the gunboot mechanic.

23245366.review:
Downwell is as close to perfect game design as it gets. In fact there are so many perfect things about Downwell's design that I'm not even going to pretend at giving this review any structure, I'm just going to enumerate them in semi random order.

Controls are tight and responsive. Don't be fooled, this is no phone game port. This belongs on PC.

The juice: gun blasts, recoil, bouncing on enemies, destroying blocks and crates, sucking up gems - all of it feels very right, with the aid of meaty visual and sound effects.

The decision to have shops and caves in a time warp, so you can enter them safely and pause your current combo.

Combos, by the way. I didn't even know about them till reaching the end game, and once I'd got that far, starting again from level 1 was made more interesting because now I would challenge myself by going for combos, in effect making the game as hard or as easy as I wanted. Combos are rewarded with health, but you often lose health in the act of trying to get a combo. WHAT A CONUNDRUM. It's a tempting and addictive risk to ones health, with euphoric highs and damaging, rueful lows, like gambling, or class A drugs.

This whole game is as addictive as a class A drug, by the way. Once you find out about hard mode you're like, fuck that, I'll just complete normal then I'm done with this game. I completed normal mode hours ago. Still playing. 

None of the mechanics are taught via tutorial, instead they're learnt IN A REAL WORLD SCENARIO, and each time you grasp a new mechanic, it fundamentally changes how you approach your next playthrough. Starting from the beginning again is never boring.

The game is short: you will lose or complete a playthrough within about 30 minutes. So you know you can sit down and enjoy for short bursts. Or not.

Weapons. When you first play the game you think you've figured out which of them are great and which garbage, and you decide to just avoid changing weapons after you've picked up your favourite. Then you learn that each time you swap your weapon you get a health or ammo bonus. That is devilishly ingenious design.

The best plot in video game history.

Oh, and each level 'trains' you to play progressively better and faster. Like the 2nd level's introducing spikes encourages you to be nimble on your feet. The 3rd is underwater, meaning you have to fall faster to save drowning. The 4th removes safe land entirely, so you're just falling and falling. Then you realise you can play in that same manner in the first level, dodging floors, stomping skulls, racking up the combos. feeling like a boss.

The randomised upgrades at the end of each stage add some variety and experimentation to each playthrough, though they are balanced enough that the order you receive them in changes the end game little, so you do not have to rely on luck.

There are different character traits to pick at the start which have their own strengths and weakness, some oriented to specific playstyles. Some are better for beginners; others great for experts. All useful, all worth experimenting with.

Some cons: wall jumps could be much easier to pull off, and unlockable colour palettes are just a gimmick and I can't imagine anyone playing with anything other than the default style and maybe a couple of others.

Those are all the cons.

There are probably hundreds of other little perfections about this game that I either haven't noticed or can't remember off the top of my head. And this game is only $3. That's less than something else very cheap. Buy it.

23243001.review:
I want to like this game. But i cant.

This is a fast-phased platformer, that progresses vertically. It is hard but fair (on most times), and skill is more important than luck, even though it's randomly generated.

I first want to say that i'd like to give a mixed review, but since that's not possible, i will have to give a negative review

The First Problem is the utterly ridiculous amount of crashes i`ve experienced, which is not only disappointing for a game that came out in 2015, but the game also feels small.

This is the kind of game that hides that it doesnt have a lot of content by making the gameplay hard. That`s usually not too bad, but because of the common crashes, it`s just... sad.

First of all, the graphics.
the game has this black and white art style that is broken with another color, creating a very interesting art. And i personally really like that you can also change the palletes

Second - Gameplay
3 buttons, not complicated. works well, and that`s what matters

And now, the enemies. From what i know, there arent many at all. there`s 5 areas, the caverns, the catacombs, ocean, void and the boss arena. There`s about 5 different enemies in each area (except the boss arena) and one boss.
That`s the amount of content a game that came out a long time ago has to offer.

Yes, it`s only 2 dollars, and there is some replayability because it`s randomly generated and it has ``different modes``, but they change almost nothing.

I find it pretty disapointing, but if the crash problems dont happen with you, you will really like the game. If you get those problems, than you will know what i`m talking about.

23203703.review:
Downwell - отличная аркада для того, чтобы убить время.
Вы - кто-то, спустившийся вниз, в подземелье. Вы спускаетесь вниз, глубоко-глубоко. Вы расстреливаете всех на своем пути с помощью особых ботинок. Что вас ждёт в конце? Зачем герой лезет вниз? Спойлерить не буду.
В данной игре вам необходимо спускать вниз, стреляя по монстрам. По мере прохождения вам будут встречатся модификаторы выстрелов для ваших ботинок, а так же магазин, в котором можно купить еду, восполняющую жизни, или энергию, дающее большее количество выстрелов. Вам необходимо собирать комбо. Комбо - это серия убийств, не касаясь пола. За убийство 8 и более - даётся 100 кристаллов, это валюта. Её можно тратить в магазине. Так же за неё открываются вырвиглазные палитры. За убийство 15 и более - даётся +1 энергия и 100 кристаллов. А за убийство 25 и более - даётся +1 жизнь, +1 энергия и 100 кристаллов. Если вы соберете 4 лишних жизни, то ваш лимит здоровья повысится. Так же в игре есть разные стили. Каждый игрок найдёт свой любимый. Игра имеет два режима сложности: сложный и лёгкий. Для того, чтобы открыть сложный режим необходимо пройти игру в лёгком режиме. 
Вроде бы я рассказал всё об этом проекте. Проект неплохой, описывать долго его не стоит.
ВПИ: 6+ т.к. есть насилие без крови, так же высокая сложность.

23121832.review:
I love this game so much. It's simple, challenging and so much fun. Its got a retro artstyle some great music and it's kind of relaxing to play not in that its super laid back (It's hard as balls) but it will make you concentrate on it and make it so you can tune out and simply make quick decisions without thinking because there is nothing at stake and nothing to worry about but getting deeper. I don't know how the idea for this game was thought of  but nether the less it's great, who keow falling down a well would be so much fun? 
The enemies are satisfying to kill and killing them is rewarding because it allows you to get gems easily. 
The game does a great job of not being punishing while still being challenging there aren't really that many moments where I thought my death was unfair. 
The controller works really well with this game. It's responsive and makes the game a little bit easier to play
I really love how i can switch the palettes im using and how all the palettes all fit the game great. The palletes are a great reward system for playing it's fun to unlock them just to see what the next one will look like.
The game also doesnt give you a solid tutorial it tells you the controls and then you are left to control your little character with no guidance and no goal.

Some of the only problems i can really think about are ones to do with the power up system because a lot of the gun parts that are given to you through the game can activly make the game harder to play. Also because it's procedurly generated you will occasionally see an enemy stuck in a wall but this doesn't really affect the game on any major level.

23094582.review:
Resumo:

Muitos dos melhores jogos contam com três fatores...

1 - Simplicidade (keep it simple)
2 - Mecânica Firme (keep it tight)
3 - Peculiaridade (be yourself)

E Downwell carrega todos os três poço abaixo... por apenas R$ 6,29.

------

Agora... este é misto de shmup (ou deveria dizer SHMDOWN?) e platformer com uma premissa simples, mas peculiar: você cai constantemente poço abaixo e, passa por obstáculos e inimigos utilizandos as incríveis PISTOBOTAS, botas que atiram.

Downwell tem uma linda apresentação e execução em pixel art. Bom retorno sonoro e controles firmes e simples o suficiente para que qualquer um possa imediatamente jogar sem necessidade de um tutorial... esquerda, direita, pulo e disparo, simples.

E não há muito o que falar, você desce poço abaixo ao longo de quatro variações de cenário em geração procedural que adicionam alguns tipos diferentes de inimigos e obstáculos, assim como visual e música diferentes. Não se pode atirar para cima, você destrói inimigos atirando para baixo com suas botas e coletando gemas que eles deixam. Ao longo do poço você pode encontrar cavernas onde pode coletar gemas ou armas e também lojas onde pode trocar gemas por powerups. Todas as armas são úteis de alguma forma e promovem variadas formas de jogar. Acumuladas, as gemas deixam o personagem mais forte durante a partida e somam números para destravar estilos de jogabilidade e paletas de cores para a interface.

O jogo não realmente precisa, mas tem tradução competente para PT-BR.

Mas... Downwell conta com sua pequena quantidade de pequenos problemas. Primeiro é a falta de cor de destaque para o personagem jogável... Ao abater uma quantidade de inimigos, explosões com a animação do túnel podem confundir o jogador em relação à posição do personagem jogável. Se ele for atingindo neste processo, o piscar e a redução de frames no momento (que eu creio que seja algo relacionado a estética e não exatamente a processamento) podem intensificar esta confusão.

Há uma incosistência na colisão com alguns inimigos. Às vezes, correr contra um por trás irá destruí-lo, às vezes irá causar dano. Mesma coisa acontece com encontros pela frente. É uma inconsistência que acontece pouco, mas que pode realmente irritar quando ocorre.

A primeira música é realmente legal, mas as demais poderiam ser mais interessantes... A maioria das paletas extras são agressivas aos meus olhos e a única que uso e 'Matcha' (gema verde com fundo preto).

Mas, apesar destes três pontos, este é um dos melhores jogos abaixo de R$ 10,00 que você pode comprar por aqui. É simples, é firme, é peculiar e, acima de tudo, é divertido e eu recomendo tranquilamente pelo preço total.

22947904.review:
Great game!  Absolutely worth the price they are offering it for.  It would be worth 50 times the price if there was an easy mode.  Game play is fun, just as shown in the preview.  Lots of different weapons which affect game play.  It reminds me of the old monochrome PC pitfall games (not to be confused with the pitfall games for SNES and SEGA).   There appears to be lots of stategies for playing also, you can avoid enemies for speed running, or try and kill them all to collect gems.

The difficulty level is not something I normally complain about with games, but in this case the speed of the game detracts from the overall experience for me.   I enjoy difficult games, but I prefer that they build to the difficulty.  This game starts off with a significant level of difficulty and builds to what I would consider impossible game play (at least for myself).

In this case the game could be more accessible to casual gamers, if slower game play was available, or if it built to the difficulty in a more methodical manner.  While the random level generation keeps the replays fresh, it doesn't create enough novelty to practice the same levels repeatedly for an untalented gamer to get to them.  It may not be a loot grinder, but I would classify it as a practice grinder.

Its a good game, but the without a difficulty setting, the casual gamer is just buying the first two levels (1-1 to 2-4).  If you are committed I'm sure you'll get further, but the amount of novelty in the game is not engaging enough to entice me to practice enough to see what the later levels look like.   I like the game enough that I feel bad leaving criticism, but I think this game is good enough, it can handle it, and perhaps it can take it and make itself even better.

I am very satisfied with what I got out of the game and I whole-heartedly recommend it.   The quality is exceptional, which I have come to expect from Devolver games.   Congrats to the developers on a great game.

22873739.review:
One night you wake up outside on a bed and decide to jump into a nearby well.
Why? Who knows. Perhaps the better question is why you decided to sleep with your gunboots on in the first place (doesn't seem safe, but neither does jumping down a well. Whatever).

Now that we have the bulk of the story out of the way, Downwell is a retro-style (pixel art) game where you're falling down a procedurally-generated well with only your "gunboots" to protect you.

While the concept of dodging objects/creatures while falling isn't particularly new, Downwell's mechanics make this game unique and worthwhile. The gunboots have a limited charge that refills everytime you land on something (enemy, ground, object). The gunboots the dual purpose of destroying things and slowing your descent, allowing you to somewhat navigate through the obstacles.

If the increasingly large, diverse number of enemies and traps don't keep you entertained for awhile, Downwell has a variety of content that adds to the replayability.
  -  The gunboot upgrades grant you some variety, including: Shotgun, Machinegun, Burst, Laser, etc.
  -  Random caves where time is frozen - contain bonuses like gunboot upgrades, gems, health recovery, etc.
  -  A shopkeeper that exchanges gems for items that increase your health or max gunboot charge.
  -  Different color pallettes are unlockable by collecting gems, including: VBOY (all red), Nuclear (green), etc.
  -  Different starting stats (gameplay styles) unlockable by collecting gems.
  -  Randomized upgrades after you complete a section of the well, including: Drones, exploding corpses, and heart balloons.

Overall, Downwell is a very, very well-made game with a lot of replayability.
The only drawbacks are: it's hard (that's a given) and it gets tedious/repetitive if you play it for a few hours straight, but it's fun again after a short break. :)

22836261.review:
Downwell starts off as a seemingly basic twitch reflex/ arcade style game and then slowly evolves into a strategy + skill game as you start to master the EXTREMELY tight interplay of mechanics as well as your own game flow.

At first you're going to be focusing on just trying to get to the bottom of each level, avoiding or killing the enemies on your way down, and picking up and buying powerups. It's going to be fun.
But eventually you'll be maneuvering your way from enemy to enemy for perfect combos, never touching the ground and hoping for items you thought were useless in your earlier playthroughs. And then you'll completely change your playstyle for the next area. It's going to be fun.

Perfect for casual gamers, hardcore gamers, and indie hipster gamers, can't really go wrong...

Наш главный герой просыпается на 8-bit'ой кровати под 8-bit'ым деревом от 8-bit'ной музыки, и тут нас ждет шокируюший сюжетный поворот: устав от своей скучной жизни, наш парень решает покончить жизнь самоубийством, прыгая в некую бездонную бездну. Но не всё так просто, как кажется на первый взгляд. Пролетая несколько метров, мы понимаем, что это вовсе не бездна, а путь к успеху; понимаем, что это не суицид, а цель жизни. Кроме того, становится ясно, что мы летим вовсе не в бездне, а спускаемся по некоторой пещере, которая плавно перетекает в катакомбы, а та в свою очередь в другую локацию. Ну а достигнув дна, вам придется встретится с хранителем сего подземного царства и сразть его.

Кроме хранителя, который выступает в качестве босса, достигнуть дна вам будут мешать местные обитатели. У каждой локации есть свои виды существ, со своми сильными и слабыми сторонами. От одних можно избавится, прыгнув на их слабое место, а от других нам помогут только BootsGun. BootsGun это наши ботинки, которые чудом инженерной мысли, умеют стрелять различными снарядами. По мере путешествия по пещерам, нам будут встречатся различные модификации нашей обуви: от кросовок-дробовиков, до тапок-лазеров. Кроме того, после прохождения каждого уровня, нам на выбор дают улучшения-бонусы.

К слову, в игре нет никаких сохранений, что только добавляет еще больше хардкора. Умерев один раз, вы начинаете свое падение с самого верха. После каждой попытки, в общюю копилку суммируются все найденые сокровища за время полета. Добыть роскошь можно либо с убитых врагов, либо в забытых временем, доисторческих кувшинах и корзинах.

Тратить добытое богатсво нам не придется. По достижению определенного лимита, игроку откроется один из внутреигровых стилстических элементов, а именно: палитра мира или стиль главного героя. Вся игра выполнина в триколорном стиле, и благодаря новым открытым палитрам, можно подобрать цвета, приятные вашему глазу, что возможно облегчит ваше падение вниз.
Стилей главного героя всего пять: обычный, револьверный(больше модулей для обуви), булыжнк(значально повышенное здоровье), шуллер и перышко (заниженная скорость падения).

Один такой заход в игру, занимает 5-10 минут. Пройти первую локацию пещер можно за 1-2 минуты. Но чем глубже вы опускаетесь, тем аккуратнее и медленнее вы начинаете играть. Лишний раз подумаешь, прыгнуть на голову призраку-ракете или переждать пару секунд стоя на заброшенных строительных лесах.

В целом, эта очень простая и дешевая инди игра, сможет подарить вам кучу потраченного впустую времени и настольгию по 8-bit'ным играм. Тем более издателем является Devolver Digital, который уже выпустил такие замечательные игры, как HotlineMaiami (1-2), Serios Sam (1,2,3, HD), OliOli и многие другие отличные продукты.

22827994.review:
Purchased a while back during the winter sale, this charming game is certainly worth the full $3, but the current sale is a great opportunity for any fan of the rogue-like genre. There are plenty of upgrades for the gunboots, upgrades in randomized shop locations, perks obtainable at the end of a level (everything from a balloon to a drone, and even the ability to stop time!), and even new unlockable game modes to keep each playthrough fresh and exciting, albeit frustrating, as is the nature in rogue-likes. 

The game runs at a very fast pace right from the beginning, and is only more unforgiving as you descend further. With luck and practice, however, I have found downwell to be very rewarding. No matter how far down you get, the gems you collect along the way count towards unlockables, often giving you new game modes to better fit your playstyle. 

Aesthetically, I'm a big fan. Retro but not corny, new palates are unlocked to change the color from the default red. Palates range from simple blue and green, to throwbacks such as the original gameboy and visualboy. Soundtrack is very fitting, but nothing to gawk at.

Overall, I would absolutely recommend this game at any price! A fine addition to any fan of this addictingly frustrating genre.

22741101.review:
Simple review:

I love it.

You fall down a well with different levels. You always shoot downwards and you have a clip which reloads if you touch the ground or stomp on enemies. Gems from enemies are needed for the gemhigh. Gemhigh boosts your damage and range with all weapons. Runs out, if you don't collect more gems. Gems are also needed to buy more HP and bigger clip size at shops.

A lot of extra rooms on the sides for more weapons which also always give you +1 HP or +2 clip size.
Some enemies only can be stomped, some can only be shot. Going into rooms stops time, so you don't have to break your combo and you have an easy way to get back into the action. Combos (killing enemies without touching the ground) gives you rewards which add up.
8    +100 gems
13  +1 clip size
16  +1 HP

It's an awesome feeling to rush down at high speed and own the enemies with awesome BLAMBLAM WAM KABLOOM. The sound really adds to the action.  It's very very challanging as well.

tl;dr
Falling down going pewpew and stompy stomp. Cool weapons for more pewpew. Bats are (like in every fucking game) the manifest of everything that's evil. COMBO REWARDS!!! Power mode --> pew pew becomes BLAM BLAM.

Also only 3 money. GOGO!!!

The game is great for a simplistic Arcade game. VERY sleek controls with fluid movement and responsive controls, very satisfying sounds for just about every action, and the perfect speed of gameplay to make the learning curve be not as steep. The game also plays at a smooth and fast framerate to allow very precise movement, which for me, is a really big plus! Expect basic obstacles, quick thinking, power-ups, combos, and an incredibly satisfying last level. 

I definitely recommend the game for anyone whom is keen on a more unique style of platformer! I don't have a lot of game time, because it didn't save my offline game-time (so I had to beat the game twice, not a very east feat!), but for what you pay, this game will always be worth picking up for the experience.

Cheers!

22510389.review:
Downfell is a fast-paced vertial action platformer with roguelike elements. The entire idea behind this game is extremely simple yet somehow satisfying when it all comes together.

Well the story is that you're playing as a person who jumps into a very deep well trying to find the cat that dived in right before you, why? Who knows; but with these kinds of games it's best not to ask questions.

Now the story may not be very deep, but the gameplay is top notch; you simply fall from the start of the stage to the end with nothing but your reflexes and trusty Gunboots to help you out. Downwell has four stages, each with three levels and as you progress through the stages the enemies start to get more complex. Add onto that, procedural generation so no two runs should end up exactly the same making it fresh each time. As you beat levels you get to choose one of three upgrades for your character and in each stage you'll come across a shop that sells the player healing items or upgrades for gems. You'll quickly realise that to get further easier you'll need to buy items from these shops, but to get a large amount of gems at once you need to get killstreaks without touching the ground to gain a 'Gemhigh'. This is where the game will start to really shine, at first it's as simple as falling down and reaching the end while stomping on a few enemies but you'll come to wonder "how do I do all this without touching the ground?". Now this is the part where the Gunboots come into play, if there's no enemy directly under you but there is slightly above your horizontal position you can move above him by shooting your Gunboots a couple times. Every time you stomp on an enemies head it will refill your ammo so you can maintain your Gunboots, at first this is really difficult but you'll get the hang of it after a while and it starts to get insanely fun. Also when you want to enter a shop you don't have to worry about your combo because it's in a 'time bubble' so your combo stays the moment you touch the floor next to the shops entrance but you'll have to jump out of it to maintain your combo.

On top of all that you can earn unlocks by just getting gems, you'll start to get colour pallets and different playstyles to fool around with. There's also a hard mode to beat once you finish the normal game, it's basically a lot more enemes thrown at you so you can actually get a higher combo easier. This game has some small quirks that the developer left for the player to find out about, one of them being wall-jumping.

Really enjoyed the graphics, I love pixel art in any game and this game is no exception. It gives you that retro vibe and even has some old throw-back colour pallets some people might like. With all that said though, some might despise the graphics; which is fine. Pixel art isn't for everyone, but it does add to the experience for this title.

The soundtrack does not disappoint, some of the tracks are chiptune so again not everyone will enjoy it but the music does help for setting the stage for a strange yet epic journey into the depths below.

Would I recommend this to everyone? Not necessarily, at first it can be challenging if you're not used to platformers; throw in the Gunboots and a 'don't touch the ground' mindset and it can be a lot to handle at once. But it is very cheap and you should be able to get a few hours out of it, so why not just add it to your cart the next time you buy something cheap as a little extra.

22461123.review:
Vamos a ver que tenemos aquí... mmm... Un shooter vertical de gran velocidad y frenetismo... La verdad es que no suena mal, e incluso me ha resultado adictivo. ¿ Pero a quién diablos se le ocurre irse a dormir a la calle y a continuación levantarse de su sueño para tirarse de cabeza a un pozo?. Sí, a eso se le llama ``caer con estilo´´ mientras acribillas a cientos de criaturillas que hemos venido a molestar sin razón alguna. Venga ¡¡ Mirémonos a la cara!!. Somos unos montruos que se dedican a acabar con la extraña e increíblemente rica fauna en el fondo de un pozo enorme; ni el mismísimo Buzz Lightyear lo habría podido expresar mejor: `` Animalitos, animalitos inocentes y toca cogines por todas partes´´.

Esto no es ni por asomo una mala crítica como podéis ver por mi pulgar arriba ya que me ha encantado. Fijaros como de
una idea bastante simple se puede hacer una gran juego que además nos transporta hasta la nostálgica y bidimensional era de los 8 bits: Una era dónde los videojuegos tenían más dificultad y nos obligaba a currarnos toda su trayectoria, un tiempo en el que pasarse un juego era más satisfactorio... En cuanto a nuestra díficil tarea de tirarnos sin conocimiento a un oscuro pozo sin vislumbrar el fondo se podría decir que su curva de dificultad es equitativa, de eso no me quejo pero aun así supone un gran reto pasarse Downwell; la generación de escenario aleatorio así como sus enemigos lo hacen un juego difícil pero superable, como cuando jugábamos al Mario de NES ( Aunque sin la espontaneidad del escenario) y una tortuga que se movía por simple inercia nos liquidaba porque estábamos decuidados.¿ No os fastidia que os mate una tortuguita de nada?.

22455809.review:
Downwell is game design genius, distilled. Every aspect is carefully and artfully executed. Each component of the experience exists in perfect harmony with the whole. It is unique, addictive, irresistable, and an absolute joy to play. The controls are so tight and responsive that the mere act of moving about becomes fun. The difficulty level is punishingly hard, yet somehow inviting, with a well balanced skill-curve. Game design students should have to study Downwell.

The concept of the game is brilliantly simple. You get 3 buttons: left, right, and a trigger for your gunboots. You fall down a procedurally generated well, stomping/shooting monsters, and collecting gems and precious upgrades that improve your chances of survival. And from from this deceptively simple mechanic, a rich gaming experience unfolds, like the petals of an onion. Gradually, the priority shifts from just making it far down the well as possible, to doing it in style. Once you realize how the mechanics work, and start stringing together combos that in some cases can even span multiple levels (!), the game takes on a new level of enjoyment. This is the kind of game that makes you feel like a ninja once you get a groove going, bouncing from one enemy to the next.

Downwell brings me to a place of gaming happiness that many recent games (even truly great ones) fail to even approach. If you appreciate 2D game design as an artform, or if you just enjoy tough-as-nails platformers with deliciously responsive controls, you owe it to yourself to play this game immediately.

I consider Downwell to be an All-Time-Top-5 platforming game, even though the objective actually involves avoiding the platforms.

[i]Game:[/i] Downwell
[i]Genre:[/i] Indie 2D arcade
[i]Developer:[/i] Moppin
[i]Publisher:[/i] Devolver Digital
[i][u]Copy supplied by Steam[/u][/i]

[b]Downwell[/b] is an indie 2D arcade game developed by Moppin and Devolver Digital. This is one of those games that everyone highly recommends: it's cheap, it's easy to play, and it's addicting as hell.

The graphics are very simple, with multiple color palettes that can be unlocked by leveling up. The soundtrack is pretty good as well, but it never gets memorable. But the gameplay... it's nearly perfect: you keep falling down a well through different areas filled with enemies and side caves that contain shops and upgrades. And the controls are responsive and easy: when in the air you press the jump button to shoot bullets from your boots. [b]This is the entire game.[/b] And it never gets boring, it is never frustratingly hard, and it is always fun to play.

Overall, a really quick and fun game to play for 10 minutes (or 2 hours) a day that never gets tiring. Highly recommended to everyone. Plus, it is very cheap!

22415323.review:
You know I've never liked mobile gaming because it always felt sort of fake. You know what I mean? Like when you play traditional games on a PC, console, or even hand held systems, you still have a complete substantial experience. But when you play a game on your phone, it always feels like an incomplete, dumbed down experience. I suppose my feelings about mediocre and insubstantial games that the App Store has become oversaturated with can be entirely attributed to the plague known as micro-transactions. I could go on about how micro-transactions are cheap and disgusting or how they create badly designed games that feel insubstantial, even after they're done sucking all the cash out of your wallet.

But you're probably wondering what all of this has to do with Downwell, a 2D platformer where you play as a guy with guns on the bottom of his boots who is (you guessed it) descending down a well. Well, the reason I brought it up is because I haven't been playing the Steam version a lot because I've mainly been playing the excellent mobile version and I've just noticed that saying "well" two times in a row at the beginning of this sentence was probably a bit uncomfortable to read. "Well" I don't give a shit. Anyway joking aside, it's a rare treat to play a mobile game that actually feels like a real and complete experience with no micro-transaction bullshit that makes you pay for content that should already be included with the game. Now, I haven't seen the face of God yet but the fact that I can say that about an iPhone game is pretty solid proof that one exists.

But that alone isn't the only reason I like Downwell, it's actually a pretty well designed and balanced game with challenging, addictive gameplay thats topped off by a charming retro aesthetic. As I mentioned in the last paragraph, the main gameplay mechanic is that you can shoot guns on your boots that will kill enemies beneath you and the kick back from the guns will propel you up a tiny bit. Which the second part is actually quite important since you'll be falling pretty fast and you'll need to control your fall so you don't land on something that will kill you. The fact that you can only get hit 4 times before dying encourages a cautious descent.

But don't worry cause you can upgrade your health. While we're on the subject of upgrades, there are plenty of them for your character and your guns which gives the gameplay a bit of variety. But while you will only ever use less than half of the character upgrades, the weapon upgrades are pretty balanced. Each one well suits a different type of play style and the game encourages experimentation by occasionally, having randomly selected weapon upgrades restore health as well. So it forces you to switch things up if you need the health.

As for the enemies, some of them are white and some are red. Red enemies can't be jumped on at all and can only be shot with your guns. But white enemies can be jumped on Mario style but have red paint on their asses because you'll get hurt if they attack while you're underneath them. Which they will do sometimes because if you fall past an enemy, they will chase you down for a bit and try to attack you. But it's only a few seconds before they get bored and stop like they have an unusually short attention span or maybe they went to the same academy all the police in Grand Theft Auto 4 trained at.

You know now that I think about it, the gun-boots mechanic would be really annoying if you had to collect ammo for your guns. But luckily it all works quite well because you can't run out of bullets. However, the game avoids becoming too easy because you can only shoot the bullets that are loaded in your gun's clip until you land on a platform or jump on an enemy which causes your guns to automatically reload. This creates a nice gameplay balance where you have to conserve the bullets in your clip to control your fall, but is still fair by always allowing you the same amount of limited control with every fall.

That is why the game is challenging but never unfair, because it follows a specific set of rules that never changes. And let me tell you this game is challenging. The next thing I'm going to say might sound like a deal breaker but let me explain why it isn't. Downwell isn't only reminiscent of the NES because of it's aesthetic and challenging gameplay but also because every time you die, you start the whole game over again! Fun fun fun!

But wait! This aspect of the game isn't the rage inducing nightmare you probably think it is right now. If most games did this, they would be horribly un engaging. But every time you start a new game the levels are still the same but the layout of the levels are randomly generated which ensures the game is constantly engaging by never getting stale. I believe this element of the game not only adds to it's replayability but also makes the game feel a lot longer than it actually is. Because the game isn't very long and with mid-level check points you would breeze through it in a single Sunday afternoon.

But like Dark Souls, Downwell is the good kind of difficult that keeps the experience engaging and fresh from beginning to end. Well I assume to the end because I haven't finished the damn game yet, probably never will. And again like Dark Souls, it's not the rage quit kind of difficulty, it's the kind that makes you want to try again and again until you finally get to the next level. Feel the brief moment of triumph that ensues by overcoming insurmountable odds and then die because a squid monster farted on you or something.

22391435.review:
After playing this game for a solid amount of time, I have finally beaten the game and obtained every achievement.
And now I can write a solid review for this gem :)

The game play is absolutely incredible. Every move you make and shot fired feels amazing and fluid. Precision in a game like this is paramount, and Downwell has this nailed perfectly. The difficulty can be quite steep at times, especially if you are new to the game, but once you have sunken a few hours into it and have gotten a hang of the controls and mechanics, you’ll use the difficulty to your advantage.

The graphics are beautiful in their simplicity. There doesn’t need to be anymore colours or objects added to the game, as they will distract you. It’s perfect. It conveys all it needs to, without overdoing or under doing it.

The sound design is spot on. Each weapon has their own unique and distinct sound to them, and the way their sound changes when you get a gem high, which increases the weapons power and range, genuinely makes them feel unstoppable.

The soundtrack is also so fitting with the theme of the game. Each level is themed differently, and the music adds to the atmosphere of each level. It’s not too overbearing or too simple, but they are all very memorable.

All in all, it’s hard to find a game on Steam that offers this much for this little, and the fact that the game is only a mere 32mb in size blows me away every, single, time.

Get this game as soon as you can.

No, buy it right now!

Downwell fits into the category of mobile games (even more so now that you can get it on mobile). Simple controls, simple graphics, and the campaign is a short 12 levels with a boss. 

Except that you're going to try, fail, and try again multiple times before you even see this boss, let alone kill it. Not trial and error gameplay (Visual cues tell you what's up with pretty much every enemy in the game) but very challenging. Each of the weapons feel good in their own way, and so does blasting through waves of enemies. In a way, Downwell is a reverse shoot-em-up. 

People on steam like cheap games, but I would easily pay double the price for this little beauty. Devolver kept this game small, but every piece of it knocked my expectations out of the park

You can play with keyboard and mouse or a controller and after a couple of tries you get used to the "shoot" and "jump" being controlled by the same button. Getting it down is the easy part though - once you get into it then the challenge comes out. Довольно увлекательный околорогалик. Графика, стилизовання под ZX Spectrum, выполнена со вкусом, совершенно не режет глаз и навевает "ту самую" атмосферу. Процесс затягивает.
Играем за человечка с реактивными ботами, который падает в колодец, отстреливает врагов и уворачивается от препятствий и ловушек. Декорации меняются, что поддерживает интерес к тому, что же будет дальше. Вместе с декорациями меняются и враги с ловушками.
Как и в большинстве хороших рогаликов, у каждого врага своя манера поведения и к каждому нужно найти свой подход. К тому же игра ни к чему не обязывает. Можно играть аккуратно, осторожно расстеливая врагов издалека (точнее свысока). А можно нестись напролом, уворачиваясь от монстров. Оба подхода прекрасно работают.
Из минусов отмечу весьма скудный выбор бонусов и отсутствие ассортимента у продавцов. Бонусы нам дают на выбор после прохождения каждого этапа. А продавцы предлагают в основном лечилки и увеличение шкалы энергии. Изредка у них встречаются усиления характеристик, но стоят они дорого и купить их на ранних этапах весьма затруднительно.

Downell est un bon petit jeu dans un style *très* marqué 8-bit, dans les graphismes niveau GameBoy (sans que ça soit un point négatif, mais un parti pris artistique) comme dans la musique. Niveau gameplay, on y découvre aussi un style dans les plateformer de l'époque, notamment dans la gestion tir / saut sur les ennemis et le game feel associé, mais avec cette touche moderne des jeux réactif et où l'on est pas frustré par des lenteurs. 
Petit point négatif pour quelques moments un peu confus niveau animation en mêlée et où on peut parfois ne plus trop savoir ce qu'il se passe. C'est mineur, cependant.

Avec ses différents "styles" (modes de jeu) et ses palettes, purement cosmétique, il a certainement une bonne durée de vie et rejouabilité même si à titre perso je ne m'y suis pas attardé. 

Ce jeu n'a pas mille choses à offrir, mais ce qu'il propose il le fait plutôt bien.

22070005.review:
I’m not much into „rougelites”, nor do I particularly like difficult platformers, and yet „Downwell” managed to hook me and keep me interested despite being a hybrid of the above. A simple game at it’s core, it tasks the player with guiding the nameless (as far as I’m concerned) hero down a series of randomly generated mineshafts in an attempt to attain unbelievable riches in the form of gems and kill The Boss while at it. Why exactly are we doing all this is never explained, and frankly does not matter, as “Downwell” is a twitch platformer and getting better is really all there is to it.
	
The game presents us with a bare-bones platforming mechanics, where we are able to run left or right and jump, and also fire our weapon called Gunboots. They shoot straight down and can be modified by a few different pickups that can be found in the caverns. They also have limited ammo which recharges when we touch the ground or stomp an enemy, which in turn is a mechanic essential to pulling out combos. Those give us bonus gems, and gems are… well, they are shiny and worth a lot. They also allow us to buy things in the occasional shop, sometimes boost firepower, and unlock styles (which modify the game in different ways) and palettes persistently, even when we fail in our quest (hence the “rougelite” element). All this makes up for a simple and yet solid mechanical makeup of the game. Dying is common, but it’s all skill-based and I almost never feel as though I was killed off randomly.
	
Minimalistic pixel art style works well for “Downwell”, as it makes discerning enemies and backgrounds easy, though the screen can get a little cluttered at times. Enemy designs are varied both visually and mechanically, and whole presentation is just oozing style. Sound design is kept in similar simplicity, though I personally find the music a little bit too monotonous after a while. One thing that perplexes me is that the game has trouble maintaining 60 fps even on a relatively strong PC – it must be an issue with underlying game engine, as there is really nothing here that should stress any modern system whatsoever. The controls stay responsive and precise at all times, so it’s not that much of a big deal.
	
In the end, “Downwell” is a minimalistic, tough platformer where only rewards are really in your head. If it’s for you or not – that’s a personal thing. I was very pleasantly surprised and I’m constantly finding myself running the game for a quick run now and then. Plus, it’s very reasonably priced, so if you’re not absolutely fed up with retro-themed games and you like a challenge, I’d say it’s worth a try.

22051111.review:
Downwell gives me the feeling of wandering into an arcade in the strange town over and finding a dusty cabinet from the late 80s sitting in the corner waiting to be played. It is, in every inch of its design philosophy, a game made at the beginning of video game hardware--Atari, NES (let's not talk about Pong etc.)--it takes one concept and enlarges it to be the focus of the entire experience. In Downwell, your only goal is to fall down the well--until, presumably, you reach the bottom. The game acknowledges this singular intent, and as such does its best to make everything about the experience interesting or enjoyable. It gives you combos for bouncing on the heads of enemies. There are perks. A shop system. And a risk/reward that becomes accounting at some point as you reach for the highest scores or fastest time.

As is perhaps a persistent thot, a local co-op for this style of game would have elevated it to legend status--imagine crowding around the CRT screen with your ten-year-old friend to bounce down to hell together--and in a less punishing vehicle than Battletoads, too.

Downwell is a wonderful game, a perfect mix of roguelike, platformer, and good old hi-score chasing addiction. I recommend it to anyone who wishes to experience the frenzy of Asteroids in the present day.

22015379.review:
I was a lot like you. I had this game on my wishlist for a rather long time, debating whether or not I should get it. The massive amount of positive reviews failed to convince me at first. One day, I saw it was on sale, so I decided to give it a go.

Initially, I was a bit disappointed. The game seemed like it had almost no depth, and it was insanely difficult. I found it nearly impossible to pass the first level, but I kept playing.

Once I played it for a little while longer, got a feel for the controls, and passed more than one level in a single run, I began to really like the game. The strategy is unique, from when to buy health upgrades, when and how to kill enemies, and what upgrades to choose. One of my only complaints is the bats.

Those freaking bats.

I hate those bats. Once you pass by them while sailing down, they follow you. They always follow you. After you gain another health point. You feel so accomplished! You can conquer the rest of the level with ease, now that you have another health point.

That's when you spot a bat.

You think "Oh, that'll be EASY, I'll just shoot that thing out of the air!".

Nope.

The bat WILL hit you somehow. You don't even understand how it happens. Before you know it, you've hit a bat. It doesn't make any sense. Even if you manage to kill that bat, another bat will swoop down and rain on your parade. It's angering. It's so angering.


Tl;dr : Bats suck, buy it you cheapskate

21889079.review:
Simple yet challenging and quite fun!
This game is all about quick reactions. There is an assortment of enemies that you need to deal with in different ways. This isn't so bad when you figure each individual enemy out. The bigger challenge comes when you are falling down the well and everything is coming at you in a blur. You need to be able to react in split seconds in order to stay alive. You also have to be able to catch yourself in order to make use of the powerups and shops that appear at the side of the well.  I tell you, that is very challenging and will result in many deaths and many disappointments. No worries, though. Each playthrough gives you experience points that unlock new pallettes and, more importantly, new playstyles, which affect small aspects of each playthrough. 
This is a game that I won't spend too much time on but can see myself coming back to time and again. One negative for the game is that it could easily get repetative for some, especially if you don't want to put in the effort to hone your reaction times. This is necessary to advance further into the well. Small variations and upgrades give the game enough diversity to make me want to keep coming back to do this. Highly recommended! Especially considering the price!

Downwell is one of those games that gives you the familiar feeling of "playing just one more round."

It is extremely fast paced and though I consider myself not so bad in these kinds of platformers, I failed to defeat the final boss after playing for around eight hours. It is easy to learn but fairly hard to master and the gameplay is varied enough to give you a playtime of around ten to fifteen hours.

I also liked that the game indirectly nudged you to become a better player: through the achivements, you really needed to master your mid-air control and get those combos going in order to have a chance at defeating the final boss.

Overall, it is a very well spent three euros and I would easily recommend Downwell to the fans of the genre.

21824698.review:
Great downwards plaformer.  

The gameplay is very good.  There is a great balance between shooting and bouncing off enemies and obstacles.  The downward guns feel great, particularly how they change your momentum.  Bouncing off of enemies is fun and fluid.  The levels are great; each area has different enemies and environmental hazards, providing new challenges and requiring new strategies to progress.  There is a good amount of variety in characters, upgrades, and weapons to allow for many different play styles.

The graphics, music, and sounds are decent.

A successful playthrough doesn't take very long, but it takes a lot of practice to be good enough to win.  Downwell is a great choice for short play sessions.

Overall, Downwell is well polished.  I recommend this game for anyone, but it is a must buy for action platformer fans.

21678678.review:
[b]A 2D downwards SHMUP platformer.[/b]
Concept's simple; go down, shoot things with your boots, and stay alive from hurty things. For most enemies you can just step on 'em.

Controls for both keyboard & a controller work well. Can't rebind 'em but they're simple enough where it's doubtful one would even need to.

You can only shoot downwards and while in midair. There's also an ammo count that, unless you get a certain upgrade, only recharges/reloads from stepping on something you can bounce off of platformer style or landing on a platform. The game goes by pretty fast if you keep up the momentum of falling down which can get a bit exhilarating.
You can rack up combos by killing via stepping or shooty shoot without landing on a regular platform. Passing certain combo counts give small rewards but after hitting 25 you're not rewarded with anymore than what a 25 count would normally give.

It's incredibly lightweight in the "rogue-lite" section; if you go through the same numbered level again (1-1, 1-2, etc.) there won't be much noticeable and/or notable differences in the terrain and enemy placements. Much harder to notice since your primary focus is going down and staying alive.
After you beat a level you get a small selection of upgrades to choose from. Throughout the game though the total upgrades that actually exist here are incredibly small in number, meaning that throughout multiple playthroughs you'll eventually be getting the option to choose the same upgrade(s) you had in the previous run you did.
There are occassional shops that pop up as you play however their selection only comes down to a +1 or +2 increase in your max ammo count, +1 or +2 to health gain, and the highly uncommon +1 increase in max health.
You'll also occassionally find different weapons you can pick up but you can't know what they do until you actually pick them up or recognize what they'll give you by the letter shown on the item. These don't come in high number as well but once you get to know them you can sort of strategize a bit on whether or not the weapon would be useful for the current situation.

After you beat the game for the first time you're rewarded with the option to go through Hard Mode which dramatically increases the enemy count per level, change the levels themselves slightly, increase the cost of items in shops, and add a few new enemies to go up against.

It's a small game in size and content if you can manage all 12 of its levels but it's great fun for its full $2.99 price.

Downwell,
It's a simple game with simple controls and simple graphics, however this does not mean it's a bad game quite the opposite. The game makes up for these things with brilliant design.

Pros:
-controls although simple control fluently
-the simple graphics make it very clear what everything is
-you can play it in very different ways depending on what style you picked and the way you go about levels
-the items at the end of each stage give the game a lot more depth
-the game is very challenging, but not unfair the games are also rather short, which make it feel a lot less frustrating when you lose and when you finally beat it, it feels very satisfying

Cons:
-hard mode can be very frustrating, however this just might be me sucking at the game
-unlockables aside from the different styles don't do very much

So, why not give it a try it's very cheap as well as a really good timewaster. It's also on the app store if you need something for on the go.

8.5/10

21219920.review:
From my experience with difficult, somewhat randomly generated games, I'd say Downwell is pretty decent. It won't be to everyone's liking because of the difficulty, but if you enjoy a challenge I'd say Downwell is worth buying.

Pros:
+Tight controls, although there is a little intertia
+Simple yet difficult, if you get hit it's always your fault
+Different character styles allow for different playstyles (ex. stack hp or go for damage)
+You can chain crazy combos for great benefits

Cons:
-The lack of a large upgrade pool means that most runs end up with you using the same upgrades every time
-You can't afford to get hit often. Health upgrades/recovery are rare and expensive.
-If an enemy is attacking from above, you're pretty much forced to keep running downwards or have a high risk of taking damage
-It's often difficult to distinguish your character from everything else with the color palette (especially with explosions/enemies everywhere)

Overall, I'd give the game a 7/10. If you enjoy punishingly difficult games, it's definitely worth the cash.

21217478.review:
Downwell: Who knew going down could be so fun?
A review of Downwell in less than 250 words.

[h1] introduction[/h1]
Downwell is a 2D platformer. This game was a surprise hit in a near endless sea of indie games. 

[h1] Main Review[/h1]
 Note: I play this game with an Xbox One controller. Downwell is a game about bouncing on top of your enemies and racking up combos. The more combos you get the better rewards you receive (up to 25 combos). Bouncing from enemy to enemy is [b]extremely [/b] satisfying to do. You also can shoot bullets and some enemies must be shot. Downwell is a very short game and it can be beaten in less than 30 minutes. The game has an old 2D pixel look to it and has music that sounds right out of a Gameboy Color game. Some people may not like this but I love it.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
[*] The game has lots of replayability.
[*] Hard mode is so good you want to [strike]break your controller[/strike] play over and over!
[*] Quick fun game that can be beaten in short sessions
[/list]

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[list]
[*] If you do not have nostalgia for retro graphics and music you might not like them in this game.
[*] I wish there was a daily challenge mode and leaderboard.
 [/list]

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
If you are OK with the simple graphics and retro music Downwell is a game that can be enjoyed! I [b]recommend[/b] Downwell for lovers of Rogue-Lites.

21190935.review:
Fantastic in its simplicity. Probably the most replayable game in my library.

You go down the well, you jump on and shoot at the beasties, you try not to die. From the first level to the last boss, a full run will take you ~20 minutes, but that's after countless deaths beforehand. Average run for me was about 10 minutes, and I enjoyed each one.

Four areas with three levels each, spiking in difficulty with the second- the third and fourth areas aren't as difficult to traverse as the second, probably owing to the several upgrades you will have acquired by the time you reach them.
In particular I found the fourth area (with exception to the last stage) to be even easier than the first, though this may have been purposeful, to allow you access to the difficult end boss.

It didn't take me too long to beat the game, but defeating the last boss unlocks hard mode. Downwell is already a fairly difficult game, so hard mode doesn't pull any punches. It definitely poses a fun challenge, though, especially if you've become very competent playing on normal mode.

Extremely energetic and quick-paced, and very very fun. Well worth the three dollars.

roguelike divertido y adictivo estilo Shoot ’Em Up en el que tu personaje el cual podrás escoger ente 5 personajes diferentes con sus propias características cada uno. se lanzara en caída libre por un pozo sin ningún motivo aparente no sabemos que lo impulsa a tomar dicha decisión pero lo hace.
tu personaje estará equipado con unas botas pistola las cuales solo dispararan cuando estés en el aire y se recargaran automáticamente al tocar el suelo, el reto sera rebotar y rebotar encima de los enemigos sin tocar suelo firme y asi realizar combos los cuales te darán bonificaciones en gemas y escalar en la tabla de clasificaciones del juego el cual le dará aun mas incentivos de seguir jugando a esos jugadores mas competitivos (he visto combos de mas de 250 rebotes).
no es un juego fácil contando con solo 4 puntos de vida que se agotaran al contacto con los enemigos, el estilo gráfico es minimalista con apenas 2 colores perfectamente diferenciados entre si (podrás desbloquear muchos mas) los colores uno que indica el peligro y el otro en el que poder tomarse un descanso, el juego es tremenda mente frenético como la mayoría de roguelikes, las armas son de diferentes características varios tipos de ametralladoras pasando por escopetas cada una con sus diferentes cadencias de disparo hasta un potente rayo laser que destroza de un solo disparo pero que necesita de la destreza del jugador al mando (recomiendo jugarlo con mando).

el juego se puede completar en mas o menos 2 horas dependiendo de la habilidad del jugador por lo tanto se presta para  partidas cortas en ratos libres digase oficina, salas de espera, clases (no recomendado) etc... cabe señalar que el juego esta también disponible para IOS y android totalmente recomendado por su potabilidad.
Conclusión:
el juego esta muy bien en cuanto a calidad precio (menos de 2 dolares) tremenda mente adictivo no podrás parar de jugarlo tu mayor pecado sera decir "una partidita mas", te consumirá.
puntuación: 10/10
