Avoid perilous traps and deadly creatures as you traverse deeper into the underground world of Downwell.

Downwell is a great distraction if you have a few minutes to kill. The arcade action can get pretty hectic the further you survive, but the longer you play, the better you'll be at knowing what to do and how to do it under pressure. A host of unlockable modes and visual flairs are nice bonuses, as well.

It's no secret that this game was built with smartphones in mind, but this is the definitive version for one crucial reason: control. For the mobile versions, the bottom portion of the screen is dedicated to the touch controls, but it covers up what your character is going to land. This game is all about reaction time, so even those few split seconds can make all the differece between success and failure.

For 3 bucks, this game is a steal. I can't tell you how much time I've already spent on the mobile version or how much more I'll spend trying to get the Steam acheivements. If you're looking for a simple and addictive arcade platformer, this is a great one to pick up.

21114027.review:
This game is unexpectedly brilliant and you won't spend long figuring out how well it does its job.

The idea behind the game is simple, you jump down a well and attempt to fall to the bottom of it using your gun boots to kill and stomp enemies as you fall.  You pick up currency you can spend on consumable items and power ups at shops.  When you finish a level you gain a power up, similar to what happens when you finish a level in nuclear throne.  All the levels are procedurally generated and each world has its own enemies and nuances.  Games start fast, go fast, and end fast with a few unlocks as part of a overarching reward scheme.  So, it's kind of like a rogue-like where you fall down and see how far down you can go.

Finding bad things to say about the game is hard, the controls are as tight as a NES era console game, there's a jump button, a shoot button, and you can go left or right as you fall.  I'd recommend a controller to play.  Your gun boots reload as you hit some floor or solid object.  The power ups are meaningful and change the way you approach encounters as you fall down the well.  The graphical design is old, Atari old, the color consists of a black-color grayscale palate where you can change the "color" as an option.  It doesn't detract from the game and I feel the gameplay more than makes up for what you get, particularly as cheap as you can get this game for.

I really can not think of a sort of gamer who wouldn't enjoy this simple game.  The mechanics are solid, it's cheap, the playthroughs are fast paced and fun, it appeals to casuals looking for a quick playthrough and hardcores looking to break the game.  In short, it does everything a good game should do.

21112960.review:
ひたすら飛び降りていくアクションゲーム

ローグライク要素やキャラクターのアンロック・ハードモードの解禁もあり繰り返し遊べる内容です。
難易度は少し難しいが操作は簡単なので心が折れなければなんとかなるかも(？)

21083243.review:
A tricky vertical scroller with surprising depth (pun intended). Downwell further compresses the "roguelite-like" formula of games like Spelunky and Nuclear Throne for into a twitchy three-colour coffee-break game of fast decisions. 

It's all about descending through vertical platformer maps, and considers the challenges of that in its design. 
Shooting your "gunboots", meant to attack enemies below you, also slows your fall, so you can always give yourself time to react.  Despite being about blind jumps and randomly generated, Downwell is fair, and your causes of death will be greed and mismanagement.
Scoring combos and going fast feels a lot more satisfying, but slow is safe, because you can't directly attack enemies that end up above you. 

Random upgrades to choose from make every round different and can make you quite powerful.  The game's fast-paced, but not to the extent of being exhausting. It's fun to learn and there's quite some nuance to the way you move.

Overall, Downwell is [b]well[/b]-made, [i]such[/i] long-lasting fun and also really cheap.
I highly recommend it.

Downwell is the kind of game you play when you don't have a lot of time and want some action quickly. The principle is simple : you go down a well (thx captain) trying to go as deep as you can, killing ennemies and buying improvements to help you going deeper. You are your worst ennemy here, alacrity will often be equal to death. However, the most you play, the most you'll be able to rush and avoid critical situations. The gameplay looks quite simple but don't be fooled, it's ruthless and needs time to be perfectly mastered. Tough it's truly gratifying when you do something good.

I hardly recommend it to all those who love platform, roguelike games with great replayability and 8 bit style. There's no better way to spend 3€. It's worth, really.

21050130.review:
Wow!
Nagyon meglepett ez a játék.
Hangulatos, (nekem) szép, egyedi és satisfying.
A játék alap mechanizmusa olyan amit még sose láttam.
A játék kevés színnel dolgozik, de azokat nagyon jól használja és nagy szerepe is van a játékmenetben!
Ezeket a színeket meg lehet változtatni a menüben, ha kioldasz szín palettákat.
Azon kívül még zuhanási stílusokat is ki lehet oldani. (pl.: plusz HP indulásnál de kevesebb fejlesztési lehetőség, stb)
Esel lefelé egy kútba ahol szörnyek vannak és lefelé lőve zuhansz a látszólag végtelenbe.
Szintekre van osztva a kút és minden szint végén kapsz lehetőséget fejlesztésre. (pl.: Megeheted a lelőtt szörnyek hulláit és néhány szörnyhulla megevése után HP-t kapsz vissza. Van még jó pár.)
A játék alap lényege, hogy a megölt szörnyekből kieső Gemeket felveszed és zuhansz tovább.
A Gemeket elköltheted shop-okba ami random spawn-ol egy-egy szinten.
Az a 2€ amit fizettem a játékért, egyszerűen az egyik legjobb 2€-s vásárlásom volt valaha.
A játéknak van Steam Leaderboards-ja, szóval lehet versenyezni a barátokkal és a világgal.

Talán az egyetlen problémám ami lehet a játékhoz tartozik vagy a gépem gyenge az-az, hogy nagy lövöldözéseknél úgy laggol mint az első The Binding of Isaac. Aki tudja, hogy mire gondolok az megérti, aki nem az majd talán megtapasztalja. Még nem játszottam olyan sokat a játékkal, de ezt az értékelést még frissíteni fogom a további tapasztalataimmal.

Bármilyen a játékkal kapcsolatos kérdésre válaszolok!

21049841.review:
[h1] Semplice ma allo stesso tempo estremamente divertente [/h1]


Downwell è la riconferma della rivincita dei giochi low-budget, incredibilmente divertenti nella loro disarmante semplicità e dal prezzo davvero irrisorio. Pagato due euro tondi tondi, questo platform arcade è quanto di più semplice si possa trovare sullo store di Steam. La premessa è semplicissima: il nostro alter-ego digitale dovrà scendere sempre più in basso, livello dopo livello, disintegrando a suon di stomp e di proiettili qualunque nemico si pari davanti alla nostra inesorabile caduta libera. Lo stile 8-bit ricorda grandi classici quali Arkanoid, Castelvania e numerosi titoli del passato, seppur l'atmosfera e il dinamismo sono quanto di più moderno si possa testare su joypad (decisamente meglio che con la tastiera). Nel corso dei livelli e della nostra discesa, distruggendo determinati blocchi e nemici, entrando in aree protette o distruggendo qualche elemento dello scenario, saremo in grado di raccogliere gemme, la valuta del gioco che ci permetterà di comprare upgrade, salute e ricariche per i nostri stivali o semplicemente per ricaricare la vita. Oltretutto se riusciremo a rimanere in volo, colpendo i nemici saltandogli sopra oppure sparandogli in volo, potremo creare combo che ci permetteranno di ottenere gemme aggiuntive. In più, alla fine di ogni livello ci verrà data la possiblità di prendere degli upgrade per il nostro personaggio (un po' come avviene in The Binding Of Isaac, per capirci), che si riveleranno utilissimi specialmente per i livelli avanzati. A fine livello (o non appena periremo durante la discesa) accumuleremo le gemme totali che abbiamo raccolto in precedenza per poter sbloccare nuovi stili di gioco e nuove palette di colori, che andranno a modificare l'estetica con combinazioni tematiche molto particolari. 

Questo è Downwell. Io posso soltanto consigliare l'acquisto a chiunque voglia sano divertimento senza voler spendere uno occhio della testa. Ma credetemi sulla parola, partita dopo partita vi verrà sempre più voglia di continuare a buttarvi verso le profondità di questo piccolo capolavoro indie.

21036219.review:
Firstly, I love this game because you can drive all over Europe. You have to manage your money, and make sure that, when you get out a loan from the bank, you have enough money to pay it back, or are at least making enough daily profit to pay it back.

You also manage a business. You can hire drivers to work for you, and they will complete jobs for you, but you have to pay them a wage, plus some for every journey they complete. You level up they skills, that make them be better at certian things, like you can make them earn more money for going over a set distance, or you can make them carry high value or fragile cargo. They can also carry ADR materials, so things that could be dangourous. But you get paid more for that.

You can always do 'Quick Jobs', and these are when the employer provides the truck, and you just go where they tell you. This is fun, but it starts to get boring, only doing short deliverys, so you can buy a truck, so that you can go further distances, and get more money.

To conclude, I feel that anybody who likes games like Farm Simulator, or any simulator game should give this game a try, because it is a great way to unwind after a long day, and I have found it to be so much fun and very calming. Some people say that this is a boring game, I happen to disagree.

20970693.review:
見ての通りの落下アクションゲーム。
おっさんに優しくないスピード感で最初は辛かったが、やっているうちに楽しくなってそのままクリアした。

上達が実感できるゲームデザインはセンスとしか言いようがないが、ローグライクながらちゃんとコンボが繋がるように考えられてあるのがいい。
日本人特有の緻密な仕事っぷりが随所に垣間見えてプレイ感が非常に心地よい。
最初のストレス期間を乗り超えると、コンボの繋がる快感でやめられなくなっていく。

マリオ以上ロックマン未満の頻度で横から敵にぶつかるという仕様には最初はストレスばかりだったが、慣れたら少しずつ忘れていった（しかしハードモードでまた思い出した）
横への非常攻撃手段（あるいは非常回避）はあってもいいような気はするが、まあそれはどちらでもいい。

それよりもゲームシステムへの一番の不満は、武器とパワーアップが同時なので、欲しくない武器でも取らなければならなかった事。
クリア時のアップグレードも含めて行き当たりばったりなシステムにしてあるが、このゲームは無理にローグライク（ライク）にする事はなかったのではないかと思う。

アップグレードは終盤でほぼ全て取り終えるし、武器が取得用アイテムになっているせいで、店の品揃えがライフと電力しかない。
ステージの数を考えるとやはりボリュームだけが惜しい。
もっとジェムを荒稼ぎして爆買いできる余地があれば更に楽しみが広がったと思う。

とは言え、名作と言われるだけの事はあって新感覚のアクションゲームとして現状でも価格以上の価値は十分にある。
極め甲斐のあるアクションゲームを探しているなら、間違いなく買い。

20914410.review:
아니 앤딩보긴햇는데 제일 극혐인얘는 박쥐랑 오징어였음

+가이드

0. 캐릭터
개인적으로 3번째가 좋다.
노말이면 3번째 (피 6) 을 하자.
하드면 2번째 (총만 찾는놈) 을 하자.

1. 채력관리

맞지마세요
처음 부분이 가장 중요하다 생각합니다.
1-3 까지는 땋에닿지않고 8킬 콤보를 하여 보너스 100 잼을 얻어주고 상점에서 
채력아이탬을 계속 사줍니다. 채력바 밑에 4칸짜리는 채력이 꽉찬상태에 채력 아이탬을 얻으면 그 채력만큼 칸이 채워지고 4칸에 도달할때 최대채력이 증가합니다.
전 이 채력바밑 4칸을 오버힐이라 부르겠습니다.
(피가 깍인다고 저 오버힐은 사라지지않으니 걱정은 안하셔도 됩니다.).
피가 1 깎인 상태에 스시하나 먹으면 오버칸이 1개 채워지는거죠.

그리고 2-3까지는 포크앤 나이프  아이탬을 꼭 얻으셧으면 합니다.
포크앤 나이프는 죽은 시체를 먹었을때, 10개(8갠가요)가 채워지면  냠냠냠 하는소리와함께 피가 채워집니다.
네, 피가 만땅일때 시체를 먹다보면 오버힐 포인트가 추가되죠.
3-1부터 3-3까진 물속이고 빨간적외엔 나머지 몹은 시체가된체 죽고, 물속이라 느리게 떨어집니다.

사과는 초반이나 후반에 드시는게 좋습니다.

3-1에서 3-3까지 25콤보를 내면서 피를 얻는 방법도 괜찮은데 가지고 있는 무기나 아이탬에따라 좀 까다로울수도 있습니다.

2.총,총알 관리

총을 얻을때 하트표시가있는건 피채워주고, 다르게 생긴건 탄창에 최대 총알소지 2를 늘립니다.
Reverse Engineering 을 얻게되면, 총을 줍기전에 그 위로 점프해서 총알로 맛추면 랜덤으로 바뀝니다.(전 안씁니다. 차라리 다른 업그레이드가 더 좋은것 같네요)

제 기준으로 총 순위는
1.Noopy(한발씩 쏘고, 머신건보다 공속이 빠르며, 쏘는 방향 제어가능 총알소지수가 많다면 갓-건)
2.Machingun(기본총. 말이필요한가.... 기본총이지만 M이라적힌 건모듈을 얻음으로 다시얻을수있습니다) 
3.Puncher(한번에2개의 총알을 쓰지만 집탄율이 높은 3개의 총알을 분산형으로 발사) > 레이져( 범위가 매우 길며, 샷건만큼의 대미지. 다만 탄소비가 4개를 쓰는데 샷건보단 덜쓴다.그래서 샷건보다 괜찮다고 생각한다.) 
4.Triple (공격키를 꾹 누른다고 발사되는게아니라 눌러줘야 연발이 가능하다. 3개의 탄약으로 3개의 총알을 분산하며 쏘며 집탄율이 좀 떨어지고 범위도 별로.) > 
5.샷건 (탄소비 5개, 분산형, 하지만 엄청난 대미지를 준다. 그러나 너무 범위가 짧다... 하지만 총알이 많고, 레이져 사이트 업그레이드를 가지게되면 범위와 정확도가 추가되어 사기가된다. 보스를 걍 녹인다.) 
6.Burst (이름대로 버스트샷을 쏜다. 3발을 쏘며 두두두 하며 나가기에 쏘는 시간도 있고 내가 직접 눌러야 발사되는 형식인데다 걍 불편하다  걍불편해; 채력을 깎는 총이니 채력과 함께 주지않는이상 받지말자. 아니 걍 들지말자. 하지만 드론이랑 같이쓰면 꽤 좋은총이 되기도한다. 그래도 그럴바에 다른총을 쓰자)

처음부터 2-2까진 총알을 엄청사주자.
뭐.. 그후엔 돈얻기가 그리쉽진않을태니.


3.업그레이드

일단 나중에 적을탠데, 맴버쉽카드는 꼭 얻길바란다.

4. 몹 대처법
천장에 붙은 박쥐를 때에맞춰 밟을생각은 위험하다
떠다니는해골은 밟아야한다
림보로 가게되면 모든몹이 밟을수없는몹이다
물속에선 블라스트모듈이없다면 거북이를 밟고 있다면 오징어를 한번에 3킬씩내자
하지만 주의할점은, 밟을때마다 다시 내려가는속도가 느리므로 자주 밟으면 산소부족에 시달린다

5. 챕터 대처법
챕터1. 개구리와 박쥐와 거북이와 떠다니는 해파리와 빨간 벌레
걍 직접하면 알게된다.

챕터2.유령,박쥐,떠다니는 해골, 파피루스, 점프하는 해골
파피루스는 그저 뼈를 던지는 몹이고 맷집도 매워 강하기에 투사체를 던질때 투사체를 총으로 부수고 머리를 사뿐히 짓밟으면 된다.

챕터3.물속이다;
오징어, 따라오는 이상한 그 물고기, 수영하는 거북이, 조개와 항아리
조개와 항아리를 깨서(밟기x) 그곳에서 뽀글뽀글 나오는 산소를 얻을수있다.
오징어는 재때 안죽이면 맵 시야 위로 올라가서 미친듯이 수직 낙하한다.
수영하는거북이는 흥미롭다. 총에 피해는없어도 총에 맞으면 밑으로 살짝 밀린다.
따라오는 그 이상한 물고기는 짜증 그 자체다.
hot cashing이 있다면 총쏠때 사방으로 튀는 탄피가 대미지를주어 그나마 처리에 도움이된다.

그냥빨리 보이면 제거하라


6. 보스전
자 이제부터 .... 채력관리를 매우~잘해야한다.
마지막 상점에서 걍 최대채력 증가사시구요
보스를 한대 건들면 대기시간이있기에 옆의 돌들도 부숴주고
맵 위에도 보스의 떨어지는 이빨공격으로 혼돈을 보스전을 시작한다.
보스는 눈깔에서 가끔씩 3갈래로 뻗치는 에너지포를 쏘며 먼저 챕터1의 지형과 몹들을 소환한다.(그챕터의 떠다니는 몹)
어느정도 대미지를 받으면 끄아앍 하면서 밑으로 계속 내러가버린다.
위에 이빨이있기에 나도 그 보스가 내려가는 속도로 구조물을 건너거나 피하며  맵을 내려가야한다.
어느정도 밑으로 내려오면 보스가 멈추고 주위 맵은 챕터 2의 지형인데다챕터2의 몹들을 스폰하기 시작한다.
굿럭
그러면서 챕터3, 챕터4로 계속 이어진다.

보스전에서 가끔씩 맵에 총얻는 아이탬을 뿌리기도한다.
채력을 얻을수있는 방법이니 꼭 얻... 대신 총 종류는 장담 못한다.
샷건으로하면 한방딜이쌔긴한데 범위때문에 좀 그렇다.
고로 보스전엔 레이저가 최고인거같다.

7. 하드모드 캐릭터
새로추가되는건 처음 챕터에 떠다니는 거북이가 있다. 뭐 지어낸 말이다만 총으로안죽고 밟아야만하는 오른쪽 왼쪽으로만 움직이는 작은몹이다.

림보에서변화가 뚜렷히보이는데
바로 모든 챕터의 떠다니는 류의 몹(오징어포함)이 등장한다
적당히 밟고 적당히 쏘자

8. 하드모드 챕터 대처법

힘들다
그냥 암스핀 스타일을 하자
암스핀캐릭에 맴버쉽카드 업그레이드를 끼면 엄청난 궁합이다.

챕터1의 변화는 위에 몹변화밖에없고
챕터2에선 밟으면 0.7초정도후 튀어나오는 가시 블럭이  2초?간격으로 자동으로 반복되며 활성화된다.
챕터3의 변화는 바로 산소공급요소다.
도자기를깨면 산소가나오고 그것을먹는형식이지만 바뀐다.
걍 산소가 한방울씩 맵에 떠다니고 그걸 먹어야한다.
콤보를 지킬수있어서 꽤 괜찮은거같은데도 은근 산소없을때가 많다.

9. 하드모드 보스전
일반과 다른게있다면 오류인지 챕터2의 맵이나올때 가시블럭이 활성화가 안된다.
3단계에서의 산소공급은 일반과 그대로 도자기로 나온다

림보는 막장 그자체

10. 엔딩
충분히 당신이 만족할만것을 찾을것이다..

20819051.review:
É impressionante como ainda hoje jogos 2d podem apresentar mecânicas novas e interessantes. A ideia básica é antiga: jogo de plataforma onde a tela rola para baixo. A primeira fase de [i]Alex Kidd[/i] é assim, e nos jogos da série [i]Metroid[/i] sempre há uma parte do mapa em que você pode cair atirando por bastante tempo, sem encostar em nenhuma plataforma.

Com essa inspiração, [i]Downwell[/i] é inteiramente dedicado a uma longa queda em um poço que parece sem fim, com botas que atiram apenas para baixo.

A grande sacada é incentivar o jogador a fazer combos, matando inimigos em sequência sem pisar no chão. Vários "tiros" diferentes e power ups são encontrados nas fases, o que permite criar seu próprio estilo de jogo. Mas o foco nos combos permanece ao longo de todas as fases e se intensifica nas últimas, onde quase não há lugar para pisar e recuperar o fôlego. 

Uma pena que jogabilidade não seja tão precisa por conta da paleta de cores, que não permite identificar o boneco direito em algumas situações. Você vai morrer várias vezes por achar que dava pra passar sem encostar no inimigo. Mesmo assim, jogar [i]Downwell[/i] em busca de grandes combos te coloca num estado de concentração e imersão raro de se ver em jogos tão simples.

20808594.review:
Downwell est un très bon jeu résolument rétro dans ses graphismes 8bit superbes.

On l'y incarne un personnage s'enfonçant de plus en plus profondemment dans un trou (et vous saurez pourquoi à la fin !), tuant ou esquivant les nombreux ennemis ou pièges qui se dresseront sous vous.

Le gameplay est très très bon : fluide, nerveux, grisant, très difficile mais jamais frustrant et à chaque fin de partie, on voudra y retourner encore et encore jusqu'à la mort du boss (ou la mort du boss en hardmode pour les plus acharnés).

On peut dire que tous les jeux où l'on tire avec ses pieds sont vraiment géniaux ... deux jeux donc > Bayonetta et Downwell !

Les palettes de couleurs sont sympathiques même si on restera sur l'original pour plus de visibilité et de confort des yeux.

Par contre les styles que l'on débloque change vraiment le gameplay et la façon d'appréhender notre déscente ce qui est vraiment appréciable.

Les power-up à chaque fin de stage sont originals et plus qu'utiles pour terminer le jeu en y ajoutant l'aide du marchand et les zones parallèles contenant des gemmes ou des armes.

Le jeu en plus encourage les combos : à partir de 8 vous gagner 100 gemmes, de 15 > 100 gemmes + 1 munition pour votre chargeur et pour 25 combos vous gagner tout cela + un 1pv !

Petit bémol pour l'action qui est quelques fois un peu fouillis et brouillonne quand il y a trop d'éléments à l'écran, mais encore une fois chaque point de vie perdu aurait pû être conservé avec plus de réfléxes ou de clairvoyance.

Bref ce petit jeu est une perle.

> Je vous conseille pour venir à bout de ce titre d'utiliser le style "manuel" et de prendre chaque arme dans les zones parallèles pour augmenter vos munitions ou vos pv (ce qui permet aussi par conséquent de diversifier le gameplay) et de combiner ce style avec les power-up "couteau et fourchette" et "la carte du magasin" car une chose essentielle à savoir c'est que les 4 petites cases en dessous de vos pv se remplissent quand vous gagner un pv alors que vous êtes full life et une fois ces 4 cases remplies votre total de pv augmente de 1 ! Tout ça, combiné avec les gemmes durement acquises dépensées uniquement chez le marchand pour acheter des curry qui augmentent eux aussi votre total de pv de 1 > vous serez avec facilement entre 7 et 10 pv pour le boss final ce qui est vraiment non négligeable !

20764843.review:
Downwell is a game about a man and his love for a cat.

It's EASILY one of the best games I've played in years.
It kind of reminds me of the binding of isaac because of several reasons.
First of all, you constantly get random upgrades, so you constantly have to adapt to the stuff that is given to you, rather than picking a loadout you want, and going with it every round.
Secondly, the game seems impossibly hard at first, but after only a couple of hours of playing, you'll get used to it.
Finally, once you've beaten the game (took me around 7 hours played), you unlock the hard modes, which by the looks of it, will take a VERY long time to beat; so there's enough content to keep even the most skilled players busy for quite some time.
The music really fits the fast pacing of the game, and the sound effects of jumping on top of enemies, or using your Gunboots, are surprisingly satisfying.

This game is a real steal, considering the amount of amazing content they crammed into a €3 game.
If you like this kind of game, and don't mind having your ass handed to you for the first couple of hours, I strongly suggest you buy this one.

9/10

20755984.review:
El chico que ha caído al pozo, si, ese. Más le vale haber llevado las botangas tira-lazers, si no se podría lastimar.

Downwell es un juego independiente de la mano de tres desarrolladores japoneses, el principal, Ojiro Fumoto, y distribuido por Devolver Digital. Un juego en dos dimensiones roguelike, con pixel art que utiliza tres colores al mismo tiempo en todo el juego, no es algo que sonaría con optimismos; Ya esta inundado el mercado de juegos de este tipo, con un giro que, en gran parte de los casos, resume muchos efectos a la generación aleatoria y no tanto al control del jugador.

Downwell tiene la suerte de ser un plataformas con elementos menores de Roguelike, y no al reves. El juego generara la estructura de los niveles de manera aleatoria, pero siempre va introduciendo al jugador a sus conceptos de buena manera y sin hacer que parezca mucho. Los enemigos van a ir variando al pasar de zona en zona, pero los enemigos de una zona no van a aparecer en otra (al menos que varien mecanicas y esten justificados). Las armas que se pueden conseguir pueden ir variando, pero son hasta menos de ocho. Las tiendas pueden generarse en cualquier sitio y pueden tener distintos items, pero los vamos a ir viendo repetidos. 

Y eso es lo que lo hace tan buen juego. Al decidir ser un juego simple, cuyas mecanicas se establecen desde el principio, y los items que existen en el juego no son demasiados, lleva al jugador a depender menos de un RNG, y hace que este vaya adquiriendo capacidad y competencia en el juego. Y los items que se van a conseguir, o son un lujo, o son en situaciones extremas. Basicamente, en este juego va a ser Git Gud or Git Rekt.

¿Y que carajos se hace en Downwell? Bueno, basicamente controlas a un monigote que tiene que bajar lo más profundo posible de un pozo. Puedes moverte, saltar, y al estar en el aire puedes disparar con tus botas, tanto como para matar enemigos, como para controlar la caida y acabar con ellos desde arriba a lo Mayro Bros. Hay enemigos que puedes pisar, hay unos que no. Hay tiendas que te puedes cruzar y comprar items de ellas, y hay cuevas en las que puedes encontrar dinero u otro tipo de disparo/arma. Te tocan 4/6 veces, mueres, y empiezas de nuevo. 

Lo que hace que Downwell sea un juego que recomiende recae en los solidos y muy bien estructurados controles. El personaje responde muy bien a como queremos que este se mueva, y al haber una velocidad relativamente rapida en dicho personaje, varias de las acciones que vamos hacer van a tomar fracciones de fracciones de segundos. 

Otro factor que hace que Downwell sea Downwell, es su paleta de colores minimalista. En todo el juego se utilizan solo tres (?) colores (los cuales pueden variar desbloqueando distintas paletas): Rojo, que es lo que puede interactuar con el jugador de mala/buena manera; Blanco, que es aquello que no causa daño al jugador; Y negro, que es basicamente el vacio, no es nada, no existe. Son faciles de reconocer, son faciles de entender, y van variando a lo largo del juego, añadiendo profundidad a lo largo que pasa el tiempoblahblablablablablablablhablablabhlabhlbhalahb.


OK. Me dejo de charlatanería. En resumen, vete a jugar esto, son tres dolares, y valen mucho la pena.

20617588.review:
Really a fantastic little game, especially considering its price.  I don't even usually like roguelites, but Downwell surprised me with its addictive, twitchy gameplay.  The combo system is an interesting mechanic because it encourages you to stay in the air for as long as possible.  This forces you to choose between bouncing off of enemies, shooting them, or shooting simply to take advantage of your weapon's recoil.

Downwell does contain randomness, but it almost never seems unfair or out of your hands--complaints I've had with many other roguelikes.  Its difficulty is therefore perfectly acceptable.

I can think of two complaints, the first being that it can sometimes be difficult to tell whether your character will land on an enemy and kill them, or hit them from the side and take damage.  I'm sure I'll be crucified by roguelike purists for saying this, but I would have preferred a slightly more generous collision detection system.  My second criticism is that combo bonuses do not increase past 25 enemies killed, so you are encouraged to land and break your combo every so often, rather than seeing how high you can go.

If you enjoy tight, streamlined gameplay and are interested in objectively improving at something the more time you spend with it, I wholeheartedly recommend Downwell.

For anyone who is a fan of 2D platformers, this a game that would be enjoyed especially by that fanbase. It is a 2D platformer with a twist!
Instead of traditionally going horizontally, you'll be traversing throughout the game vertically, going down to whatever lies in the depths below in Downwell. For the aesthetics, it is a retro 8-bit style game to fit the aging genre. For the gameplay aspect, your player character is equipped with a pair of gunboots that would help not only fight monsters that inhabit Downwell but can be used as a means of controlling yourself as gravity is pulling you downwards. There are also many altercations you can find to change your gunboots like a triple shot or a laser beam. But every time you die, you lose these upgrades you acquire, ala permadeath. 
The thing that may turn off some people from the game is the difficulty since it is part of the trend of old school hard games. But if you can get past that, check out Downwell.

20578563.review:
Downwell is so good that I bought it twice, once on steam and then on mobile. If you like quick and casual action games, I can't reccomend this game enough.

[h1]Mechanics/Controls[/h1]
The gameplay is simple, you have to travel downwards without getting hit to many times, you shoot downwards, and can damage certian enemies by jumping on them. after each level you choose a random ability or upgrade. The controls are  very easy to handle, even on a mobile device; they are tight allowing precision even in the game's fast pacing. This is one of the few randomly generating type games I like.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Downwell has a minimalistic retro pixel-art style with fluid animation. This is one of my favorites games, in terms of graphics. The game only has 3 different colors in it's pallette: background and 2 forground colors, 1 is safe and other hurts you. This gives enemies pixel based hit areas instead of boxes and instantly communicates the way objects and enemies can hurt you.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
When playing on mobile I often mute the game, as I often play this on the bus/train... but I swear I play better when the audio is on. The Audio is top notch, but don't take my word for it, the gameplay footages above pretty much includes the entire soundtrack; Go ahead give it a listen!

At $2.99 this will give you hours if not days of fun. Can't recommend it enough!

20474572.review:
✰80%✰

[b]Pros[/b]
~Cheap
~Highly polished
~Tight controls
~Pick-up-and-play

[b]Cons[/b]
~Lack of content
~Uninteresting powerups

Downwell is a delightfully simple and somewhat unique concept for a platformer. Make your way from the start of the level at the top, to the end at the bottom. Down the well, as the title implies.

To flesh out this idea, each of the 12 levels are procedurally generated to some degree in the placement of platforms, powerups, and obstacles - which take the form of archetypal platformer baddies like bats, ghosts, frogs... and spikes. Lots and lots of spikes. You can easily deal with most of your foes by stomping on them, though some will require you to blast them with one of the several downward-shooting weapons you can find along the way. The weapon recoil is also useful for slowing your fall. Completing each level will allow you to choose from a small selection of buffs, such as a drone that follows you for additional damage, or the ability to eat the corpses of your foes to regain health. Lovely. There are also randomly appearing shops to spend your gems, which is the currency of the game, where you can buy more health or energy upgrades for your weapon.

Downwell is blessed by some very precise and responsive controls, whether which using a keyboard or controller. This both allows for some really satisfying moments where you can pull off massive combos after several successive enemy stomps, and it also means that deaths don't feel frustratingly unfair, unlike some other procedurally generated games.
The levels are split into four distinct themes: the first being like a cave where you can get to grips with the controls, the second introducing platforms with spikes that appear if you stand on them for too long, as well as new ghostly enemies. Next is everyone's favourite water level where your oxygen supply is limited. You can replenish your supply by breaking bottles and clam shells. In the last part of the game, the difficulty ramps up further with levels that have no platforms to land on at all (every wall and platform is covered in spikes!), meaning you have to rely on your shooting and stomping skills to properly control your fall. Completing this relatively short game will also unlock a harder mode.

The visual style is authentically retro-looking, and coupled with the 8bit music and sound effects, it could genuinely pass for a game from the 1980's. A cool feature that some people will appreciate is that you can change the colour palette of the game from the options menu. You can also unlock different palettes as you keep playing the game, and collect more and more gems which get added to a counter, unlocking new palettes each time it fills. The music does the job of adding thematic ambience to each of the level styles, but none of the tunes are particularly catchy or memorable.

As you'd imagine from a simplistic-looking game, it runs very well on pretty much any spec PC. The framerate is locked to 60 which is just fine. I haven't encountered any glitches or crashes and my Xbox One controller worked from the start. As previously mentioned, using the keyboard works just fine too.

So this all sounds great, right? Then why does this game, even at full price, only cost $3? Well, aside from the game being short, it also lacks in content and depth (irony?). What few weapon varieties there are, all pretty much function the same, and don't change the playstyle much. The same issue extends to the powerups. There are far fewer than you'd find on similar sorts of games like Risk of Rain or Binding of Isaac, and they also don't really have enough of an impact to make each playthrough unique.

Still, if you set your expectations on the price, then this game is an absolute steal. Those who love platform games will especially enjoy it thanks to its challenging gameplay and tight controls. Plus it's an ideal game if you just need something to occupy 20 minutes of your time.

Downwell is an enjoyable and highly polished challenge and an absolute bargain, but the lack of content makes it feel more like the foundation of a game, and a disappointing waste of potential for such a great idea.

Normal mode is pretty easy and you should be able to beat it after a couple hours of practice, but Hard mode is a jerk and a half.

20388116.review:
Downwell is one man's quest to save a cat that fell down a well by using his only weapon: gunboots. It's kind of like Vertical Drop Heroes in that the majority of your movement is vertically downward, with only your boot "bullets" and stomping on items/enemies to slow you down. You have a limited charge of gunboot bullets before you run out (and then enter free fall) but this can be replenished by landing or bouncing on an object or enemy. Additionally, killing enough enemies before you "land" on a flat surface will run up a combo counter that pays out generously if you can make it to 25 (extra heart, charge, and 100 gems). The game gives you a choice of one of 3 upgrades per level and there are shops to boost the amount of HP and charge you have.

I found the controls to be pretty good, especially in the floaty style which is really forgiving for players new to the game and the game itself really is easy to learn. However, the randomized levels and red enemies, which cannot be stomped, really ramp up the difficulty a lot for players looking to try and get 25 hit combos for that extra HP. To make things even more difficult, each of the zones adds additional stage hazards, making your journey to the bottom even more perilous. You are going to die a lot over and over again before you can even get “okay” at this game. I found myself really wishing there had been some sort of easier mode or maybe even save points.

Despite how fun the game is in all of its difficulty, I decided to finally throw in the towel after around 12 hours and making it to the final boss for the 4th time only to get quickly destroyed yet again. For now, this will be another roguelike that I just can’t finish, despite really wanting to.

20341186.review:
Downwell is a very simple game. It opens with you jumping down a well, and continues with you jumping down said well some more. That's pretty much the whole game.

The controls are extremely tight, and the visuals are very clear and easy to read. In short, the core gameplay is perfect, they couldn't make it better if they tried.

You simply platform your way down a hole and collect as much treasure as you can, spending gems at shops as you come across them. Between each level you pick one of three perks to help you through the next. When you inevitably die, it counts up your total gems. If you pass certain gem thresholds you'll unlock color palettes and modifiers to use on future runs.

And that's the game. I doesn't try to do much, but it does what it does flawlessly. At $2.99, you'd be insane not to buy this, its incredibly fun! Just download it already, you fool!

(If you like my reviews, I'm posting them all on this hideous Wordpress site now! https://probablysanny.wordpress.com/)

Very simple, but fun and addicting game. On the first night I played the game, I spent two straight hours playing through it, a testament of how fun and addicting it is. It's a retro style platformer, but instead of side scrolling, you constantly go down. The point of the game is to try and advance through the different levels all while avoiding damage and taking out enemies. You get various upgrades and abilities that makes the experience a little bit easier as you go on. What's interesting about this game is that the levels are never the same. They're randomly generated so it's never the same level. One cool thing about this game is being able to change the color of the screen. So far, I've noticed that there are 9 different colors and it changes quite a lot. Overall, I recommend this game and I give it a 4/5.

2/10/16 6:30am: I've just finished beating this game and though it was a hard and infuriating journey, it was worth it.

20315089.review:
As of writing this review, I've put in a measly 37 minutes of gameplay. Yet I'm already hooked at this game's fast-paced action with simple controls; the game is played with 3 buttons. The retro music fits in perfectly with the pixel graphics as well, and you can unlock things (such as different colors and gameplay modes) simply by collecting gems (which are dropped by pretty much everything you hit). Because of this, even if you get a game over, the gems you collected still count towards unlocking things.

The gameplay is very simple, but that doesn't mean it's easy. The startup screen shows otherwise, but the game can be played either with a controller or with the spacebar and the left and right arrow keys. You play as a character equipped with what are called Gunboots; as the name implies, they're shoes with guns that shoot downwards. You can only shoot them while you're in the air; the boots will shoot downwards, consuming charges (gunboots ammo, so to speak) as well as allowing you to briefly hover in place, cancelling your downward momentum. The instant you land on a platform or enemy, the boots will instantly reload. You can land on enemies rather than shoot them in order to kill them, but some enemies hurt you if you land on them while other enemies must be jumped on to kill them. When you defeat an enemy, they'll drop gems; collecting these gems allows you to spend them at shops located periodically throughout the levels. These shops allow you to restore some health or increase your max charges.

One of the reasons I personally think this game is so great is because it turns the concept of platformers upside down. Literally. Rather than going up, the objective is to go down. This in itself makes this platformer feel very different than the other games, as the objective isn't to go forward, upwards or a combination thereof. However, falling down too fast makes it difficult to survive as you'll get hit by enemies that are approaching too fast for you to react due to your fall speed; as such, the game makes you take a fine balance between using your gunboots to hover in place briefly (while shooting enemies) and falling. Another thing I personally enjoy is, as I mentioned earlier, how a game doesn't feel like a wasted effort if you get a game over. There are some games that are simply brutal; run out of health and it's back to the start and you get nothing. In a game with a difficulty like this, it feels like a marathon to see how far down in the well you can get, rewarding you after reach run with the gems you yourself collected in that run. When you ultimately do beat the game, you'll unlock Hard Mode, which is aptly named; there are far more enemies on each level, and the stage hazards are tweaked a bit as well to make gameplay more difficult (such as your oxygen level depleting faster on the water stages).

If you're unsure if you'll like this game, simply look at some gameplay footage; the game plays exactly how it appears.

And I think it's awesome.

20279017.review: Downwell is another prime example of why I feel that 2015 was the year of platformers. It doesn’t have the same level of world-building as Ori and the Blind Forest, the sense of discovery of INK, or the retro-done-right of Axiom Verge. What Downwell does have is gameplay that can be described as a cross between The Binding of Isaac and Dig Dug. The graphics, music, and lore seem to be pushed aside in favour of fast-paced action more akin to the action found in old arcades. The game rewards experimentation and risk taking while at the same time pushing the simple gameplay to its limits and creating some of the best twitch-gameplay of 2015. Surely Downwell could be seen as the most ‘simple’ game on this list, but that’s part of its charm. Simplicity only hurts when the core qualities are lacking. For Downwell, this is simply simple fun.

20275354.review:
Mi análisis de este juego, es decir, mi valoración sobre este es triste, puesto que me está dando muchas horas de juego y estoy disfrutando con él.

¿POR QUÉ NEGATIVO?

Antes de nada decir que la valoración negativa de este juego se debe a su absurdamente mala compatibilidad con los controladores, mandos, teclados, etc, y por la que está dando muchos problemas a mucha gente al conectar sus mandos. esta no llegaría a ser razón suficiente para un voto negativo en muchos otros juegos pero en un juego como este, en el que el uso del mando es increíblemente importante, lo es. He de decir que mi valoración de este juego cambiará tan pronto como se solcuione y lo vea o alguién me lo comunique.

AHORA HABLEMOS DEL JUEGO.

El juego es muy muy bueno, es un juego que sí, se parece mucho a The Binding of Isaac en muchos aspectos, al empezar a jugar eres basura, no puedes con nada, todo te da, todo te mata. Pero cuando llevas un tiempo jugando, acostumbrándote a todo, consigues pasártelo y hasta definir algunas partes del juego como fáciles. No os confundáis, el juego es absurdamente difícil, y muy divertido y entretenido, a parte de que la banda sonora es muy buena.

Este juego será un desafío tanto para los que quieran pasárselo sin más, como para los que pretendamos conseguir el 100% y, quien sabe, para cuando tú leas esto ya lo tengo conseguido ^-^

En resúmen, por favor arreglar lo del mando que pueda votar este gran juego como positivo.

20273052.review: After playing about 3 hours of the game I can safely say this game is worth any price under 5$. The soundtrack gets a little bit boring, but the art style and palette selection (see guides) allow for you to easily find a color scheme you enjoy to play the game in. The mechanics are simple, but prove nice with each *empty* that appears on your screen unloading your gunboots at your enemies. The game does prove difficult though, as I've managed to only almost get through the second zone when there are 4 (+a final boss) that need to be completed to beat the game. The game takes but 10 minutes to learn, but still after hours seems impossible to master. Overall, it is a hard but casual shooter that you'll find yourself hooked on regardless of its simplicity.

Overall I would give this beautiful game a 9/10!

Summary: An amazingly fun roguelite game where you go down a well while shooting enemies below you. Very fun gameplay and each gun feels great to use. Every session makes you want to come back for more and the game always gets your blood pumping.

Pros:
-Immensely entertaining and well-polished gameplay

-Good art, asethetic is consistent

-Nice soundtrack 

-Superb gunplay, often very satisfying 

-Low price

-Runs fairly well, good performance and very rarely ever laggy

-Gameplay very profound, but very easy to comprehend and hard to master

-Fair amount of unlockable content

-Fair difficulty, game is addicting

-High replayability

Cons:
 
-Lack of rebindable keys

-Lack of resolution options

-Soundtrack seems barebones, song selection is sparse and no song is very long

-Slight lack of content

Full review here: https://theflashcollection.wordpress.com/2015/12/19/downwell-review/

Downwell is a cheap little game, a shooter-platformer with very simple graphics. Absolutely recommended if you like retro platformers and shoot em ups. The world is randomly generated, so every game is different. Control is good and generally it's a very fun game! Sound effects are great, but music is forgettable.

In the game you just keep going downwards, jumping and shooting the enemies (you can also just jump on most enemies, but not all of them). In the game you can only shoot downward. So you are pretty much defenseless if the enemies attack from above or from the side. You collect new weapons and upgrades as you go. You only have a small amount of HP, so you gotta be careful. This game WILL get very difficult quickly. But it's also very addictive and makes you say "one more game!".

This game was suprisingly good, so any fan of retro 2D action should check it out! For this price, it's a great deal.

20185905.review:
Just by playing Downwell for a couple of hours it is understandable how good this game actually is.
It is in fact a mixture of a platformer with "Spelunky", developed on the Y-axis rather than a X one, with a simple mission: get as far, or in this case deep as you can by jumping on enemies or using your beloved weapon, being the Gunboots you have, which can eventually be upgraded thanks to some powerups (e.g. different types of projectiles)  you will soon find.
3 bucks are definitely more than recommended for a product of this sort, as its replayability is high due to the random levels differently generated every single time you start a new run!
Not to mention that Downwell, contrary to other games, for once asks the player to be careful in his movement and actions, as every step must not be made with ease, simply because it could completely ruin your day (i.e. it demands more skill and less luck than you think, just try to get good!).

Downwell could easily have been a classic had it been released a couple decades ago, not just because it looks and sounds the part (with a palette consisting of 4 colors and GameBoy style chiptune music), but also because it nails the old principle of simple yet challenging gameplay. It's quite addictive!

The premise is extremely simple: You have to make your way down a long tunnel filled with breakable bricks and enemies, but your abilities are limited to jumping and shooting downwards with jetpack/gun equipped boots. It feels like a blend of the original Metroid and an upside-down Kid Icarus.

This game is as good as this brownie recipe:
YIELDMakes 16 large or 25 smaller brownies
INGREDIENTS

10 tablespoons (1 1/4 sticks) unsalted butter
1 1/4 cups sugar
3/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons unsweetened cocoa powder (natural or Dutch-process)
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
2 cold large eggs
1/2 cup all-purpose flour
2/3 cup walnut or pecan pieces (optional)
Special equipment: An 8-inch square baking pan
PREPARATION

Position a rack in the lower third of the oven and preheat the oven to 325°F. Line the bottom and sides of the baking pan with parchment paper or foil, leaving an overhang on two opposite sides.
Combine the butter, sugar, cocoa, and salt in a medium heatproof bowl and set the bowl in a wide skillet of barely simmering water. Stir from time to time until the butter is melted and the mixture is smooth and hot enough that you want to remove your finger fairly quickly after dipping it in to test. Remove the bowl from the skillet and set aside briefly until the mixture is only warm, not hot.
Stir in the vanilla with a wooden spoon. Add the eggs one at a time, stirring vigorously after each one. When the batter looks thick, shiny, and well blended, add the flour and stir until you cannot see it any longer, then beat vigorously for 40 strokes with the wooden spoon or a rubber spatula. Stir in the nuts, if using. Spread evenly in the lined pan.
Bake until a toothpick plunged into the center emerges slightly moist with batter, 20 to 25 minutes. Let cool completely on a rack.
Lift up the ends of the parchment or foil liner, and transfer the brownies to a cutting board. Cut into 16 or 25 squares.

20073772.review:
Many platformer games reward you for repeatedly jumping on the heads of enemies without touching the ground. Sometimes you can earn bonuses or use them as stepping stones to reach new places. [i]Downwell[/i] is an entire game about this. 

This is a very well-polished, well-balanced action game with a neat visual style consisting of about only four colors.

The object of the game is to jump down the well, fall through twelve stages, and fight a boss. Each run is different, as the levels have randomly generated terrain, and there are also a few simple perks, stats, weapons, and upgrades to earn in a different order each game. Every three stages, the environment changes into something surprisingly different which will probably kill you the first time you make it that far, but a pleasantly stable skill curve will reward your persistence. Through dying many times you can also unlock different characters and palette swaps for the entire game, some of which will make your eyes bleed, others which are awesome enough that they might actually improve your skill level.

Don’t be fooled: this is no metroidvania or roguelike. It’s not a game about exploring the scenery, hunting treasure, and slowly proceeding forward. It’s more like a vertically-scrolling [i]Canabalt[/i] where you only have a few moments to react to whatever the game throws at you. It also has the same addictive “just one more try!” quality that runner games have.

Also, don’t make the newbie mistake of thinking that the gunboots are your main weapon. Your main weapon is your ability to stomp on enemies, and the gunboots are mostly just there to help you stabilize and aim your jump. [i]Downwell[/i] is all about the combos. The game rewards you with money and stat boosts for killing many enemies without touching the ground, things which can add up and make all the difference by the end of the game.

I had a blast with this game! It’s got a refreshingly new type of gameplay for a platformer, and the shadowy, creepy pixel graphics were stylish and fun to watch. The last achievement is quite tough, and achievement hunters can expect anywhere from 10 to 40 hours of gameplay depending on how they handle the daunting final challenge the game has in store.

20055120.review:
With simple to learn yet difficult to master 3-button gameplay, matched with 16(?)-bit graphics + 3-bit RBG/ANSI Standard colour, and an awesomely old-school soundtrack. All at the price of $3? It's hard to not recomend.

You want a better review,? I think I can do that.

Jump, move, shoot, name of the game. Controlls are tight, combat is fast and impactful, think on your feet or you will end up with your face impaled on a snail. Health is not common, and you only start out with 4. Speed is something the game handles extremely well, go fast and not mess up, an it gets a little trippy I must admit. Albeit, mental trippy, not visual trippy.

Rougelite, when you die, you go to the beginning of the game. Doing certian things unlocks styles, of which determine spawnrates of shops and weapons. You can also unlock paletts, of which are colour paletts for the game itself, purely cosmetic, but a neat feature none the less.

Graphics are what they are, this game might be able to run on a Comodre 64 if someone made a port for it. What matters when doing a retro style game is aesthetic, and this gots the nail on the head. Sprites have a consistant style, they don't look like the are from a different game entirely, of which some titles struggle with. The use of colour makes recognition at a glance possible, if it is something you should see, it's red, simple as that.

Overall, it's a good game. Simple to learn, hard to master. It's also cheap, what have you got to lose?

19854787.review:
Downwell is what I have dubbed a "Run-into-the-dungeon-and-die" simulator. In a similar vain to Super House of Dead Ninjas, you run into a hostile environment where everything wants to kill you, with one weapon, and see how long you last.

In Downwell, your weapon is the titular gunboots. A suspiciously situational weapon that just so happens to function perfectly for this area. What untold treasure you're looking for, I have no clue. But I'm guessing it's a weapon that can function beyond a purely vertical environment. Along the way, you discover gems. Which are both a form of currency and an illegal narcotic, as collecting enough gives you a gem high. I have no idea what the gem high does, but like all crippling addictions it can only be sated through unsavory acts like murder (killing enemies) and vandalism (breaking certain blocks and background objects).

If you're willing to part with your gem-shaped narcotics, however, you may find a shop within the caves. Run by a man I like to call "Master Onion". Master Onion isn't too smart, but he's more than happy to help by supplying you with health and ammo for your continued survival. Just don't go behind the counter, or he'll make a grumpy face.

If luck favors you, you'll stumble upon small caves containing gems and gun mods. These caves are protected by Time Voids, which stop all time outside when you enter them. Allowing you to take your sweet-ass time collecting what's inside. Gun mods change the way your gun fires, and it's in your best interest to pick them up, as they provide additional health and ammo. Making it through the various sections of the map allow you to pick upgrades, which are passive bonuses to further assist your survival.

When you are inevitably murdered by whatever critters lurk inside the well, you earn XP, filling up the bar unlocks Palettes (which change the color scheme of the game in various eye-straining ways) and Styles. Styles have the minor affect of changing some of your sprite animations, but the major effect of changing certain game mechanics. Such as your health, the frequency of visits from Master Onion, etc. Picking the style that suits you most, along with some practice, is how I imagine you'd make your way through this gauntlet. I've not seen past the beginning of the second area, and as far as I know there are no checkpoints.

Downwell is one of those games that I imagine I'll never be able to beat, but I still enjoy playing the hell out of it. Get it while it's cheap, though the full price is a meagre 3 dollars.

19815785.review:
Alright, I've played for a good hour. A good hour solid. And I can say that Downwell is the best Indie game I have PERSONALLY played in a while. And with good reason. This game is simple. Amazingly simple. And that is brilliant.

Let me firstly talk about the controls. When I say simple, I am mostly talking about the controls. You need to use a whopping, THREE keys to play this game. That's right, only three keys. A, D and Right Shift. Personally, I thought this game was going to be one of those games that would be a pain in the butt to get used to with controls, but within my first run of playing the game I have the controls figured out. That is one of the biggest signs of a good game; easy controls which don't take long for you to understand and figure out.

Art style in this game may look amazingly basic... And, well, it is. Once again, that is perfectly fine! You realise that the art doesn't take away from the basic gameplay of the game, and you soon realise that the art doesn't affect this game or the way you play it. That can be said for tonnes of other games, but it's not for this review. The art, whilst being basic, is lovely looking. It's not a strain to the eyes, it doesn't make me want to stop playing it after a good 10 minutes and it's really visually pleasing.

In terms of gameplay, this game has a very simple style of how you play it. You fall, whilst stomping on enemies or shooting them with your Gunboats. That's it, attack enemies. Sounds simple, right? It's not. It's really not. Your inevitable thoughts of being good at the game will soon be counteracted with how amazingly hard it actually is. Now, I mean hard as in "You-get-better-as-the-game-progresses" type hard, and not a "This-game-is-so-unfair-and-not-fun" type hard.

In terms of upgrades and such, when you complete the current floor you're on, you get a few upgrades to choose from. So far, each of the upgrades I've seen actually help you and none are a direct downgrade. There are small little enclaves which contain things to help you. You can either get weapons, health, a combination of both or even a shop. Gems are used when you die. They unlock skins for how the game looks. No, it doesn't change the art style (not that I know of, still very early in!), it changes the colour and theme of the game. I've currently unlocked a few skins, and I must say they're rather pleasing to have.

All in all, this game is great. I currently have no flaws with it. Except for the bats, man screw those little things. It's not a flaw, merely just a thing I'm going to have to get better at dealing with. And that's about it for this game, for such a cheap price you cannot go wrong with this game. And currently there is nothing wrong with this game that I can find! Extremely fun little game to just pick up and play for a good 10-20 minutes at a time.

19752980.review:
Gameplay

This game is an incredible addiction. The rules are pretty simple: you are failing down a well, you've got a gunboots that serve as weapons for the enemies beneath and slowdown your descent with limited ammo which can be refilled when you land on the ground or jump on an enemies head. Certain enemies (the ones that are completely red if you haven't changed the colours) can only die to bullets and others (shelled enemies) only to being stomped on. If you kill five enemies in a row without landing you start a combo which can give you gems (the games currency), more bullets per magasines and health if you make it long enough. The only real issues I have with the game play is that there seems to be a wall jump that is inconsistent and that more often than not makes me jump into an enemy

Level description

During your descent, to assist you, you will find side rooms sorrounded with a small bubble that stop times which either contains a giant gem which you can shoot to get (surprise!) gems, gun mods which changed your gun and gives you either health or more bullets per clip or shops were you can spend gems. When you collect enough gems you enter a gem high which allows your bullets to do more damages. As you get further in the well you will enter different areas which each have their own unique challanges to deal with (not spoiling any of its fun), with the last one which test all the skills you've accrued to that point. Each of these areas are split into 3 parts and you'll get to choose between three upgrades in between each of the parts to help you during the game.

Replayability

After each run you will do in the game you will gain EXP which allow you to unlock new styles which changes a bit how the game works (starting with more health but less upgrade choice, get more gun mod rooms but no gem room and less stores, etc.) and to unlock new colour palettes, some of which are awesome and others hurt your eyes. When you finish the game and discover what is at the bottom of the well you unlock a hard mode which adds more enemies and change slightly (or greatly) how an area work. Seriously, a surprising amount of content here for three dollars.

19714636.review:
You really can't go wrong when the User Review Rating is Overwhelmingly Positive.

You also can't go wrong with a Devolver title.

Like everyone else has said here, Downwell is a very solid, easy to pick up, hard to put down, impossible to survive 8bit action platform shooter.

Easiest way to describe it is your little 8 bit dude is falling down a well filled with enemies.  You only have two controls:  jump and shoot, all controlled with the same button, so you'll either be using the directional pad of your controller, jumping, or shooting.  When you shoot, your fall is slowed down until you run out of ammo, but your dude will reload after you either land on a rock or platform or stomp an enemy.  You'll also collect gems as you destroy rocks and kill enemies, and you can use these gems in shops on the way down to get better gun upgrades or refill your HP.  Each level concludes with you reaching the water at the bottom of the well.  The wells get deeper and take longer to complete the higher levels you reach.

It's a rogue-like, so you'll keep playing and progressing until you die, then it's back to level 1.  It will take your gems and give you a progress bar. Once it's filled, you'll unlock different colors for your screen as well as styles of play. 

You'll die a lot when you first start because you'll think you have the game figured out and you so don't.  You're not just falling and shooting stuff.  There IS strategy involved, it's not just dumb luck.

My suggestions are these:  TAKE YOUR TIME.  It's not a race to the bottom.  You want to stay alive as much as possible. Also, know your enemies.  Some of them you HAVE to shoot in order to kill and others can be stomped on the head.  Those little dudes scaling the sides of the walls with the spikey backs..SHOOT THEM.  Those birds can be a nuisance too, so blow them away when you get the chance and don't linger because they will chase you and take a nice bite out of your HP.

Know your guns.  Not every gun is as effective.  While some are really powerful, they have a very short "magazine", so if you're spamming it all the way down, you'll be empty more times than not.  My personal favorites so far are Burst (B), Shotgun (S), Fist (F), and Machine Gun (M).  Laser (L) is my least favorite.

Pick your post-level upgrades wisely.  You can drastically change your survivability by choosing the right one.  Giving yourself extra HP is fine, but not if you're not doing as much damage as you could.  You'll just take slightly longer to die.  The Droid is a great upgrade for clearing rocks and enemies as you fall.  I usually grab that and couple it with Triple (T).   I also like the upgrade that reloads your gun as you collect gems.  The less I have to think about reloading the better.  I'm trying to get to the bottom of the well with as much HP left as possible.  The right combo of gun and upgrade can make all the difference. 

Don't try to kill every enemy.  Remember, your goal is to stay alive, collect gems, and reach the end of the level, not clear the well of all enemies.  Some enemies you will seriously need to ignore and keep moving down.  If they get persistent, THEN dispatch them, but you're gonna gain gems regardless, so don't waste time trying to kill everything, lest you put yourself at risk of dying early.  You can fall faster than they can chase you, so destroy what's in your way and bypass what is not.

Have fun!  This is another great game from Devolver!

9/10

19665133.review:
Spectacular little game that provides a ton of value for three bucks.

Downwell is wonderfully simple: you're a little dude who jumps down a well, for reasons unknown.  You go deeper and deeper with each level, stomping and shooting baddies and collecting gems as you go.  The controls are very basic - you can move, jump, and shoot - but there's some depth to the gameplay, including setting up profitable combos if you can kill a bunch of critters without touching solid ground.  At the end of each stage, you can choose from one of several power-ups, much like Nuclear Throne.  Levels, enemies, shops, and so on are randomly generated, which keeps things fresh.

You can play the game slow and deliberately, to try to protect your health, or really blast down the stage and try to get huge combos for the possible payout.  The farther you go, the weirder and more dangerous the game gets, until you wind up in a pretty epic boss battle.  Downwell is one of those games that actually benefits from not having any written plot or cinematics, as the complete lack of explanation adds to the eerie aesthetic.

Great gameplay and terrific retro production values - an easy recommendation for platformer or rogue-like fans.

19646733.review:
This game is pure and simple fun. Downwell is a game about falling down a well with gunboots strapped to your feet. There are four normal worlds, and a fifth world with a final boss. That might seem like a formula for a short game.

You are sorely mistaken.

In Downwell, you will die repeatedly, and you will probably rage quit too. But this game is too satisfying, too addicting, too fun to put down.

 This game is a rogue-lite; a roguelike without all of the complexities normally associated with the genre. The levels are randomly generated, making no two playthrough the same. There are five playstyles, a harder difficulty mode, and 32 color palettes to unlock, with a custom palette maker on the way soon.

As of this review, I still haven't beaten the game. If you want to know more about the game, watch the trailer, and buy it for yourself! It's really cheap and you won't regret it!

19596890.review:
+$3
+Pick-up-and-play, easy to learn, hard to master, all that kind of stuff. Very easy to hop in and out of at a whim, as expected of a well-designed mobile port.
+Rouge-lite elements give a sense of progression both within and out a run, e.g. Upgrades, gem unlocks.
+A decent sense of balance. No upgrades or weapons feel terribly overpowered from the getgo, unless you go out of your way to find a decent synergy which even then isn't gamebreaking. However...
-Some styles are clearly better or worse than others, like Levitate Style compared to Normal and Arm Spin to generally everything else. There's not much incentive to take the others beyond self-imposed challenge. Nothing's gamebreaking here, though.
+Three-tone pallet works well enough, enemies you can and can't stomp are clearly identifiable, leads to color pallets being rewards.
/Music's okay. I was more impressed with the sound design, though.

TL;DR: This is an honest-to-god game. It's not a terribly large game, but it's designed well, it's presented stylistically, there's never a dull moment, it's cheap, it's addictive, and for what limited content it offers, it is very replayable. I would definitely recommend this to anybody, and I look forward to the Android port.

19558364.review:
This one I'm still not entirely sure about.  

The core gameplay here is pretty solid; dropping down a well, alternately blasting enemies and stomping on them, trying desperately to keep your ammo count up lest you go hurtling into oblivion is a LOT of fun...  when it works.  
More often, though, you end up, well, hurtling into oblivion.

The game seems to be trying to stretch its content by being brutally difficult; the difference between stomping an enemy and getting hit by one is very unforgiving, your life pool is painfully small, and very few of the accessable power-ups feel like they really add much.

This approach doesn't really work because, after a couple of hours, you've seen the majority of what the game has to offer, and grinding your way to the required skill to actually beat the game just doesn't seem to be worth the effort.

The game stopped being fun before I got anwhere close to beating it, but I had a good enough time with it that, considering the price tag, I wouldn't call it a poor purchase.

19518363.review:
Downwell takes what would be a section in any early platformer and pad it out into a 20-30 odd minute game. It takes a bit tenacity, and fistful of fast reflexes, some quick enemy identification, and a nice heaping of luck to navigate this vertical scroller. The main challenge of Downwell (and any horizontal scoller section) is reaction to the unknown- as oppose to a typical sidescroller that runs left to right, which gives the player a good deal of insight as what will come next due to the display dimensions of the typical screen. (Most screen and wider than they are tall) This in turn, makes such sections a practice of trial and error, memorizing the map and hazards and react to them before they are displayed on the screen. Downwell shakes this up by having randomized maps and enemy placement, which leans gameplay into the “false difficulty” territory. The game is “difficult” because you don't know what will come up and you have to react to in short order.

Completing a section rewards the player with a choice of power-up. Many of these are negligible as they add little or no benefit to your survival.(a few tend to hurt your survival) Different weapons are stowed in side areas, which have a greater influence on the gameplay though the “hang time” they give a player and damage the deal. Though your default gun works wonders and there is little reason to change it. Oddly, there is poor incentive to shoot enemies with the gun itself, as most can be stomped on, instantly defeated, and have greater rewards. Enemies that can only be defeated with the gun are better off avoided. Indeed, I found ignoring most enemies is the best strategy for survival on the mobile and PC version. The young lad you play is nimble with a small hit box and most enemies are sluggish, making them choice targets to evade rather than engage.

Overall, I find the game better suited to the mobile device than PC, thus my rating- its a cheap, shallow, slightly luck-based game to pick up and play when in transit. In short, it plays like a “falling” or vertical version of Flappy Birds, and if you like that sort of game, you will enjoy Downwell. For a mere three dollars, you get exactly what you paid for.

Weapon variety is decent, basically everything you'd need for most people's interests, I was a fan of the laser. Just a big beam that destroys everything.

19494465.review:
Downwell is about the harrowing journey of a boy to the centre of the earth via a well. He also happens to have gunboots, and people dotted along the way that are willing to extend his mortal life and give him more ammunition by trading in the crystalline souls of dead creatures. For what end, it isn’t uncovered.

Each shot is able to counter-act about 90% of the effect of gravity impacted on the boy, so the level of trauma not only on the shot creature, but also on the legs and hips of the boy, is absolutely tremendous. Landing on a creature or having a creature touch your boots instantly vaporises them, sometimes in a reaction so violent that it destroys the nearby brick and mortar of the well.

A desperate and surreal story told in a minimalist, stark fashion that is more poem than novel. A must-play for fans of Kafkaesque nightmares.

Este juego va de un homínido que cae por un pozo armado únicamente con sus botas cohete.

19465806.review:
[h1]Intense et terriblement exigeant... et pourtant, on y reviens tout temps, allez comprendre ![/h1]

Si y avais une chose à dire sur Downwell, juste une, çà serait qu'[b]à l'heure actuelle vous ne pourrez pas dépenser 3€ de meilleur manière sur Steam ![/b]

Si on devais lui rendre justice, et on va le faire, on dira que c'est le meilleur mix que vous pouvez trouvez entre un rogue-lite(« The binding of Isaac » par ex) et un plate former époque 8 bits(mais un bon! Pas une maniabilité rigide à la Castlevania... ).
Mais çà serait trop simple ; ce jeu à vraiment quelque chose pour lui, une direction artistique déjà et ensuite une vrai patte au niveau de son gameplay, impitoyable mais terriblement gratifiant quand vous arrivez à quelque chose de bien.
Bref, vecteur d'adrénaline pur et dur.

Scénario ? Obscure. Un personnage qui se réveille dans un parc, et tombe au fond d'un puits et qui plonge indéfiniment jusqu'à ce qu'un ennemie le tue où jusqu'à ce qu'il en voit le fond. Rêve, réalité ? C'est pas vraiment le propos ; on est pas dans un jeu qui se dévoile par des cinématiques et de toutes façons, vous devrez appréhendez le gameplay et les obstacles qu'il vous tend tout le long pour avoir une conclusion.

On descend les mondes dans Downwell donc. Et çà va être extrêmement simple à expliquer, parce qu'en dehors d'une croix directionnelle, il ne requiert qu'un bouton.
Vous appuyez, il saute.
Vous appuyez quand il est en l'air, il tire des balles de ses pieds. Une jauge permet de voir combien de munitions vous disposez encore, et celle ci se rempliront uniquement si vous vous poser sur une surface solide. Faudra bien faire attention donc, car si vous pouvez descendre sans vous arrêtez vous risquez d'être rapidement à cours de balle, et çà va très vite dans ce jeu !
Vous pouvez aussi tuer les ennemis qui se présentent en leur sautant dessus, attaque en générale plus destructrice, mais qui ne marche pas avec les ennemis de couleur rouge(plus exactement la troisième de la palette que vous choisirez... oui, on peut débloquer un certains nombres de trucs gadgets mais sympa...).
Vie limités et entre chaque stage au moins un upgrade à choisir parmi tout un tas qui changeront radicalement votre réussite dans ce run...

Downwell, réussi à tous les niveaux : côté plate forme, c'est frénétique et en générale vous êtes votre pire ennemie parce que vous êtes allez trop vite et vous avez pas sue contenir vos nerfs.
Côté roguelike, on peut voir çà comme une façon masochiste d'apprendre la chose ; on peut aussi saluer la grande rejouabilité que titre offre...
Dans l'un comme dans l'autre, tout dans l'esthétique de Downwell donne un aspect sombre malgré, une musique cheaptune excellente(je veux dire, pas le premier truc qu'on pense dans ces cas là comme ambiance), au sound design et surtout aux animations qui compensent mais largeeeeeeeement tout le trip minimaliste du jeu.

Y a quelque chose de presque mystérieux dans ce titre, et n'ayant pas de choses à lui reprocher, je ne vois pas l'intérêt de faire un points positifs/négatifs. Si le trailer vous parle ne passez surtout pas à côté de cette pépite, car c'est encore mieux en jeu, et j'ai rarement pour pas dire, jamais vu un meilleur investissement au prix demandé sur PC.

Un des jeux indé de l'année !

Вот правда, вся эта тряска экрана, эффекты мельтишение из ДВУХ цветов превращает в самые ответственные моменты игру в хаос. Когда вся эта хeрня заслоняет игрока наступает дизориентация и потерю ХП. Downwell's design is nothing new, but it's how it weaves its influences together that makes it special. Nothing is extraneous, and the game is extremely well balanced in its difficulty that lets you improve on your own merits and develop your own playstyle.

19390673.review:
高難易度(？)の運ゲーかつ事故ゲー

下向きにしか撃てない銃とジャンプを駆使して爽快にコンボを重ね井戸を下っていくローグライク
…の筈だが実際には事故要素の塊を極限まで排除していくただのアクションゲームである

下スクロールという特性上 常に重力に従がって落ちるため反射神経や一瞬での判断を必要とする
しかしぶつかると勝手にジャンプする障害物や当たり判定の怪しい敵など直感を邪魔する要素が多い
しかもランダム生成のブロックすら道を阻害するためにコンボを狙おうものなら敵やブロックの位置が悪くならないよう祈る他ない

そうしてライフを削るリスクを犯してコンボを稼いでもそれで交換できるのはライフか弾薬である
武器を片端から拾っていけば弾薬で困ることも早々ない上 攻撃力は武器に依存するので金では買えない
正直被弾する要素が無ければ金を稼ぐ必要はあまり無く被弾するならコストパフォーマンスが著しく悪い

手に入る銃やパワーアップアイテムも一部はコンボや爽快感に相反する性能を誇り方向性がよくわからなくなる
クリアしたいだけなら死骸を食べると回復するModを付けて敵を丁寧に処理していこう

総評すると「大学生が1人で作ったにしては」いいゲームだろうか
安いので買って損はないけど高難易度ゲーだと思ってチャレンジするとコレジャナイ感を覚えることだろう

The depth of the game comes from its variety, the levels are randomly generated and the pickups and shop items are too. That being said, this is not a very deep game (the puns) but it is worth more than the asking price of $3.00. Not a big investment at all.

19368771.review:
This is one of those games that you get immediate satisfaction from and can start or stop at any time. Imagine something like Metroid or Contra but in one direction, with the addictive short bursts of games like Super Meat Boy or Super Hexagon, but not so ball-crushingly hard. 19363541.review:
This game is amazing if you're into twitchy platformers like Cave Story.

At first it looks impossibly hard to play, but the controls and mechanics are so intuitive and polished that you actually learn to play it surprisingly fast. For example, it's very clear from the visuals which enemies you can jump on safely, and your character usually ends up making the exact movements you want, even when they're very precise. And the whole game is presented without any tutorial, instead you just learn a bit more of the mechanics and strategies each time you play, and there's a surprising amount of nuance to them. There's choices in how you upgrade your character, how you spend the gems you collect, rewards for completing combos, what types of power ups you go for, etc. and each time you play, you're motivated to try something different, or do better at what you tried last time. The graphics may look primitive, but they're excellent at conveying information. Colors and shapes are used effectively to highlight different types of objects, and even at high speeds, you can see things clearly. The sound effects are also very distinct, and provide helpful feedback.

I'd like to go for all the achievements, but the last 3 might be too hard, we shall see. Maybe I can do it.

Overall Downwell has an amazingly rewarding feeling of improving your skills. At first I looked at the achievements and felt that they would be way too hard, but after a few hours of practice, most of them became easy.

For people who like this style of skill-based game, I'd say it's perfect. I love every aspect of the design.

19326306.review:
I paid 10$ for Battlefield 4 through a 3rd party key retailer. I bought this game on sale for 2$. I can honestly say I have had more fun playing this game than a fully polished triple A title. Here's the review.

So in downwell the goal is to get to the bottom of this well. And to accomplish this you have to go down the well with bullet firing boots and kill all the monsters within. So that is a pretty simple concept however what makes this game good is the smoothness of the controls. The game plays very smooth like butter! The sound and music is very well done. The graphics are a retro style nostalgia kind of thing. Now as you go down these levels you will run into these little timevoids on the side of the wall. If you enter inside you will find either a shop, upgrades, or gems. Gems are like points that you can pickup from monsters that you kill which can be spent in shops. You can do things like, increase the amount of bullets you have, refill your hp, and even give a health boost. The game also features proccedurely generated levels. So no memorizing levels or anything like that, it's all skill based. It also serves to keep the gameplay from getting stale as well. Now on to the upgrades. In this game the bullets that you fire in the beginning are very simple and don't do much damage. In these timevoid areas you can find upgrades that change what what you shoot out of your boots. For example a shotgun upgrade will let you do a lot of damage up close but not much at a distance, a laser will do a lot of damage but you need to be a good shot to use it effectively. Also all of the upgrades are actually upgrades, they actually help you and are different from each other in certain ways. There is also a very nice variety of monsters.

Overall if you buy this game at full price I think you will easily get your money's worth out of it.

9/10

19296768.review:
Downwell es un juego arcade de plataformas en el que controlamos a un pequeño ser con unas botas que disparan. El punto del juego es atravesar cuatro zonas y derrotar al jefe para terminar el juego, usando nuestras botas (las cuales SOLO DISPARAN HACIA ABAJO) para matar a quien se ponga en nuestro camino o para mantenerse en el aire. Es un pequeño juego de plataformas, rogue-lite y down-scroller.
Empezando, el personaje se mueve muy rápido, por lo que en un inicio es una bestia para controlar, pero con un ratillo de juego uno se acostumbra; a pesar de ser muy veloz, la manera de controlar el personaje es muy muy cómoda, pues se puede mover con mucha seguridad (el personaje no se resbala al aterrizar ni cosas por el estilo). Otra parte interesante del juego es que existe la posibilidad de hacer combos saltando sobre los enemigos sin tocar el suelo, un como de 8+ te da 100 gemas (dichas gemas se usan en las tiendas para comprar distintos productos), uno de 14+ proporciona 100 gemas y una bala más y uno de 24+ da lo anterior y otro punto de salud. Hay una variedad de tipos de disparos que se ajustan mejor a cada jugador: unas que disparan más rápido pero hacen menos daño y otras que hacen mucho daño, pero disparan pocas balas. Al inicio de la partida tenemos la libertad de seleccionar el estilo que qeremos, que modifica la velocidad a la que caémos, la salud con la que iniciamos o la frecuencia con la que aparecerán las tiendas. A medida que bajamos nos topamos con una especie de burbujas que detienen el tiempo, dentro de estas puedes cambiar el tipo de bala que disparas, puedes hallar gemas o una tienda. Al final de cada nivel tienes la oportuidad de tres mejoras (o dos dependiendo del estilo que tomes), dichas mejoras modifican al personaje y hacen que, por ejemplo, atrigas gemas cercanas o que las tiendas aparezcan más frecuentemente. La variedad de enemigos del juego no es tanta, pero suficiente en cada parte el pozo. El juego da la posibilidad de cambiar la paleta de colores al gusto de cada usuario (aunque deben ser desbloqueadas). En cuanto a música no está ni bien ni mal. El juego se puede jugar lento o rápido, pero se disfruta más de la última forma. Es difícil, aunque si consigues pasar el juego te tomará unos 20 min (pero morirás VARIAS veces en el intento).
Lo malo es que las hitbox no están muy bien definidas, pero no le quita mucha diversión.
Lo recomiendo si estás de acuerdo en morir muchas veces y en poner listos tus reflejos, de lo contrario lo seguro es que no lo disfrutes.
8/10
