19279819.review:
Awesome and highly addictive! Think of Nuclear Throne/Binding of Isaac style randomization but with an emphasis on skilled platforming and combos. This game defines "easy to learn, hard to master".

Pros:
-GREAT soundtrack, makes you feel amped up while playing.

-The potential for huge combos is just absolutely nuts. Combos build up when bouncing on enemies without touching the ground, like a genocidal take on "The Floor is Lava". Jump on enemies and scenery alike, take damage to reload your Gunboots, continue combos between levels, it's a surprisingly deep mechanic that encourages you get creative. And that's before we get to item synergies! Check out some speedrun videos for this game, it gets pretty nuts.

-XP Progression, meaning that even if you suck at first, you still unlock new content if you keep at it. Very appreciated compared to games like Spelunky, which wall off new content unless you actually beat the game.

Cons:
-Somewhat "trial and error"-y, as some descriptions don't do a good job explaining things (IE, weapons called "Noppy", and characters described only with the word "floaty"). Even after a bunch of runs, I'm still not entirely sure what that heart balloon does.

-Since most of this game is falling at high speed, it can be difficult to react to threats. This can lead to some frustrating moments, such as landing on an un-stompable enemy for damage because you couldn't react in time.

Bottom line, this game is dirt cheap, and is an excellent timewaster. It's simplistic graphics hides a surprisingly deep combo system, and you can end up sinking hours into this game without realizing it.

19191042.review:
Downwell is a perfect example of how a simple twist on a worn-out formula can revitalize a genre. I may be wrong, but this is the only example I can think of where a platformer was designed to go top-to-bottom rather than the other way around, and while I don't consider myself enough of an expert to definitely say that this is the first such game, it certainly embraces that idea and executes it remarkebly well. 

You are a person, who I guess I'll just call Downwell, who comes across a well and decides, as we all would, to just jump into it. The goal is to get to the bottom, and as you can imagine, progressing through the level is no longer the main challenge - now the problem is surviving the drop, for the well is populated by worms, frogs, turtles, ghosts, floating skulls and various eldritch beasts. Luckily, Downwell has gun boots for some reason, and for some other reason, you can find modules that modify your shots. Some are standard, like the machine gun and shotgun, others are way overpowered, like the puncher or the triple, and others downright sabotage you, like the laser. Of course, you may disagree regarding which modules are good depending on your play style, but you'll always be tempted to get the module anyway, because modules always either heal you or increase your ammo charge. 

Things aren't all that simple, though, because some enemeis cannot be shot and must be pounced on, while others can only be defeated with the gun boots. Adding to the strategic nature of the drop are the upgrades you get after each level, and here each player will have his favorites as well, although one strong criticism of the game is that certain upgrades - like the increased range / accuracy upgrade and the upgrade that makes your bullet casings deal damage - are almost completely useless. 

As you go down the well, you also collect gems, which are used to buy health and charge at shops, motivating you to try and take on the tougher enemies who give out more gems. They also unlock color palettes and play styles, the former a purely cosmetic element which is nevertheless a nice touch (I like the blue Aqua palette), and the latter giving you certain pro/con combinations that allow further experimentation (I'm a fan of the boulder style myself).

If you're worried about Downwell being a roguelike, don't - this is the first time I've felt a roguelike is not only almost always fair, but also damn fun to play even when it isn't. It's a wonderful game which combines a few simple ideas to make a surprisingly sophisticated and addictive game that I imagine we all will continue to enjoy and experiment with for years to come. For example, I only recently found out that by pouncing on enemies and objects in succession starts a combo which, when long enough, gives you extra gems. It's hard to pull off, but incredibly fun and satisfying when it works. Can't wait to see what I'll find out next!

大量の敵を沸いた側から次々と倒し、進む事が出来た時は、とても気持ちが良かった。

19162381.review:
Downwell es una joya de juego basado en un concepto simplérrimo: llegar hasta el fondo de un pozo, con la ayuda de un par de botas-pistola. Con dichas botas puedes frenar el momentum de la caída, planear brevemente y cómo no, masacrar sin piedad a todo ser que encuentres. Cuánto más tiempo te mantengas sin pisar firme, mayor cantidad de gemas conseguirás, con las que podrás comprar mejoras de munición y vida. Al superar cada uno de los 12 niveles, podrás seleccionar una mejora permanente para el personaje, rollo "los enemigos explotan cuando los pisas" o "cuando recoges gemas disparas balas por todos lados".

El juego cuenta con una serie de paletas de colores. Personalmente me quedo con la predefinida; tras un rato jugando tu cerebro ya asocia que lo blanco es bueno, y lo rojo es algo que merece ser disparado. Pero si quieres jugarlo con la paleta verde de Game Boy, con el rojo cáncer del Virtual Boy, o con otra buena cantidad de combinaciones que hacen daño a la vista, puedes.

Por los tres euros que cuesta es una ganga. Es uno de estos juegos de "un intento más", y acabas echándole dos horas. Una idea sencilla (que no nueva, Super House of Dead Ninjas partía de la misma base) ejecutada a la perfección. Con una dificultad relativamente elevada, pero ni muchísimo menos imposible. Sin contar con que eventualmente desbloqueas un "modo difícil", que me hace temblar un poco de pensar en ello.

Downwell es como una fusión entre Super Hexagon y Nuclear Throne, en parte por ese momento zen de concentración absoluta cuando intentas no romper un combo de 3 niveles seguidos sin tocar suelo, y en parte por el "game feel" tan característico de cualquier juego de Vlambeer, con armas variadas soltando casquillos de bala, explosiones y cadáveres por todas partes.

Total y absolutamente recomendado.

19142510.review:
I wasn't sure what to expect when I picked up Downwell for $3.49; it looked fine enough for a cheap game, and it appeared to be an arcade-like fling that would make for some quick fun in the same vein as Luftrausers. I certainly wasn't expecting a fast, challenging twitch shooter that has a surprising amount of depth for a game about falling down a hole while firing off gunboots. If gunboots doesn't have you sold right away, I'm not sure anything else will.

Downwell is a platforming shooter where you'll spend most of your time descending deep down into said well, encountering enemies that you either have to stomp on or shoot while collecting gems to buy power-ups. As you descend through the procedurally generated levels you'll come across throngs of enemies that can be shot, stomped or have an invulnerability to one or the other. Your gunboots start off as a basic little pea shooter with a small magazine, but stomping something, like an enemy or torch, or landing on solid ground will reload your magazine, though reloading can also be achieved through upgrades awarded to you upon level completion (which I'll get to shortly). The graphics lend themselves quite nicely to the fast paced nature of the game, their chunky Commodore 64 style allows you to see incoming obstacles clearly and react accordingly, since enemies are easily discernable between one another, and the color scheme only further helps differentiate what's bad and what's safe. For example, the default color palette has your character and stompable enemies colored solid white, while gems and hazardous things to touch are colored a stark red in contrast. This means that even when you reach new level sets with new hazards, it's quite easy to deduce what can or cannot be stomped, like sharp coral or fiery ghosts. You can unlock more palettes upon death or game completion when your collected gems are tallied up towards a milestone goal, but many of the color schemes are horrifically garish, some of them downright painful to look at.

Your character's movement is borderline perfect with enough loose floatiness to your jumps, while firing your gunboots provides sharp, sudden control when needing to redirect yourself in a hurry. You'll come across side rooms during your descent which will contain either a shop to spend your gems for health and extra gunboot magazine charges, a room with a pile of gems for the taking, or a room that contains gun modules that will give you a point of health or some charges in addition to changing your gun type. There are a handful of gun types that you can obtain but you can only use one at a time, ranging from a beefy machine gun to a vicious laser which can grow stronger if you collect enough gems to reach a 'gem high', a multiplier/enhanced character state where your gunboots are super charged, doing more damage and having larger bullets depending on the weapon currently equipped. Each gun type also has different attributes for the kickback received, jolting you up which can often mean the difference between stomping an enemy and taking damage. You can also go for combos, where you're rewarded with bonus gems, health and charges for killing multiple enemies in a row without landing on solid ground - excluding ground connected to a side room. Then there are upgrades you can choose from at the end of each level, which include your stomps becoming explosive, your character being put into a time stopping bubble upon taking damage, becoming able to consume corpses for extra health and more.

While the number of gun types and end of level upgrades aren't very numerous, this means it doesn't take long until you know exactly what you're doing and what upgrades to immediately shoot for to tackle the challenges each level brings. Your play style probably won't vary with each new run since death is very likely, and you generally are stuck playing in the same ways; you may play cautiously, focus on avoiding ground as much as possible in order to rack up combos, go completely Rambo and brute force your way, or a hybrid of tactics depending on what the situation is. While other rogue-lites suffer from the issue of getting 'lucky' and having a superb run due to a lone item that makes your character overpowered, Downwell manages to avoid this folly by having character upgrades be incredibly useful in their own ways, not just flatout game breakers - Not to mention the game relies on quick, twitchy reactions and raw playing skill, which is a breath of fresh air. The jetpack is great for when you unload a full magazine and need to save yourself, but it can run out of fuel until you land on something again. The drone may be a great buddy to have for fire support, but it can kill the very enemy you were hoping to stomp on to reload your gunboots.The amount of player skill that Downwell demands while also supplying a surprising amount of depth is astounding for such a little game, and it's all punctuated by being able to restart a failed run in no time at all.

What's frustrating is that my only real complaint about Downwell is that sometimes hit detection between the player character and enemies can sometimes be a bit unreliable, especially when coming at them from an angle. Besides that, the game's brevity lends itself miles, not padding itself out with any filler or needless content that keeps you from getting right to the next level and making the big plays. Downwell is cheap, fast, fun and challenging, and at the time of writing this there is talk of the game also getting free updates. Such a little game offering so much enjoyment makes Downwell an absolute treat to romp through and I cannot recommend it enough to those wanting a new rogue-lite fix.

19088288.review:
Downwell is an unexpectedly amazing game. It came out of nowhere, showed up costing way less than it deserves, and is a very solid roguelike platforming experience. With 4 worlds and a surprise at the end, it keeps me returning to play again and again.

It looks very simple, with a three color palette, but you can soon customize this in a variety of ways. There are several playing styles to unlock as well, to suit your own.

It's not simple at all. There are a ton of systems in the game and decisions to make, more than you realize at first, and as time goes on you will make these reflexively based on what works best for you. You have to manage your downward velocity, either by bouncing off certain enemies or firing your weapon. Based on your weapon and energy, you need to decide how fast you want to fire. Based on the color and behavior of the enemies, you have to decide whether to bounce off them, shoot from a distance, or run the hell away. Do those enemies leave corpses, and can you do anything with those? Will you avoid hits and try to get yourself more maximum HP with extra food and weapons, or will you focus on getting extra energy? And, if the floor goes away for a while and you're running low on ammo, what then?

In every other platformer game, I hate pits. I find the concept anger inducing, making you suffer for issues you can't even see. But in this game, you have complete control. Sure, you're falling down a very long well, sort of an endless pit... but you're taking control of your life while you do so.

I wouldn't want to play this on anything but a keyboard or a controller, the controls are good but I wouldn't trust anything needing this kind of speed and accuracy on a phone or tablet.

If you like a challenge, buy this game. It's not easy, but it's not impossible. And it's a lot of fun. And if you're a real glutton for punishment and find the game too easy, there's a hard mode you can unlock.

19044644.review:
[h1]Downwell[/h1]

[h1]"Caer con estilo... Y con peligro de forma retro"[/h1]

Este juego indie nos de "acción plataforma" con elementos "rogue-lite y aventura" te 
adentrara te mostrara lo que nuestros juegos de infancia nos ofrecían: Dificultad, adicción, 
diversión y sin importarnos los gráficos o DLCs.

[b]Historia/Temática[/b]

Un joven sentado en el parque relajándose y pensando sobre la vida... ¡Súbitamente decide 
saltar a un abismo en busca aventuras y tesoros con tan solo sus botas de propulsión para 
defenderse! ¿¡Porque no!?.

[b]Arte Visual[/b]

2D Pixel de plataformas.
La forma del personaje y de las criaturas están muy bien hechas sin importar que sean 2D al 
igual que los mapas, cuartos y ciertos objetos.
A cierto punto del juego, habrá mucho caos pudiendo causarnos confusiones una que otra vez dificultando saber donde estar si no estamos prestando suma atención a lo que sucede.
Algo excelente del juego es que podremos cambiar el color de la interfaz, fondo, mapas y... 
TODO con las "paletas" que iremos desbloqueando.

[b]Arte Auditivo/Musical[/b]

Cada uno de las músicas de los escenarios y sonidos del juego encajan a la perfección con el juego, causando no perder interés en ningún momento en sus sonidos... Al contrario, al mas jugar y escuchar, hará que queramos seguir jugando.

[b]Controles e Interfaz[/b]

Teclado: "Flechas" para moverse. "Espacio" para saltar y al dejarlo presionado disparamos 
con las botas.

[b]Jugabilidad[/b]

Para avanzar en el juego tendremos que caer hasta llegar al final de la parte del mundo. Un mundo estará compuesto por tres partes. Solo tendremos 4 vidas, hay que tener mucho cuidado
A medida que vayamos cayendo, habrán criaturas que nos impedirán el paso e irán hacia 
nosotros para atacarnos, por lo cual tendremos la opción de saltar en ellos para destruirlos 
o usar las botas a propulsión para disparar. Al matar al criaturas conseguiremos "Gemas" 
las cuales se pueden usar en las "Tiendas" para comprar "PS" (Vida) o "Recarga" (Mas cargas para disparar con las botas).
No siempre podremos estar disparando con las botas si se nos acabaron las "Cargas", si se 
nos acaban, tendremos que tocar suelo de nuevo o caer encima de alguna criatura para 
recargar y seguir disparando.

- Habra ciertos cuartos los cuales tendrán diferentes tipos de disparos, desde "Ráfaga" a 
"Láser"
- Cada vez que terminamos una parte de un mundo, tendremos la opción de escoger entre tres mejoras que nos servirán para seguir avanzando.
- Los mapas se generan de forma aleatoria, difícilmente un mapa se repetirá.
- La dificultad es excesivamente alta.
- Muy adictivo
- Muy bajo costo
- No costa con cartas de Steam

[b]9.5/10[/b]

Mentor/Curator de [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/VaomGaming#]Vaom Gaming[/url]

19017573.review:
Sometimes I fantasize about my coworkers. At night and by myself (not in the workplace). I know that some of them may find this offensive. But it’s a compliment. Plus, it’s not like I have rapey fantasies (I GREATLY dislike the porno sex). I treat the ladies right in my awake dreams. And in my sleep dreams, too. 

I can see us right now. 

Imagine two of us at some venue. Someplace where levity reigns. And we’re laughing. 
And later on, we end up at her place, where she pulls me to her couch.

What happens next depends on the lady. Different women have different fantasies, waiting for me to make real.

And as you look at the screenshots for Downwell, you may think that it’s just The Sims with lesser graphics. But there are many subtle differences, altogether making the games quite different. For one thing in Downwell, instead of being about running a family and their home, you’re a white man falling down a VERY long well. Also in The Sims you have a massive wardrobe, along with careers for characters; while in Downwell you’re just the one dude (presumably unemployed or vacationing), and you’re naked except for the boots you wear with the guns in them. This is very different from The Sims, where usually you have to use starvation or drowning or guinea pigs to kill your characters. The Sims doesn’t let you kill via any guns attached to boots. Downwell is Japanese. The Sims is American.

I like imagining myself taking off the heels (or boots) of my coworkers, and kissing up the inward sides of their legs. 

While with some of the ladies, I like to imagine holding them from behind, placing my hands and stroking wherever it feels right. And while doing this kissing the side of her neck and just behind her ear, compelling her body to want to fall backwards, as her mind focuses on the touch of my nose and lips and hands. Sorta like when you fall down the well, and you finally get to the 2nd level; and it looks spooky! There are ghosts and skeletons!  

It’s so satisfying seeing yourself masterfully make your way through those enemies, through the side shops, and finally to the next floor.

Although I have heard people complain about the colors. The graphics are fairly minimalist (it may take three seconds for you to download the game). Enemies you shouldn’t touch at all are red (at least on the color pallete I’ve stuck with), while the others are the other main color. White by default. I’ve noticed games critics complain about it being too samey, setting players up for visual confusion and unfair deaths. I agree that the deaths can feel unfair.

But you should never see the fairly solid color of a co-worker’s skin as a bad thing. Her skin tone makes her more interesting. And if a rare color, exotic. (Remember the green lady from the 2009 Star Trek film?) From one’s body, I just want it to be healthy. And I want her to be happy. I want to make her Very happy. Happier than she’s ever been with any other man, or woman. My coworkers deserve that. And not just the lady ones, but the male ones, too. I can be open-minded (for my sexy coworkers).

Which reminds me, Downwell strikes what seems a near-perfect balance between simplicity and complexity. It has just three buttons, with which you can have many dramatic moments due to all the variables the levels throw at you. 

Losing life becomes drama.
Gathering gems (to buy power-ups) becomes drama. 
Shopping even becomes drama!
Quickly deciding when to fire your weapons is drama; you really don’t want to miss your targets. And it almost all moves so fast--you’re usually falling--with those time-freezing bubbles feeling sublime. It is all so close to being perfect. Like the minds and bodies of the ladies and gents at work.

18944325.review:
I CAN'T BEAT THIS GAME BUT I CAN'T STOP PLAYING IT

In all seriousness though, this is probably one of my favorite games to date. It's clever, brutal, and inspired, all the while feeling original. The premise, if you don't know by now, is simple. Descend down the well using your gunboots and various platforms to slow your descent. Enemies are both interesting and varied, providing a robust challenge that to the point of this review (~3 hours played on and off) has kept even a moderately skilled gamer like myself from reaching the end.

This is a simple arcade game on its face, but once you spend some time with it, you really start to see just how much of an attention to detail the creators have. It's a masterpiece, from its mechanics, to the gems, to the addicting challenge, and all the way to something as minor as the freaking music that plays when you enter one of the many store-zones scattered around the game.

Downwell, without a doubt, is my favorite game of 2015. Not just because it reeks of arcadey nostalgia. Not just because the various music tracks are buried into my head. Not because it's wholly original in its design. But because it has ALL of those things. Downwell is my favorite game of 2015 because, simply put, it's perfect.















Why are you still reading this shit? Go buy Downwell already dammit!

18841969.review:
Downwell is a game that does quite literally everything right:

[olist]
[*][b]Being a platformer[/b]: as a huge 2D and 3D platformer fan I must admit that the controls here are extremely tight, just the way I like them. If you loved the momentum-based movement in newest Raymans, Speedrunners and Cave Story, you will feel right at home here.
[*][b]Having a fitting graphical style[/b]: I'm not all that much into pixel graphics, I'd always choose drawn art over 10x10 chunks - assuming they both have good animations, because not having these makes your game unplayable. However in Downwell the graphical simplicity is a part of gameplay design - the game has only three colors, and they all mean something different. Also the animations are really great.
[*][b]Being procedural[/b]: As much as I prefer handmade levels, the "always different" aspect is crucial here as the game has literally no story at all and boy, it's been programmed really well. The game mechanics are simple, so the game needs constant changes in order to keep being fresh. Just like f.e. Binding of Isaac.
[/olist]

However there are also some minor issues: FPS drop when invincible (I feel like it has been programmed that way but it's not good at all) and no DirectInput support - if your pad doesn't support XInput, you'll need x360ce (or InputMapper in my case).

Overall it's a great game, definitely worth the full (3$) price.

18841254.review:
I'm pretty sure you can make a retro platformer out of literally any concept. Only the best games fully marry their concept to their gameplay, however. Downwell has you as an adorably animated little dude plunging to the bottom of a mysterious and randomly-generated well, armed only with his gunboots. Yes, those are boots that shoot things, which means Downwell almost plays more like a vertical shooter than a platformer. The well is full of enemies you can stomp Goomba-style or blast with your boots, though each one behaves a little differently. Red enemies can't be stomped, and a few white enemies can't be shot. So, as you're weaving your way past the strange, forgotten ledges of the well, you really need to be focused on what you're fighting and how to fight it.

Enemies leave behind gems that can be spent at stores to regain health or get more shots. Additionally, you can find weapon capsules that give your gunboots a new shot pattern AND a small health or ammo bonus. These add up over time to help grow your character; every 4 points of health you collect while at max HP extends your max HP by 1, and your shots help slow your descent and make it easier to deal with tougher enemies. Hard-hitting weapons like the shotgun and laser also use huge chunks of ammo at a time, so at the beginning of the game you might only have two shots before stomping or landing to reload, but by the end you might have 4 or 5 at a time. Additionally, after each of the game's 12 levels you can pick an upgrade from a random set of three, and these REALLY have a big effect on your playstyle. They can grant ammo from collecting gems, additional attacks from breaking blocks, a drone buddy that works like an Option from Gradius, rocket jumps, jetpacks, and more. Picking smart upgrades makes a big difference, especially when facing the boss at the end of the game.

The 12 levels are split into four thematic areas, each with its own unique challenges. I won't spoil what they are, but the latter two areas have new mechanics that prove quite challenging and require you to adapt quickly. And that's what's really going to determine how much you enjoy Downwell, your ability to manage chaos. Everything is rendered in loving detail, so at any given time there are monsters attacking you, shots flying, gems bouncing, shell casings tumbling, and more going on on the screen. Once you start to master the game you can rack up some amazing combos by ping-ponging from enemy to enemy without touching the floor, for which the game will reward you richly. There are new character styles and color palettes to unlock via your total gemcount, and a hard mode with new enemies and challenges once you beat the base game. Any fan of platformers or roguelite games will find a lot to love about Downwell, and I guarantee you'll be spending more time than you'd ever expect to mastering its clever moves.

What Is Downwell?
Intro:
Downwell is a game published by Devolver Digital about a man who, while out on a stroll, trajically falls down a well. While down the well you must make your way farther down by jumping on enemies heads, and shooting them with your gun… shoes… YES! That’s right, gun shoes, they simultaneously kill enemies and propel you upward to make sweet combos. All along the way picking up gems, alternate guns, and upgrades to make you, and your gun shoes even more suitable for your traitorous terrain. Speaking of terrain every time you start the game, the levels are procedurally generated giving you and your trusty shoes a new challenge to overcome. The random levels plus the fast paced gameplay give this game a “one more time” effect making it incredibly addictive. Not to mention that there are with 7+ weapon types, and 9+ upgrades, this game can really…… bring the oomph. Alternatively for more oomph at the end of every life you are given an upgrade bar which when fills up can give you either a new style, or color palate.  Oooh Look at the pretty colors.
Conclusion:
Clocking in at $2 Dollars 99, 1 Pound 99, or 2,99 Euros this game is definitely is worth your time if you are hungry for an action based roguelike.

18758598.review:
This game is one of the textbook examples how, even in the middle of today's massive AAA-title driven 45h open world madness, one core gameplay feature can still carry the whole game and make it truly brilliant, when just executed the right way. This game is a testament to the phrase "less is more", having restrictions, keeping the design simple, clean and tight. 

Also one of the rare games that actually really benefits from procedural level design. The dev haven't just included that feature in sake of being in the "procedural hype train". And why it works then? Permadeath and fast gameplay loop (a bit like in Rogue Legacy), also score hunt, if that's your cup of tea. The game still reaks of huge emphasis on skill driven gameplay, despite of little randomity here and there (also like in Rogue Legacy, and I do NOT mean this copies RL, just pointing it out as a reference).

If you read this far, I'm sure it should be clear now whether to buy this or not. Gonna install this one on my arcade/emulator machine too (plays so well with a stick) - the true arcade spirit is strong in this one!

18756174.review: My new favorite game. Such tight gameplay, similar in feel to a Vlambeer game like Nuclear Throne or Luftrausers. Awesome.

18753432.review:
I never write reviews here and I know I'm a little too late to the party but I just gotta confirm what basically everybody else is already preaching: Downwell is a brilliantly crafted gem (pardon the pun).

This game ticks all the boxes that a carefully refined platformer should:
- Easy to learn, hard to master
- More concerned about proper visual feedback for each and every event than shiny graphics
- Great sense of flow that is further encouraged by its combo system
- Procedurally generated content which is set up in a way that the game always sticks true to its core design (both mechanics and levels)
- Weapons, Upgrades, and playstyles are interesting to try out and all come with their own advantages and repercussions
- Excellent sense of space with a fresh approach to classic platforming mechanics (Endless Faller as the creator calls it)

I could go on and on about how much I love this game. While only a very small number of indie efforts from Japan really make it over the various ponds, this right here is a shimmer of hope that there are more little masterstrokes like this out there and that more publishers like Devolver will make the effort to seek them out and make them known to a wider audience.

Even Downwell has room for tweaks, sure... World 2 seems to be the hardest to me, or maybe the most unfair because the enemy types are just so damn unpredictable (how I hate those huge burning skulls) and Levitation Mode should maybe just be called Easy Mode but every minute I spent with the game made me more and more aware of how much attention to detail and loving craft went into its design.

Should you break your combo chain because you seriously lack some cash? What weapon suits your playstyle best? Why the hell is that balloon shaped like a heart but never gives you any love?

Before really getting into Hard Mode I have to take a break for a few days though - this game will deliver some of the most frantic 10-15 minutes of your gameplaying career.

Keep on munching those corpses!


(Looking forward to playing your next game, もっぴん様)

18702018.review:
[h1][i][b]Downwell[/b][/i] combines the never-ending sense of discovery of [i][b]The Binding of Isaac Rebirth[/b][/i], the randomness arcade perfection of [i][b]Super Crate Box[/b][/i] and the extreme level of polish seen in Nintendo EAD most beloved creations with all the awesomeness and frantic intensity of Sega’s 90s classics. In the best Japanese game created in the last 30 years, that is as influential as the first [i][b]Super Mario Bros[/b][/i][/h1]

When Shigeru Miyamoto designed the original [i]Super Mario Bros[/i] in 1985, there was a true intentionality behind it of disrupting every single rule and convention to the date. The key to understand the design philosophy behind Super Mario Bros is the turtle in level 3-1. Until [i]Super Mario Bros[/i] all in the Japanese games was about scoring, creating a small and enclosed world where every single element had a purpose.

But Shigeru Miyamoto realized that he wanted to evolve the games to much more complex universes. Worlds not being restricted to a single screen. So for him, the scoring wasn’t the primal focus anymore, being only a second layer in its design philosophy.

With [i]Super Mario Bros[/i], Shigeru Miyamoto had in his hands a perfect and memorable game for scoring purposes, an unforgettable arcade experience. But he didn't feel in the mood for creating games with restricted rules while he was working at the same time in its design for the ambitious universe of [i]Zelda[/i]. So, he intentionally put a turtle in the level 3-1 that serves to achieve an infinite score, like a punk act of insurgency. A turtle that was destined to change the videogame history.

And then, after 30 years of this murder of the classic arcade committed by Miyamoto, comes [i]Downwell[/i]. That it’s not only a game so well constructed and that it’s so joyful to play as [i]Super Mario Bros[/i], evoking the same sense of magic seen in Miyamoto’s masterful creation. But that it’s also a game that like [i]Super Mario Bros[/i] 30 years before, tries to revolutionize the Japanese industry turning it around every misconception and previous rule. In a certain manner, [i]Downwell[/i] can be seen as an intent to reverting all the things that the influence of [i]Super Mario Bros[/i] changed in videogame history. It’s infused with he same punk spirit of trying to break every known rule, the same spirit that we can see in the level 3-1 of [i]Super Mario Bros[/i].

The game starts as a declaration of intent from part of its creators, saying to us that they know Nintendo history, that they love Nintendo EAD creations, but they also know that previously to the success of Miyamoto, Gunpei Yokoi was a fundamental figure to understand the history of videogames. The minimal color palette used in [i]Downwell[/i] has the same philosophy that can be seen in the creation of the original Game Boy, when Yokoi was obsessed with the idea of suggesting things and evoking a broad range of sensations, via the use of a limited number of colors to suggesting abstract shapes that the player needs to reconstruct in his imagination.

If [i]Super Mario Bros[/i] was all about horizontality, [i]Downwell[/i] centers its design in the idea of verticality. By looking at the original [i]Kid Icarus[/i], one of the most iconic Gunpei Yokoi’s creations. And the references to Gunpei Yokoi don’t stop there, as in the first level we can see enemies that resemble the original Metroids. But wen can also meet turtles that we can’t shoot, needing to jump over them. As if the developers want to say that they prefer a pre-Miyamoto world when the scoring was the most important thing and that they enjoy enclosed and simplistic worlds. But at the same time they also feel an enormous respect for the Miyamoto’s creations.

But with [i]Downwell[/i] being a love letter to Nintendo and Gunpei Yokoi’s creations, the game also has a mesmerizing sense of action and a frantic intensity in its shooting parts that it’s on par with Sega’s mid-90s greatest classics. Sometimes, playing [i]Downwell[/i] you can feel this particular Nintendo magic, of a game in which every design concept fits perfectly creating a captivating flow. But also this sense of enjoyment and almost hypnotic trance that you could feel the first time when you played [i]Sonic the Hedgehog[/i]. Or some of the most greatest Megadrive’s action titles created by emblematic studios like Treasure or the Konami team responsible of [i]Contra Hard Corps[/i].

This Sega’s greatest classics feeling is emphasized with a brilliant synthetized soundtrack with some dissonant and noisy fragments that resembles Motohiro Kawashima’s compositions for [i]Streets of Rage 3[/i].

And if [i]Downwell[/i] looks at Gunpei Yokoi as a game designer, it also looks at Yokoi as the man making cheerful toys. Trying to be not only as fun as a toy, but also as easy to learn and enjoy as a toy. With a masterful control scheme designed with only 3 buttons in mind. Adding another disruptive note respect to [i]Super Mario Bros[/i]. Because in Mario, with the act of jumping we ascend vertically. So it’s necessary to keep pressed the button. But in [i]Downwell[/i] we’re most of the time failing, taking the brilliant decision of using the same button for jump and shooting purposes. [i]Downwell[/i] has a control scheme so smart and intuitive, so precise and exquisite, that playing it becomes an unforgettable experience. One of these rare games that you can’t stop playing.

And then it comes all of its masterful lessons in game design. It’s incredible how the creators have inserted so many variables in such a simple concept. Every enemy adds a new challenge and needs a different approach. Every weapon or item obtained in a random basis that looks at [i]Super Crate Box[/i], can completely modify the gameplay structure. You will never cease of discovering new weapons, new subtle and small details inserted in the structure of its levels, new tricks to improve your score. And the random nature of the game only increases this sensation of master class in game design. No matter its random structure, every single run in [i]Downwell[/i] is perfectly crafted. Every element in its gameplay fits so well that you could not believe it until you play it.

[i]Cave Story[/i] and [i]La Mulana[/i] were two Japanese masterpieces, extracting its greatness from looking at past titles and creating gaming concepts by imitating the classics. But I think that [i]Downwell[/i] is a leap forward from past Japanese indie games. Because it not only looks at an amazing period in Japanese videogame history, but also looks at the contemporary occidental scene. Taking its influences from creators and studios like Vlambeer or Edmund McMillen. Resulting in a title that is destined to lead the actual Japanese scene, being its main referent. And a game that will be venerated for future indie creators to come.

[i]Downwell[/i] has become the most influential and industry-changer release coming from Devolver Digital since [i]Hotline Miami[/i].


[i]( The writer of this review is not an English native. So you should expect occasional grammar errors. I apologize in advance. )[/i]

18690666.review:
About 4 hours in, and I feel like I've seen most of what this game has to offer. Whether or not that's a good thing depends on you, but for me the hook of this game isn't getting ot the end (though that's a part of it), its the god-like feeling you get when you reach your next max combo and the feeling of progression in unlocking new styles and pallets. If you're the kind of gamer that loves score-attack type games, mixed with some platforming, this is most definately for you. 

Basically, if you have even the slightest inclination, just try it.  It's the price of a sandwich.


However, I do have some issues/suggestions for the developer. 

1) Variety: It takes about one hour to encounter/use all shop items/upgrades/guns, which I think is a problem. I understand that one can't expect a BOI or Nucear Throne level of variety form a 3 dollar game, but I think this is still an issue that the developer should maybe focus on for future dlcs/updates.

2) Unlockables: More stlyes? Custom Palletes? Please? I would love more complex styles that have real trade-offs. This is all fodder for future dlc, which I would buy in a heartbeat.

3) Screen space: super-super nitpicky, but the borders don't fit the whole screen when in fullscreen. I respect the size of the game itslef, but the presence of ugly black bars on either side of the border art really urks me off.  I would really love for this to be fixed in the future.

All-in-all, it's a great lunch-break rogue-lite with some minor issues.

18689533.review:
Simply Downwell is a roguelike descent game but that really doesn’t paint this game as illustratively as I would like.  I would rather describe this games as the vertical corridor sections in Metroid but you can only go down and it all happens very fast.

The game isn’t exactly the best looking game out there but a few minutes into your first play through it is abundantly clear that there is something to this retro inspired action game. As you descend the well stage by stage you are assisted by a pair of gun boots you are wearing (God knows why). These are useful firstly to kill enemies but also to help keep you afloat. As you progress through the game you can upgrade you boots contra style by picking up power ups and the weapons are all different enough that you will soon find your favourites. When I first started playing I spent most of the time shooting almost constantly as I fell and looking for the most powerful weapon but pretty soon you realise this isn’t the best tactic. Firstly because shooting also breaks blocks which you need to land on. Without platforms to land you might land on an enemy or miss a shop neither of which is a desirable outcome. The other important thing about landing is landing recharges your boots and this is needed to progress through the game. You eventually find a confident but thorough pace through the game… well until you get to stage 3 where everything runs under a time limit anyway. 

The game obviously draws a fair amount of visual comparison from the Metroid series. While it obviously has a Spectrum look to it the vertical “corridors” scream Metroid as do the enemies that look like Metroids along with the other variety of Metroid type creatures that inhabit the well. 

There are no continues in the game that spreads over 5 stages each split up into 3 sections and upon death you find yourself back up at the top of the well. At the end of each sub stage you are given a choice of upgrades ranging from a jet pack that slows your descent, an ability that shoots bullets upwards when you collect gems, a knife and fork that lets you eat enemies to replenish health and a drone that mimics your bullets. 

All powerups and shops are in side rooms protected by time freezing barriers. This gives you time to recuperate amongst all the craziness. 

As you play and gain gems a number of different styles and palettes are unlocked. Palettes simply change the visual look of the game. Whilst a fun little distraction the original colours are by far the best and I never really found myself inclined to use any others. The other unlockables are in the form of styles. These slightly alter the gameplay such as removing shops in favour of weapon upgrades or giving you more health at the expense of power up choices. While these are a distraction I found myself usually going back to the standard style.

Downwell is hard, but it is incredibly addictive and I found myself playing it again and again and again. At only £1.99 or your regional equivalent this really is one of the best game to money ratio games you will buy this year. Downwell is fantastic and I really cannot recommend it highly enough… more please.

For our full video review please follow the link: http://www.thegametutor.co.uk/videos/game-tutor-grades/151026_game-tutor-grades-downwell

18642163.review:
Downwell is a vertical shooter... upside down. With standard roguelite features and a stage based item system (and an almost Contra-esque Weapon system). It's strangly addicting and compelling - each run lasts a very short period of time, but I sat down and burned an hour in the first sitting. 

Let's break it down though:

Pros:
- Sharp contrasts make the screen easily readible despite only utilizing essentially 3 colors in the default color scheme (Red, Black, White)
- Nice difficulty curve and pacing - the levels change at a frequency that keeps one area from getting stagnant within a run.
- Lots of variety to weapons/power ups/etc. - while it's not Binding of Isaac levels, even after a few hours in you'll run in to situations of "oh, I haven't seen that before!"

Cons:
- Can get repetative, you are just falling down a well after all.
- 4:3 with the backgrounds (so you still have black bars, even with the backgrounds)
- Has a Virtual Boy Skin (burn it with fire! - this is my review, I'll list that as a con if I want! - the rest are fine though)

It can get chaotic at times, but for less than the cost of a good sandwich, you can have a few hours of fun? sounds like a great deal to me. I can see myself sinking a few more hours in this, it's well designed, if short.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=539897575

18638496.review:
This game is immensely satisfying and I continually want to come back to it. It is easy to understand, and you learn how to handle different situations by being thrown into them. 
There's enough sense of progression in unlocking pallettes (which only requires time, not skill) and seeing new areas. You want to get better. You're encouraged to try different styles of play, see which suits you best.
It's satisfying to play and even more satisfying to play well. You get comfortable with the rules, then are constantly getting into situations you can't prepare for. And that's good.

I do have some medium-sized complaints: I continue to struggle with precise movement needed for combos, but perhaps I simply need more practice. Every so often an enemy's hitbox will surprise me, damaging me when I expected to bounce, or vice versa. 
And the fourth area is a rather sudden change of expectations, and honestly seems a bit lazy (the Jetpack upgrade is a must). Indeed, after the second area, there's really only one way of playing that will let you survive.

But it's much easier to come up with gripes than it is to put to words my enjoyment. I do keep coming back - I can't believe I've spent this much time on this game already. It's cheap and fun and clearly made by someone who cares!

Despite being a game about falling down a hole with shoes that shoot bullets, Downwell is constantly challenging your spatial awareness and platforming execution with things that will follow you from up above you and from your sides. 18635539.review:
You're in free-fall down apparently the world's deepest well, and everything wants to kill you. Your controls are Left, Right, and Shoot (which can also be used for limited hovering). For each stage you survive you get a free perk, and you'll frequently have to swap out your weapon for others in the form of pickups that may or may not be well suited to the situation, as each time you do so you'll recover some health or increase your clip size. None of the weapons are outright terrible though, which is a plus.

Less getting hit means more opportunities for maximum health or clip extensions, which you're gonna need to survive all the nonsense to come. Apart from shooting enemies, you can also bounce off of some of them, and even get huge bounce combos going once you're more familiar with the game. I really like it, getting a good flow going and bouncing off of everything feels great.

It's available here and on iOS for about the same price, but although it's the perfect sort of bite-sized game to take on the go, I'd recommend it on PC or something with a decent controller, as it's a bit twitchy for touch controls, even with just 3 buttons. Especially if you're ever going to even think about tackling hard mode.

18625025.review:
Downwell is a 2d, retro style, rogue-lite, action platformer, with noticeable inspirations from Vlambeer. The game conceptually plays like the offspring of Super House of Dead Ninjas and Luftrausers; a game about fluidity, speed, reflexes and screenshake. Lots of screen shake.

Your goal is to perpetually move downwards, through a procedurally generated well, killing or avoiding enemies, collecting gems and weapon upgrades, before making it to the end of the stage. At the end of each stage, you are rewarded with a choice of perks/abilities; think Nuclear Throne.

The main joy in this game comes from the superbly fluid controls, allowing for instinctive, twitch platforming. All good platformers are defined by their movement mechanics, and this game has really nailed it. Couple this with the game's brilliantly nostalgic art style and soundtrack, and you have a real indie gem.

Downwell may not be everyones cup of tea, but for fans of the genre, this is an amazing game, at a steal of a price.

18606401.review:
This game is fantastic to play in bursts.  It's a quick, snappy game which you can literally load up and go in a couple of minutes.  The graphics, while two bit, still convey the needed information.

Each run begins with a descent, and ends with a descent.  It's a constant downward movement, and unless you're patient with your gunplay, you'll miss gun upgrades, which will either heal you or increase ammo, as well as change the bullet style.  Each bullet style offers different things, and you will be quick to latch onto a favorite.  There are also the occasional shop, letting you trade in gems earned for provisions and ammo.

Going deeper into the run, and as you play more with the particular bullet styles, you start to develop habits.  Machine gun is the best for some jump combos, which the game rewards for racking up several kills without so much as touching the normal ground.  Laser is for the ridiculously power hungry who just want to annihilate everything in their path, and it's glorious to do so.

The gun styles can also compliment the styles of play as well.  A floaty style with machine gun results in a heap of combos, while the more patient with lasers will appreciate the tanky approach of the boulder style.  This kind of play results in waiting for a shop to fly by, or to wait for reverse engineering so you can collect upgrades without fear of changing.

The end level upgrades also provide a nice incentive to finish, and some will synergize well with particular shots.  The easy to run out Shotgun and Laser bullets will appreciate the extra air time the Safety Jetboots offer once they're depleted.  Most styles will synergize with the upgrades as well, except for Handstand.

The game offers a lot of variety in terms of areas.  And each of them demand their own playstyle.  The first area is a sort of tutorial area, to let you get used to the mechanics of the game.  Later on, they start throwing curveballs until the point where there is little ground to land on safely.

All of this can be your's for three goddamn bucks.  Pick it up and start falling.

So, you're down here, unconvinced about whether to buy Downwell. Unconvinced that Downwell's shockingly fantastic gameplay recommended by several video game review publications at the price of three American dollars (or equivalent) is worth it.

Let me tell you something:

You're going to make bad decisions on the video games you purchase sometimes, but that's okay.

You're going to look at something everyone enjoys, and listen to their recommendations to purchase that something. And you will purchase that something, and you will realize that it's not as great as you were expecting it to be. And slowly, you will eat yourself inside out over that purchase. Three months into the future, while you're sitting at a Subway eating a terrible sandwich, you will think: "Boy, that game sure did not meet my lofty standards". A year into the future, when you're looking at the classifieds online for a job, you'll think "Boy, that game did not take the prerequisite amount of time that I consider to be a good game." Five years into the future, when you're getting married, looking into the eyes of your significant other as the pastor reads the words that lead up to the kiss that seals your relationship in the eyes of your family, your God, and the law, you will think: "Seriously, what were the developers thinking? Am I on a planet of aliens or something? Why can't I find the video game that I like?" 

And you will throw off your covers in the night, fall down the stairs onto your face, screaming "WHY IS VIDEO GAMES BAD? WHY CAN'T VIDEO GAMES GOOD? WHY WHY WHY?" before you are carted off to the hospital, babbling about how the game that other people like isn't something you like.

All I'm saying is, you gotta take a chance. You just gotta.

Or wait for a fucking Steam sale, you cheapskate. Just buy Downwell, it's good.

18595063.review:
[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kb_aXGJJuPI]I also did a YouTube video on this game.[/url]

I knew almost nothing of Downwell when I saw some footage of it and decided to pick it up on a whim and I'm so glad I did! This is an 8-bit style Rogue-like vertical shooter that is very simple in its core design, but very deep in how you can approach it and is rock hard.

Originally a mobile game (though the PC version is quite good quality), there are only three concepts in this game, moving side to side jumping and shooting. Your goal is to reach the bottom of each level, avoiding or taking out as many enemies as you can, with the goal of reaching the last level and beating the boss. Difficulty ramps up very quickly though so getting to the final boss will be no small feat and will require lots of replays. You will acquire and purchase various upgrades along the way but as this is a Rogue-like, they will only stay with you until you die and then you have to start over again with nothing. There is a persistent progression mechanic that unlocks different colour palettes and a few rule modifications to mix up the challenge.

Sessions tend to last for only a few minutes each and the quick nature of the game play and the feeling of improvement through iteration really gives this that "Just one more run!" feeling. You'll find yourself sitting down to kill a few minutes, only to find out an hour blinked by without you noticing. As hard as the game is, I never found myself getting frustrated or angry, even though I died repeatedly. A good Rogue-like should be tough but also feel fair and responsive and Downwell absolutely does. The controls are sharp and tight and when you die, it never feels like it was because the game cheated you.

Downwell is presented in a very faithful NES 8-bit style. It runs at a constant 60fps and it looks and sounds like it could be running on an NES. The music and sound effects and are very crunchy with a lot of punch to them and compliment the game play very well. I played this on my laptop with Intel graphics as well as my main gaming rig and it ran fine on both. I suspect this will run on a potato.

The best part is that this is only $3! This would be a steal to me at 5 times the price and I can't recommend it enough from a value perspective. Even if you aren't sure you'll like it, there's practically nothing to lose. If you're a fan of Rogue-like mechanics and/or arcade, lightning-fast mechanics, get this, seriously. I'm having a blast and will likely put many more hours into it. As someone who only enjoys specific types of Rogue-likes, this one has me hooked.

18594230.review:
I'm a fan of the belief that a game can best be judged based on its playtime value vs. its cost. In general, I like getting 1 hour per dollar spent on games. For Downwell, that'd equate to three hours of playtime.

While I presently haven't reached that point yet, I expect I'll be getting more than my money's worth out of this game, and so do recommend it overall. That said, no game is perfect, so if you'd like to get into the nitty-gritty of the game, keep reading.

Like many Roguelikes, Downwell has an itemization system and a bit of a character development system, along with varying characters known as "Styles". The most intriguing of these systems is the itemization one. While most other Roguelikes tend to have some overlap between their item pools (or only pull from one pool) (i.e., Risk of Rain, Binding of Isaac, etc.) Downwell has a separate item pool for its shops, caves (side areas that grant a weapon and/or health/ammo), and end-of-level rewards. That is to say, you cannot buy a weapon or passive upgrade from a shop, nor can you obtain shop-upgrades when you complete a level. This introduces a fairly restrictive system overall for character development and, I believe, cuts into the game's overall longevity, as you run into the same types of items in the same places, rather than mixing things up and keeping it random.

The items themselves are mostly good, however Downwell fits right into the mold of Roguelikes in having a few items that are simply crap. Think Spike Strips from RoR, or The Poop in BoI. 

As far as gameplay goes, Downwell is very fast-paced, which is a huge plus for me but may not be appealling to others. Between combos, precision jumping, the Gunboots, and using all of these things at once, a player can (and will need to) be quite active in the game. Unfortunately, some of the hitboxes are in my opinion somewhat wonky, for lack of a better word. Sometimes I'll be able to kill an enemy by hitting them diagonally, other times I'll take damage. Also, there is no enemy/player overlap prevention, meaning that enemies can stack on top of each other (leading to very confusing situations; for instance, an enemy which can only be killed with the Gunboots may be ontop of an enemy invulnerable to Gunboots) and that enemies can stack on top of YOU (leading to situations in which you may take more damage than you should because that one flying enemy followed you around during your retreat). In this vein, the collision of the Gunboots blasts is also a little funky. You cannot shoot enemies that are slightly overlapping you, leaving you very vulnerable in those situations, and many Gunboots weapon types are not especially accurate (even with the accuracy upgrade). Downwell is heavily precision-oriented, but given how much irregularity there is in collision detection for entities/bullets, the required precision of Downwell often becomes a nuisance. Hopefully this can be fixed/adjusted overtime with patches.

Overall, I recommend and enjoy Downwell and look forward to playing it more. I can easily see myself investing 20-40 hours into this game, which, for a $3 price tag, is a steal.

18588898.review:
[b]Downwell[/b] is a roguelite game with a classic arcade feel. Armed with gunboots, your character always is going down, shooting and stomping enemies in an almost non-stop pace. All levels are procedurally generated, ensuring a high replay value, and once you’re dead, you can’t continue. 

Costing only [b]US$ 3[/b], Downwell is an excellent choice if you’re looking for a cheap game with high polish that’ll provide lots of fun. Be warned, though, that this game is really challenging. That’s no big deal actually, because the gameplay is [b]addictive[/b] and is [b]very satisfying[/b] to perform combos (jumping from enemy to enemy consecutively). 

Despite a lot of players comparing this game with Spelunky, I think [b]Super House of Dead Ninjas[/b] would be a fairer comparison. Like that game, Downwell is crazily fast and will put you on the edge, testing your reflexes and skill, all the time. 

[h1]You might like this game if:[/h1]
*You’re looking for the perfect coffee break game, with short and fun playthroughs
*You don’t mind starting over and over (you’ll die a lot)
*You want an “easy to learn / hard to master” experience
*You enjoy compete for scores and like challenging yourself to get better

[h1]You might NOT like this game if:[/h1]
*High difficulty and permadeath turns you off
*You’re expecting the same variety as The Binding of Isaac. This is a simple game
*You prefer tactical gameplay over non-stop action 
*Lots of unlockables are a must. It’s possible to unlock everything in a few hours

18584679.review:
What can I say about Downwell that hasn't already been said? It's a roguelike? (Or is it rogue-lite? I can never remember the difference) We already know that. That its controls are tight and responsive in just the right way? That despite the increasing horrors you encounter down the well, you want to keep going to see what happens next? All of that's been said before, by people more articulate than I.

Well... one thing that doesn't seem to be said too much is that Downwell is hard, punishing even, but at the same time fair. You're going to die. You're going to die often. And yet, at no point does it feel like the game is punishing you for anything other than your own mistakes. At no point does it feel like the game is cheating, or punishing you for mistakes *it* made.

And that's part of what makes the game so compelling. It's easy to dismiss J. Random 12-Year-Old when he tells you to "lern2play, nub", but it's a lot harder to dismiss the cry of "git gud" when it's coming from inside your own brain.

Downwell will make you swear. It'll make you rage, even. And then you'll jump right back into the game because dammit, you can't stop now, not before you've made up for that screwup you just done did.

The only way is down, you are only equipped with boots that fire downwards. A very simple gimmick, but wait... There are enemies and they are pretty annoying, especially those bats! 18574966.review:
Fast paced, challenging, & fun!  Downwell is one of those games that you will sit down to play for 5 minutes & then all of a sudden it's been over an hour.

PROS
-Solid Controls
-Buy & Find Upgrades
-Unique, Fun & Challenging
-Randomized Levels
-Unlockables

CONS
-High Difficulty

The game is all about going down the well.   You could compare it to Binding of Isaac or Spelunky in that both games go deeper & deeper underground & as you get deeper the game's difficulty goes up!  You also will probably die a lot.  

GAMEPLAY

You will be falling a lot but you will need to hone your senses so you don't fall too fast or miss the all important upgrades along the way.  You could probably play this game with an Atari controller if you have one.  All you do is Move/Jump/Shoot & the latter is done all with one button.  Upgrades are always given once you finish a level but they can be found in Shops & Caves which are all guarded by a Time Warp Circles that freeze time as long as you're in it.  As you keep playing the game you earn points that give unlocks for new games but you can only equip one at a time.  These are fairly simple but can have both pisitive & negative effects such as increasing health while lowering your upgrade choices after each level.  

You collect GEMS as well which you spend at the shops that are usually at the beginning of each level.  As you progress shops get less & less common. They sell food & weapon upgrades.  If you are full health & eat food you gain 1/4 of an extra health point.  Once you get 4/4 you get +1 Overall Health.  This means you gotta not get hit in order to increase your health which is easier said than done.  Enemies are rampant & will group up against you if you let them.  You can also find ammo/gun/food upgrades in caves or at the end of a level.  It might be best to try to find everything you can because a gun upgrade can also give you food or an ammo upgrade along with it.  

RED = DANGER  If you get hit by a red enemy or part of the enemy that's RED you will take damage.  Red terrain also means there's a trap of some kind so you will need to keep your guard up while moving down the well.  You can safely jump on WHITE terrain & white parts of enemies. Whenever your feed touch the ground or an enemy your ammo gets replenished. So you could shoot a red to death, jump on a white then proceed to shoot another red.  If it's RED shoot it, if it's WHITE jump on it.  Some parts are a tad confusing, though.  Like a white skeleton throwing white bones & since you're white it's easy to lose track of yourself amidst all the chaos going on if there's a lot of enemies.  

OVERALL

Everything about this game is great!  It feels retro & brings forth that nostalgic feel if you're an old fogey gamer like me.  It even has cosmetic changes where you can make the game look like it's running on a Commadore 64, GameBoy or even Virtual Boy.  This is one of those games where death's mean progress so don't get discouraged if you die frequently.  For under $3 it's really good for the price as well.

18571489.review:
In short: Awesome game little game. Go on and buy it!

Downwell may look really simple, but actually packs quite a lot of gameplay for its price. The base game is as simple as it gets. Move left and right and press once to jump, and a second time to shoot down from your gunboots. Some platforms can be destroyed. Some platforms can be shot through. Most enemies are killed by jumping on them (except the red ones, shoot those instead). Collect crystals dropped by fallen enemies. Get to the bottom of the well without loosing all your hit points, or it's game over. Death comes quickly if you make too many mistakes.

What makes the game interesting are the weapons, the items and the powerups. Weapons are found in little caves off to the side of the well. Some are more powerful than others. I personally love the laser. Overpowered? Nah. :) Some caves contain shops where you can buy items to restore hit points or add more shots to your boots. Each well you complete rewards you with a choice of one out of three powerups, which stack up as you move from well to well. Some of them are really cool and combine in interesting ways. The challenge is to try and hold on to those powerups for as long as you can before you inevetably die and have to restart.

The controls are responsive (as is essential for this type of game). The graphics are very minimalistic and are likely to run on a toaster. The sprites are nicely animated. There are a few colour schemes you can unlock to change up the game's look.

I heartily recommend this game and will be playing it a lot more myself.

18571040.review:
One thing about that makes Downwell stand out from similar Procedural Death Labyrinths such as Spelunky or Nuclear Throne is that it's a lot easier to understand and takes less time to get the hang of and get good at. At the same time, it also encourages skillful high-level play with rewards for stringing together combos and competitive leaderboards. Unlockable game modes and palette swaps give you a reason to keep on trying even when you feel like you get stuck.

In short, Downwell is fun, addictive and cheap. I think you should give it a shot.

18570963.review:
Downwell does a lot of things right.  Starting with the visuals.  For a game whose active play area is a vertical shaft, they've done a great job as making the space outside the play area both both functional and attractive.  I don't have to wander far from my character to see my health or number of bullets available.  And the inclusion of various backgrounds to fill out the area is a nice touch.  I, for one, really enjoy the simple 3-color aesthetic (Luftrausers is similar, but contains a lot less contrast).  And the ability to swap the palette is great, especially for people who might be put off by the default one (which I am not, I love it.)

The sound design is great.  No action is ambiguous, and every sound effect feels natural.  The music is really good.  Too good, because I wish there was more of it (like Spelunky has a rotating list of tracks per area, I wish Downwell did, as well).

The controls are "tight" as one might say.  Very intuitive and responsive.

The enemies are varied enough to keep you on your toes.  You can't just chain-bounce everything, but you also can't just go in blindly firing off your gunboots.  The area variation is really good, too.  All the guns feel good, and are well balanced.  

Overall, it's a really solid game, that's lots of fun, and could get away with being sold at twice the price, so for $2.99 it's a no-brainer.  Pick this one up, and have blast!

Ten runs and I already got my money's worth. I don't yet know if it will prove to have the staying power of a Spelunky or a Binding of Isaac (I mean, it won't, but maybe close, dunno!), but look at whatever my playtime is for an indicator of that. And for $3, this game is more than worth the price if you like roguelites/roguelikelikes. It's been a while since I played something that was simply so much visceral fun condensed into such a small but elegant package.

It's a platformer sort of roguelite, only, as you can see, you platform downward, with various upgrades for your gunboots laying around and a Nuclear Throne style choice of upgrades when you complete a level. It is very action-packed and fastpaced... sort of. There are a lot of times where you are very capable of taking things slow and scoping things out, but once you accidentally trigger a bat that flies down at you, well, you can't shoot up generally, so all hell immediately breaks loose. And gets you in more fun-as-all-hell trouble.

It's very fun.

UPDATE: I just got to the boss accidentally and unexpectedly, with a large degree of luck, while experimenting with a combo-focused, completely not cautious playstyle and build, at a bit over 5 hours in. And lost - I think barely.

Saw this as a new Steam game when it was released day one. The description of the game sounded interesting and was craving for an arcade fix. The thing that made the game truly shine is it's frantic way of beating levels. You're going down a well with gunboots. Smashing and shooting your way through bricks and scoring gems. Also, the levels are procedurally generated so of course you will see the layout of the level of bricks, powerups, and enemies placed at random parts of the well when playing through each level. So far the game has a nice replay value if you did include the randomization of level generation and highscore leaderboards.

The price is a downright steal for such a unique arcade game and this being a debut of 23-year-old Ojiro Fumoto is a rather impressive game for such an awesome price. I beg of you dev if you can improve this awesome formula you have concocted I would pay you a significant amount of money. If any of you have not picked it up yet I suggest you do so now. While new to the game and only a couple of hours in I feel as though this little GEM ( I'm so sorry ) is worth talking about.
TL;DR version:
-Tons of nifty nostalgic unlocks.
-Great dedication to the theme of an arcade quarter muncher / handheld platformer from the late 80's/early 90's.
-Extremely fast and rewarding gameplay.
-Lots of character in a little package.
-Super addictive
(Also the word "M U N C H E R" is censored by steam?!
0.o Wut?)

Downwell is as the description calls it: "A curious game".
Taking Rogue-like elements and mashing them into a precision, skill based "platformer" is a really neat idea. One of which results in very addictive gameplay.

In the vain of Super House of Dead Ninja's; the game is given to you in bite sized chunks. Testing you in on-the-fly problem solving through its very fast bouncing mechanic. Which is extremely rewarding. Granting the player bonus gems ( currency/points ), health boosts and just an awesome feeling of accomplishment.
I won't bother going to far into to detail as the game is fairly self explanatory based on the trailer video within the store front. I will say that while very easy to pick up, it is an extremely skill based and deep game. One that offers a very nice skill curve that I myself am still exploring.

Much like S.H.o.D.N/ Luftrausers; the game is brimming with highly addictive replayablity for arcade and rogue-like junkies.
Also: It's fucking $2.99. Skip buying an energy drink or pack of gum and pick it up.

18543787.review:
"Woof!"
"What's that, Jean?"
"Woof woof woof!"
"Immy fell down the well?!"
"Woof!"

Joking aside, Downwell is a really good retro-styled game that actually earns its retro styling by playing like old action games used to - brutally difficult, but in a more or less fair way, such that once you've learned what to do, enemies that killed you easily before will be easy to take out without worries. It also uses procedural generation nicely, making each run somewhat different so that it's not a matter of memorization, while avoiding the pitfalls of boring or obnoxious auto-generated content - I didn't run into any in the three hours I've spent with the game.

Much like old action games, it's also not all that long - only 12 short levels and then a boss fight - but it's rather heavy on replay value with all of the times you'll die before making progress. There's also a hard mode you can unlock once you've beaten the final boss once, which makes shops more expensive and fills the levels with more enemies, including a new variety or two on each set of levels. Especially considering how inexpensive it is, I recommend Downwell to anyone who liked the simpler action games of the early console eras, or people who like "roguelike-like" action games in general.

EDIT: I beat the game and unlocked hard mode so I figured I'd edit its description into my review.

I find the game delivers for its price point and is a must pick up if you're into rogue-like games and 2D shooters.

18533520.review:
Downwell is a vertical action platformer rogue-like (think spelunky) where you delve into the depths until you beat the game. While descending, you'll encounter enemies which can only be killed by stomping them or killing by them with your pair of gunboots. You'll also discover various guns which may contain extra charges for your afformentioned gunboots or extra health, shops which sell health and extra charges and also powers after each level section. It has a really simple and addictive premise that's a lot of fun.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
- It's really cheap, I mean $2.99 come on now
- Great rogue-like feel consisting of easy to learn, hard to master gameplay
- Tight controls you can move left or right, jump and shoot. If any error was made platforming it always your fault
- Great simple pixel art style consisting of 3 colours black white and red (main theme)
- Great audio and music from composers of Spelunky and Nuclear Throne fame
- Scratches that 'one more try' itch because of it's combo and depth delving mechanics
- Influenced by MossMouth's Spelunky and Vlambeer's Nuclear Throne and that's great
- It's a difficult game if you don't understand the gunboots mechanic don't spam but feather (buffer) your shots and stomp to recharge

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Slight slowdown when you get hit, it doesn't affect the game but it might

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
An extemely fun and addictive vertical action platformer rogue-like with only 1 minor problem. The challenges you on how well understand its mechanics and leaves the execution up to you. You're low on health, have an strong gunboot equipped, do you exchange [x] weapon for +1 health or do you weather the storm keeping your pair until you reach a shop where you can buy health. It's an amazing game and if I may quote a certain space fighter this game is about "falling with style".
