18523786.review:
Ich schreibe für gewöhnlich keine Reviews, aber bei diesem Spiel hier muss ich es einfach machen.

Mit diesem Spiel geht es bergab. Höhöhöhö (Ja, der war schlecht, weiß ich selbst :/)
Das Spiel sieht einfach aus, ist aber doch hinterhältig. Das Spiel animiert einen, schnell runter in das nächste Level zu kommen, was man aber nicht unbedingt tun sollte. Wenn man zu schnell ist, verpasst man Upgrade (zu diesen komme ich später), Shops und (wenn man unbedingt alle sammel will) Edelsteine. Hier heißt die Devise: "Vorsichtig und Sicher.

Die Figur beginnt mit der normalen Waffe und 4 Trefferpunkten.

1. *Upgrades*

Es gibt (soweit wi ich gespielt habe) 2 Arten von Upgrades. Die Passiven (die auf die Spielfigur bezogen sind) und Aktive (welche auf die Waffe der Figur bezogen sind).

1.1 *Passiv*

Wenn man einen Level-Abschnitt "durchgefallen" ist, kann man sich ein Upgrade von 3 (oder auch mehr, wenn man das Upgrade danach dann hat) aussuchen, diese können sowohl mehr Leben geben, können aber auch unterstützen indem dich ein Droide begeitet, oder du Leichen zum Explodieren bringst, wenn du auf sie schießt.
Zu erwähnen wäre noch, dass man die passiven Upgades behält, wenn man ein neues erspielt.

1.2 *Aktiv*

Aktive Upgrades beziehen sich wie gesagt auf die Waffe der Figur. Sie verändern das Schussverhalten der Waffe. Ohne Upgrades hat die Waffe ein Verhalten wie eine normale Handfeuerwaffe mit einer Schusskapazität von 8 Schüssen, was sich aber ändert, wenn man ein Upgrade aufsammelt. Die Upgrades sind in kleinen Boxen die mit einem Buchstaben gekenntzeichnet sind.Ein paar Beispiele:

S = Shotgun (Schrotflinte: kurze Distanz, großer Trefferbereich und eliminiert Gegner meist bei dem ersten Treffer)
B = Burst      (Drei-Schuss-Bertieb: 3 Schüsse hintereinander, punktgenaues Zielen und tötet wenn alle 3 Schüsse treffen)
L = Laser      (Laser-Schuss: Ein langer Strahl, punktgenaues Zielen und tötet auch meist beim ersten Treffer)

Es gibt noch weitere Upgrades die man finden kann. Erwähnenswert ist noch, dass sich die Schusskapazität mit dem jeweiligem Upgrade verändert.
Im Gegensatz zu den passiven Upgrades können die aktiven Upgrades nicht gesammelt werden, das heißt: Wenn man ein Upgrade einsammelt, verschwindet das Upgrade, welches man davor hatte.

Die aktiven Upgrades findet man in kleinen Höhlen, welche am Rand des Spiels liegen und mit einer Blase am Eingang makiert ist. Wenn man in dieser Blase steht,ist die Zeit außerhalb der Blase angehalten, das heißt, dass Gegner bewegungslos stehen bleiben.
Noch zu erwähnen wäre, dass wenn ihr ein Upgrade aufsammelt, es euch einen Trefferpunkt wieder gibt.

2. *Edelsteine*

Edelsteine erscheinen, wenn man Gegner getötet hat, ein Gegenstand der irgendwo stand zerstört hat oder einen Stein, welcher einen Edelstein in sich hatte zerstört hat.
Die Edelsteine können in unterschiedlichen Größen vorkommen, was soviel bedeutet wie : Großer Edelstein = mehr Punkte.
Wenn man genug Edelsteine in kurzer Zeit eingesammelt hat, wird die Figur "Gemhigh", bedeutet dass die Schüsse mehr Kraft haben und mehr Schaden austeilen. Am Ende des Spiels helfen dir Edelsteine neue Modi und Farbpaletten für das Spiel freizuschalten.

3. *Gegner*

Natürlich gibt es auch Gegner die einem den Abstieg erschweren (wäre ja sonst langweilig). Das können am Anfang kleine Quallen sein, auf die man nur springen muss, oder kleine stachelige Gegner die man lieber abschießen sollte. Es gibt aber auch Gegner welche sich nicht abschießen lassen, wobei man dann nur auf sie sprigen kann.
Je tiefer man kommt desto unterschiedliche Gegner kommen, mit denen man unterschiedlich umgehen muss.

4. *Freischaltbares*

Wenn man genug Punkte erspielt hat, kann man sowohl diverse Modi als auch Farb-Paletten bekommen.
Die Modi verändern das Spiel ein wenig, wie zum Beispiel dass weniger Shops und dafür mehr Upgrades für Waffen vorkommen.
Die Farb-Paletten verändern die Optik des Spieles, sodass es an andere ältere Konsolen erinnern soll wie den guten alten Gameboy, aber auch einfach nur die Farbe ändern.

5. *Shops*

Zu den Shops kann ich leider noch nicht soviel sagen, außer, dass ihr ihn im Spiel am Rand wie die aktiven Upgrades findet. Er ist mit einem kleinen Schild mit den Buchstaben "SHOP" gekennzeichnet. 
Wenn ihr hinein geht, könnt ihr mit den Edelsteinen, welche ihr im Spiel gesammelt habt ein paar Sachen kaufen, was die meisten aber machen hat sich mir noch nicht ganz offenbart.

Fazit:

Downwell hat für mich diesen Faktor, dass ich immer wieder herunter will um zu schauen, wie die tieferen Ebenen aussehen. Die vielen Upgrades und Waffen sind ganz witzig und können das Spiel etwas beinflussen.

Alles in allem ist mir dieses Spiel seinen Preis schon wert und man sollte dem Spiel eine Chance geben.

18523321.review: Hi!  Do you like video games?  Okay, please buy Downwell right away!!

18521037.review:
Downwell is a roguelite platformer that excels in its design.

The game appears very simple as it consists of going down procedurally generated levels with only three keys to use: left, right and jump (sadly not possible to rebind... at least both arrows and WASD can be used). While in the air, jump becomes shoot, and the character shoots guns from its feet. Landing allows to reload. Pretty straight-forward.

And then, a ton of little details come into place. Some enemies can only be killed by jumping on them, some enemies can only be killed by shooting at them, and the information is graphically conveyed to the player through a color code. There are different kinds of weapons in side caves (the shotgun feels amazing) and different upgrades to choose from at the end of a level. Those upgrades add a lot of flavor to the game and change the tactical possibilities, such as rocket/fire jumps that kill enemies but also destroy blocks. Each set of levels is very different further down, adding new dangers and enemy behaviors.

There is a second system that allows to upgrade the character, which takes the form of shops that sell health and weapon charges (more charges permit to have more ammo while in the air, and thus to shoot a few more bullets). Health is very precious as there seem to be little ways to recover it, however shops always sell a few health points. Other ways to get health are  a slight chance while occasionally picking up a new gun, and there is an upgrade that allows to eat enemy corpses. And even that upgrade is not overpowered as it forces the player to take risks in order to touch enough bodies in dangerous areas. The health in shops pushes the player to actively seek out gems, which is the currency of the game. Gems obtained through a run also count to a permanent progression system, unlocking new color palettes for the graphics, and new styles/classes (such as a style with more health, but less upgrades to choose from). When a certain amount of gems has been reached, there is some sort of frenzy which allows the player to earn more gems for each enemy killed and new gems obtained keep the frenzy going. Similarly, doing combos without touching the ground has a chance to get health back. Thus the game subtly pushes the player to play better and take more risks!

Every little bit has been polished and it shows. The controls are tight and the character is perfectly maneuverable, the game feels great, fun and accessible while requiring a lot of skill to progress farther through the levels. First off I want to say I went into this game completely blind, I had no idea who made it or who the publisher was or anything until i started up the game. I was just looking for something decent  to play and this was very affordable. 

The game starts off  very simple, you're on the surface and you jump down a well and that's mostly it for the story so far. As you continue you realize how tight the game is and how good it feels to play, jumping off enemies heads and using your guns to boost yourself up and shoot enemies below which drop gems that you can use to buy items to make you better as you delve deeper in the well, also when you die I beleive either your expierence or your gems unlock new things in the game like guns, themes, and more.

It's really not the most complicated game in the world but for me it's really quite enjoyable and tight, the thrill of risking to jump on an enemies head or shoot them down one more time risking your final bit of HP only to pull it off, fall into a room where a shop is and finally be able to heal is something amazing.

18516425.review:
from what i can tell, a lot of people have been waiting on this game for quite a while, and i can definitely see why.

i think the best way to describe downwell would be "spelunky as interpreted by vlambeer." it pairs spelunky's roguelike platforming and astute enemy designs with vlambeer's arcade-y fast pace, ridiculous + satisfying weapons, nuclear throne-esque perk system, and, well, screen shake. progress downward, jump on some enemies, shoot others with your rad gunboots, collect gems, die a lot. it's fun!

frankly i'm amazed that downwell is only $3. its artwork and visual style are beautiful and distinctive, its gameplay is challenging and addictive, its controls are tight, its music (by eirik suhrke, who you may know from his work in spelunky and a few vlambeer titles) is cool and groovy as hell and i certainly don't mind hearing it over and over. the sound design (by joonas turner, who you may know from his work in vlambeer's nuclear throne) makes every weapon so much fun to use. it's endlessly entertaining, and on top of the main game itself there are tons of unlocks to add some additional challenge and variation (i'm a big fan of all the palette options tbh).

downwell is loaded with polish and personality, and it's a steal at $3. if it sounds like your kind of game, buy it, you'll have a blast. i'm absolutely looking forward to future games from moppin.

18511466.review:
https://youtu.be/i5C1Uj7jJCg

[h1][b][i]Downwell[/i][/b] is a vertical action platformer with roguelike elements.[/h1] The game's premise is simple: you are a young person traveling down a mysterious well full of monsters and treasure. Your only weapon is a pair of ultra-cool [b]Gunboots[/b] that help you by both slowing your fall and shooting up monsters. It's insane, and I love it.

This is the first commercial release by [url=https://twitter.com/moppin_]Ojiro Fumoto[/url], a Japanese indie game developer. It's obvious that his game design has been influenced a lot by Vlambeer. It's got all the right ingredients: simple gameplay that's easy to learn but tough to master, the addictive qualities of an arcade game, and lots of screenshake. If you like to compare games, the best way to describe this is like a mix of [i]Nuclear Throne[/i] and [i]Super Crate Box[/i].

[i]Downwell[/i] isn't an easy game. It's fast paced with a good variety of hazards and enemies to fight. Some can be killed through headstomps [i]Mario[/i]-style, while others can only be dispatched with your Gunboots. There are 4 different levels with 3 stages apiece (as well as an endboss), and each of them have different themes that challenge the player. However, you can't save your progress at any point with checkpoints or files: you need to perform perfectly if you want to beat the game. It's not impossible; beating a stage will let you choose from character upgrades [i]Nuclear Throne[/i]-style, and you can find different gun modules that change up your weapon. Like [i]Super Crate Box[/i], weapon pickups are a risk/reward affair. They all handle differently from each other, and you may prefer some to others so much you might skip some. The catch is that they will always give you an upgrade of either refilling your HP or increasing your max ammo capacity. Combined with a selection of 5 different playstyles to choose from, this game ensures that each run you have will be fresh and fun. Playthroughs usually last anywhere from 5 - 20 minutes, which keeps you coming back for more. It's perfect for players who like to invest their game time in short bursts while requiring quick reflexes and providing unique experiences.

The production values for this game are [b]excellent[/b]. [url=https://phlogiston.bandcamp.com/album/downwell]Eirik Suhrke[/url], the composer of [i]Spelunky[/i]'s soundtrack, put together some amazing chiptune tracks. [i]Uroburos[/i], the first level's song, features some great Gameboy-like bass and a great catchy beat to smash monsters to. The music perfectly sets the stage for a strange but epic journey into the depths. It sounds foreboding, but it's never dreary enough to turn you away. Coupled with the great sound design by [url=https://twitter.com/KissaKolme]Joonas Turner[/url] of [i]Nuclear Throne[/i], this game feels extremely satisfying to play. His gunshots and explosions are full of punch, and every sound you hear else fits right in with the game's aesthetic. I almost wish he had made more sound effects for all of the monsters, like cries of pain as you stomp and shoot them into oblivion. The bitcrushed shrieks and laughs are sure to give you chills. The visuals are cute and minimalistic, sticking to a 3-tone color palette that still conveys all the right information to the player. Enemies are highlighted with a blend of 2 colors, while tougher ones stick out with 1 bold tone. Though they aren't highly detailed, the animations bring so much life to all of the characters. Everything about this game [b]feels[/b] great, and it's nice to know that they put such love and care into the design of a simple game.

Not everyone would like this game, though. It's really difficult, and it can discourage new players from the beginning, especially since there's no saving. The high skill ceiling might keep you on the first few floors for a while, so practice is crucial to moving on to the later parts. Some may find the pixel graphics unimpressive and hard to read because of the lack of coloring. There's other small problems with user interface, like a lack of personal control binding and no option to reduce or remove the screenshake. Some of the finer mechanics like wall-jumping, combos, and increasing max HP are left ambiguous to the player as well. You might complain that it feelsl ike just another mobile port from the lack of support, but fortunately, the developer has promised to change up the interface in future patches. 

Still, even if you're on the fence about playing this game, I'd recommend to everybody to get it. It might be the best game I've played all year, and it's only $3 and available on mobile. Plus, it also tends to go on sale quite frequently, so it's definitely worth a dollar or two to grab! It has tremendous replay value and the amount of work put into it is very admirable. It's been applauded by many other indie devs (who have probably made some of your favorite games as well), including Derek Yu of [i]Spelunky[/i] and J.W. Nijman of Vlambeer. It was made by one guy who lovingly paid attention to every detail and knows exactly how to design a fun game. It's a work of art that has simple but distinct mechanisms and a lot of moving parts, and once you understand how it works and how to best play it, it flows like music. I love it, and I hope you do too. It's definitely one of my favorite games of 2015.

[b]TL; DR:[/b] For fans of [i]Super House of Dead Ninjas[/i], [i]Probability 0[/i], [i]Spelunky[/i], [i]Nuclear Throne[/i], [i]Super Crate Box[/i], and good games in general. :)

18511087.review:
https://youtu.be/Tqd18gSyY0c

Downwell is as straight forward an entry into the rogue-like style as it’s name suggests. You play as a young boy who jumps down a well in search of treasure. Armed with your trusty gunboots, you must journey deeper down this well, destroy the many enemy creatures, as well as collect all the gems you can as you inch closer to the final boss. Along your path are random time safety bubbles that hold more treasures, alterations to your gunboots, as well as various stores you can spend your found treasure at for things like extra health.

The basic game play may seem like it gets old pretty quick, but the glory of Downwell‘s design is the additional boosters you can pick up, not to mention the tight, frantic combat that occurs as you plummet uncontrollably down the well itself. After each section you are given a choice between three power-ups (more if you happen to get the power-up that allows for more power-ups to choose from) that alter your game play. These include random safety time bubbles upon being hit, a drone to deal extra damage, even just health refills or simple things like dead bodies firing a random bullet, or even the ability to eat said dead bodies to slowly regain health. There’s also the option of a balloon, but it’s more just a random cosmetic accessory that easily pops than anything all that beneficial.

What’s more, the combat punishes you for moving fast. There are a lot of times where enemies will begin to swarm you all at once, forcing you to descend a lot slower than you might want. This actually works in your favor, causing you to have to think out a plan to avoid being hit, or how to reach certain enemies since you might not be able to jump above them and fire with your boots, or have enough room to not get hit while attacking them. This title also does run on Super Mario Bros. rules as far as that fighting system goes, allowing for a number of foes to be defeated by jump/landing on top of them. However, there are a few that cause damage if you do this, such as the spike shelled snails on the wall, the random Space Invaders looking bat, or the floating glowing orbs, so you still have to be somewhat vigilant in how you dispatch these creatures.

There’s also the unlockable elements the gems provide, such as the various palettes you can earn that crawl the span of early gaming graphics. Much of them revolve around the days of the Nintendo Entertainment System or the Sega Master System, but you can unlock others like “GBOY”, a black and green Nintendo Gameboy style, as well as “VBOY” which, as you would guess, is the all red line against black background look of the failed Nintendo Virtual Boy sans the three-dimensional aspect. Even the screen is heavily condensed to represent an early arcade machine look without going overboard and including a fake glass layer with reflecting flourescent lights from the background.

Sadly, there is only one difficulty available upon purchasing. There is no easy or hard mode available right out the gate, nor do I think an easy mode even exists, really. Downwell seems to move along at a standard medium difficulty setting, but you can unlock a hard mode [which I have yet to do] for a grander challenger. But, even at medium difficulty, Downwell is still a pretty tense game, one that will have you struggling in the first set of stages alone despite the many side rooms that offer a bonus health and gunboot upgrade, or downgrade based on your weapon preference. Thankfully gems also unlock new character designs that come with additional boosts or restrictions to add more tension or to make things a little easier.

Downwell is a very well constructed title with tight controls, battles, and even visuals. At launch, you can pick this one up for three dollars (US currency), and, honestly, it’s well worth the investment. While the unlocks are often minimal and visual alterations, the difficulty and learning curve really leaves more to discover about the game than just what you happen to see. The only major problem to be had is that the music for each set of stages seems fairly short, having to repeat itself more than you would like, not to mention also sounds like many other memorable scores like the flying ship stages of Super Mario Bros. 3 and the opening notes of the Final Fantasy VII victory battle theme. But, if you can look past those minor things, you will find a great deal of fun in this small package, making Downwell an addicting reverse Ice Climber style title that is well worth diving head first into.

Downwell is a surprisingy well polished, but also simple and small game. The only thing this game needs is more content, but because it only costs 3€, that isn't meant as criticism. This game is so addicting and satisfying to play, the sound design is especially great. Also the upgrades you can choose from after every stage are all useful and fun, which isn't the norm with rouge-lites these days. The unlocks you get from your playthroughs are a bit dissapointing, especially the color palettes which just change up the colors a bit and probably weren't even a huge effort for the developer. If the game had a ton more upgrades, they could lock some of them away as unlocks, which not only rewards every single run, it also motivates new playthroughs. I think when you beat the final boss you unlock a "hard mode", but that's about it.
Downwell is small, simple, it doesn't try to do much, but what it wants to do it does exceptionally well.
I hope there will be a big expansion for this game, with tons more upgrades to choose from, more levels, more unlocks, different game modes, and of course more weapons. It would be cool if you could also upgrade the weapons or something like that. Anyway, Downwell is definitly worth the 3€ if you're a fan of platformers or rogue-lites.

18498604.review:
Great game.  Good to play in either short or long bursts, since each run can range from 20 or so seconds to maybe under 20 minutes at the longest (no idea yet, haven't gotten past the third area).  It's got really smooth controls and fun gameplay as well as plenty of different customization and character styles (changes your character as well as how the run will go, somewhat like the characters you're able to play in Binding of Isaac, but without as many playstyle differences).  

The only downsides I currently see in this game is that it's short, doesn't have that many shop items, weapon types, or end-of-level items (you'll encounter all of them within your first hour of playing), and I don't think there's too much replayability once you've beat the game a few times (again, I haven't beaten it yet so I honestly don't know).  

As for now, though, I'm enjoying this addictive little rogue-like.  I think it fits the price well for the amount of content that it offers, just don't expect to get more than 15-20 hours out of this game (at the most probably).

Definitely pick it up if you have $3 to spare!

All around great little arcade game, especially for only $3. Definitely Worth. 10/10

Just played for about one hour and I gotta say, anyone who likes fastpaced, tightly controlled action should pick this up.

The graphics are minimal, but charming and they read very well. Everything is easy to see and has nice little animations which adds a lot to the gamefeel, esp when it comes to picking up and shooting things.

The music and sfx are very nice as well and fit the atmosphere of the game.

The gameplay is wonderful. It takes a while to get to know the different enemy types and how to approach them, but they are all managable and the colour coding is cleverly done. Any enemy that is almost entirely or entirely red can not be stomped and has to be shot to be killed. The enemies also have a nice variety in how they move, keeping you on your toes. And then on top of this you get a bunch of different weapons to find and upgrades which greatly add to the game too.

All I can say to sum it up, if you like action and got $2.99 handy, get this. You wont regret it.

18488808.review:
Downwell is a platforming roguelike, in which you fall downard while shooting at enemies(Sort of like the cave story way of gun jumping).  You get weapons (similar to contra's style.  There's various siderooms with nodes that have a letter on them, corresponding with what the gun is.), powerups between stages(3 stages in 1 level), and can even buy items with benifits from shop rooms.  

Collecting coins lets you not only buy from the shop, but also moves you toward progressing on permanent stuff like color schemes (Default, Aqua, Green, Gameboy Classic, Virtual Boy, etc), similar to how Luftrausers works.  You also get a few alternate guys to pick at the start.  They all have pros and cons, with the default being the most generally well balanced.

The art (and controls) reminds me of another Devolver game, Luftrausers. The art style is simple but well done, and is very pleasing to the eyes.   The various color schemes you can choose really help enchance the game and let you personalize it.  

Similar to Luftrausers, the platforming is very fluid and I feel like if I die its entirely my fault.   That's how a platformer/roguelike should be.   My main complaint is weird hitboxes with the bats, but everything else feels solid.


The rng isn't too heavy, while still making the game fun and exciting.  What upgrade is going to be in this sideroom or what upgrade will I be able to choose?  It's small rng, but for the most part is controllable.

Overall, if you like fun/addicting games to play in short burst, then Downwell is a great choice.   For only $3 bucks at full price, you can easily get over 3+ hours of it in no time.

18486188.review:
I did a quick review of Downwell here:

https://youtu.be/VlBkLIDNirw

Transcript: 

Hey there everybody, I am Draz, and welcome to my first impressions of a game that just came out today, Downwell. As you may guess by the name, Downwell is a game about... well, falling down a well. What initially intrigued me about downwell is one of the core mechanics of the game, your gunboots. They act exactly as they sound and allow you to fire shots out of your feet, attacking enemies below you. The main focus of the game is trying to make it as far as you can without dying. Downwell has some aspects of a "rogue-lite" type of game, such as randomly generated levels. As you fall, you will also occasionally encounter side areas and shops that might contain upgrades and gems that are used as currency. Some items might simply increase the number of shots you can fire from your gunboots before you need to reload, while others change the way your gunboots work, such as adding rapid fire or causing them to fire in a shotgun-type blast.

Now that we've covered the game mechanics themselves, let's talk about the game's controls. The game feels like a dream, the controls are extremely responsive and I never once felt like I didn't have control of my character. In addition to jumping and moving around, if you are near a wall and jump away from it, you can wall jump for extra height. It all feels extremely natural.

The combat itself boils down to jumping on enemies a la Mario, and shooting them with your gunboots. Some enemies have spiky shells that prevent you from jumping on them, requiring you to use your gunboots on them. You have a certain number of shots that you can fire with your gunboots before you run out, at which point you can reload simply by landing on the ground (or an enemy). Some enemies maneuver their way above you, causing problems that way and forcing you to either get above them to attack, or keep moving downward.

The game's difficulty felt spot on, to me. Between the combat and the controls working extremely well, I never had a death that I felt I didn't deserve. 

The game's sound is top-notch. The sound effects of the gunboots feel absolutely perfect, and really added that extra punch to the combat. The music itself felt spot on, too. It really fit the game without feeling distracting or taking me out of it.

Overall, the game is a ton of fun to play, and I would highly recommend it. For only a few bucks, it is an absolute steal, and it's on both PC and iOS, with an Android version in the works. You should definitely check it out. Thank you guys for watching, and I'll catch you next time.
